y 27, 2016
												Tl;Dr - I'd give X Rebirth an 8 out of 10. It's an incredibly fun, diverse game with plenty of things to do. The Steam reviews do not represent the game in its current state.Let me start by saying this to prospective buyers; X Rebirth is NOT X4. It's a game set in the X universe, and aspired to be a new game entirely - Something which I think it has done very, very well.You can only fly one ship. This ship is virtually your own Millennium Falcon - It's unique, incredibly powerful, and quite customizable, and is basically a few different ships in one package. If you were able to fly multiple types of ships, you'd probably go for this one every time.Now, onto the review.You'll notice that X Rebirth has a very low score on Steam. Don't judge a book by its cover - Most of these scores were given around the time of v1.0, or were given by people who don't read up on a game before they buy it.X Rebirth 1.0 was a shoddy mess, virtually an early beta of a game with clunky mechanics, bad voice acting, and more glitches than you could possibly imagine. Most people dropped X Rebirth straight off the bat, gave it a bad review, and never looked back.Not long after that, however, 2.0 came out and completely revolutionized the game. Everything was streamlined and most of the problems fixed, and the game became more or less playable, and even pretty enjoyable. A few patches later and the game was pretty much how you'd expect a game to be at launch, with hundreds upon hundreds of hours of content (If you're a creative person) and lots of ways to make your empire what you want it to be - If you want an empire at all, that is.The story was honestly not that compelling, but there's plenty of reasons to play it as it confers unique bonuses on certain systems that free play simply would not, such as more diverse economies in certain systems.3.0 rolled around at the end of 2014, only a year after the game's release, and set the bar higher than before. The game became much, much more fun, now with a total of 5 systems to explore (Note that each system has multiple sectors, each of which is bigger than a system from previous X games) as well as dozens of factions to meet, hundreds of ships and stations to build and use, and wares to mine, manufacture, and trade.X Rebirth today is an incredibly fun game. A single save could take hundreds of hours of your time as you build yourself an empire in a system. You could start a new game and take a completely different route, giving you hundreds more hours of gameplay as you make a name for yourself elsewhere. The sky's the limit with your choices in X Rebirth.While there are still a few glitches and bad mechanics to the game, most of it has been smoothed out. With the upcoming Home of Light DLC, the world is set to almost double in size and have many new factions to play with.If you're looking for X4, don't bother with X Rebirth. If you're looking for a new and fun space business and combat sim that'll provide hours of fun, then X Rebirth is the game for you.

												This was supposed to be an improvement over previous versions, but other than the graphics, soundtrack and the return of a visible and usefull cockpit it does not live up to the expectations, nor the X title.First of all your immediate surroundings look cramped, and I'm not talking about the ship interior... It used to be a lot more spaced out and felt more of...well...space... The upscaling of the stations certainly did not do the game any good as well, as it only contributes to that same feeling. It really feels as though your in the middle of a concert than in space.Second, the controls...I don't know what came over the developers when figuring this out, but after all the hard work they put in the X3 engine I really expected more. I found it near impossible to target a station to dock with, not to mention it being counter-intuitive; While you could click on a ship in the distance to target, get info, whatever, on stations that simply doesn't work. The menu system was a lot sleaker and less cumbersome as well, it reacted a lot faster without all the fancy animations / transitions and the general feel complemented the game as a whole. And although I like the idea of a board computer that gives that feeling of your character actually interacting with a computer, unless you run at a very high resolution it is very difficult to actually read what it's displaying (played on 1280x800).Last but not least, the lanes...why...why not have sectors overlap eachother so you don't need all that fancy stuff, or load based on the ships radar distance...there are so many alternatives to using jump gates (if that was the goal) that are not so much of a nuisance.I have played every X game, and have loved every single one of them, regardless of the terrible characters and all that; That somehow became part of the charm. But I seriously believe this to be a big mistake made by EgoSoft. If they wanted to make an engine / game that looked and felt so immensely different from the rest of the X series, they should really have experimented with some arbitrary new title that has nothing to do with it; A once off game that may have the potential to grow into an entirely new series, or merge with the X series at a later time, whatever. It would have been a lot better than take a succesfull series and throw it down the toilet like this.

I miss the fact that it was possible in X3 to personally fly any ships in the galaxy.  I am tired of being called a skunk and this ship is not impressive in no way. It gets easily shot even after upgrading and it is hard to hit anything with it.  After 25 hours trying to figure out the mechanics of the game, I am barely able to trade, defend and manage anything.  The trading system requires that you own a station in order to do anything significant.  I find it hard to understand why I need to be soo close to docking points to only get very limited information. (even after upgrades)  I would assume that a trading dock would advertise what it is doing, right???  It is strange how everyone knows everything about the galaxy while I can barely remember anything about the station I visited.  Just one word I want to add, sunglasses, they were discovered millenniums ago... they seem to have forgotten about this very advanced technology.  It kills the graphics quality, sad.   I am complaining a lot, but I am sure I will finally get through the very complex mechanics of this game.  I think there is interesting ideas about it, I would simply appreciate ameliorations on the trading system.

content:
1, 2015
												First let me mention this game is much better with a few mods which you can get from the workshop or nexusmods. I do like this game but my review focuses more on what I don't like about it. You play as Ren Otani, pilot of the Albion Skunk (You can change the ship name!), a small space craft seemingly about the size of the Millennium Falcon. The engines, weapons, shield, ect can be upgraded. While you can't pilot any other vessel, you can acquire and issue commands to pretty much any class ship in the game. Your ships will also watch you get destroyed unless you tell them to attack each target one at a time or agro on every enemy they get in range of which will just cause unnecessary engagement. There really needs to be a "destroy anyone attacking your squad" option.I can see a lot of work went into this game and the scripting is impressive but it was obviously rushed out of production and nearly committed suicide by releasing in what was basically an unmarked beta stage. The bugs were so bad people started thinking if they couldn't find something it was a bug so they would just edit their save file as a fix. Currently most alleged "bugs" are due to "user error" and you should probably visit youtube before doing anything drastic like saved file editing but there are still a few minor bugs/issues.The biggest issue remaining in this game is the lack of in game information. Not only on how to do anything or where to start looking for a particular item but also info such as how a crew skill stats affect anything and the fact that you can't buy cargolifter drones from drone dealers but rather ship dealers at a shipyard.The economy is very much like elite dangerous but not quite as bad. NPC ships spawn in with cargo and deliver it to stations if you don't intervene. That cargo is then used to build parts to be sold to the quickest buyer, to build ships you order or NPC ships that do nothing but despawn shortly after construction. If a shipyard is constructing a (NPC) ship you can't use it for repairs, buying drones or anything. To make things worse if the shipyard doesn't have the resources for the ship it's building you can wait for a delivery if it ever happens or find and sell them the parts your self. Stations can't be obliterated or taken over, only badly damaged but they will get repaired after a time.The only station players can't build is a shipyard but fortunately there is a mod for that.I must mention once you acquire a missile on your ship, there is no way to remove it from the weapon list even after getting rid of it. Nothing like flipping through 10 types of missiles during the midst of combat looking for one you DO have. Also the same button for missile launching is used for scanning which is the equivalent of modifying a hand gun to function as a lighter when the safety is on. Additionally you will encounter a similar issue with your main guns, only two of which are deemed useful in combat but you may not want to toss your mining laser (oddly enough Elite Dangerous did the same thing).AI in this game must stand for "Artificial Idiots" because it has caused me several saved game reloads. Once my ship auto piloted it's way into the center of a station trapping me inside and another time my fleet of rihannas tried to jump through a warp gate all at the same time causing what looked like an Autobahn pile up.Graphics aren't bad for the most part but they do look years behind and nothing close to Elite Dangerous. The face textures for station crew however are kind of horrendous and everyone has a face only a mother could love.It's unfortunate there aren't more people playing this game because a broader audience would mean more modders and the modding community is what made this game enjoyable (rather than a tedious head ach) to me. But the bottom line is, if you can put up with a bit of a learning curve, enjoy long relaxing space flights and dogfight style combat intertwined with the strategy aspect of fleet commanding then this game is worth buying but best wait for a sale because $40 is a bit much unless they release a 4k graphical pack and more updates (last one being released Mar 13) to fix the things so many people are complaining about.

												I had great expectations of this game. I preordered it and woke up at 4 am to play it... and got very very disappointed.The introduction of your first officer is a prime example of most of this game: tacked on!The new highway system is fun, but once you get to a place that is sparsly populated, you will spend long minutes travelling though each highway segiment.The rework of how AI and ship commands work leave you manually controlling your ship at all times and with next to no options for controlling your ships. For most players most of the time, the only command you can give your ships is to follow you.At release, this game had a large number of game-breaking bugs that left me stuck for hours and restarting the game 4 times before i managed to break though them.The easy to use, easy to find stuff in map present in previous X games has been redesigned and is now extremely awkward and hard to navigate to say the least. It is extremely hard to find a commodity when you are searching for one and even harder to remember the convoluted way to set the station as an objective.It is very clear that the user interface of this game was build to mainly appeal to game controllers. The layout of UI makes mouse contol nothing short of painful and getting joysticks to work is an art. Don't even think of trying to use a HOTAS.The combat system and space graphics are extremely good and nothing beats the satisfaction of blowing up a hostile will your guns (which entails the best explosion graphics i have EVER seen). Although many people complain about the cut and paste station interiors, I like them. Sure it isn't as good as we could have hoped but it still give SOME level of personal feel. I would definitely love to go back to the menu system though. The reworked level of activity in space is another big pro and gives the X universe a more awesome feel to it.Never the less, due to what I have stated here and an endless list of additional issues, this game is a huge leap back from previous titles and should be avoided at all costs. I hope with all my heart that Egosoft learns from this horrific mistake and look forward to the next installment of the X series. Despite X Rebirth, I can't deny that the X series is still my favourite sci-fi space ship sim. I highly recommend that any player go and buy X3 Terran Conflict as well as seriously consider X3 Reunion and X3 Albion Prelude.

												X: Rebirth is not an X series game. If you are trying to buy it while expecting such, dont. It is simply unsatisfying to play if you are looking for anything more complex than a space shooter.The developers spent 7 years working on the game to release for console, so the interface, options, and controls suffer from that design decision. As of this review, there is no way to target enemies besides clicking on them, all the menus are radial and difficult to navigate, and overall the performace of the game, even on high-end rigs, is poor.Being stuck in the same ship the entire game (The Albion Skunk, endearing..) is unsatisfying, especially when you see all the other cool looking ships flying around. Your co-pilot is annoying as humanly possible, your ship is invulnerable if you activate a drone, and you cannot carry any cargo inside of it. You have to hire other people to fly your other ships and carry cargo for you, and they have to be the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ pilots ever.The combat is weak and unchallenging. Enemies have spawned inside other ships and inside stations on several occasions, or they will just spawn in empty space and sit there, doing nothing as you blow them up. Though, why you would blow them up is a mystery, as they never shoot at you.The only good thing about the game is that stations look and feel truly alive and massive, with tons of npc ships flying around them and giving them satisfying feel. Unfortunately even this is ruined as the developers turned it into a minigame, making you fly and look at every inch of these massive stations to get missions and discounts. I won't even go into detail about docking and walking around inside of them, as that has to be the absolute worst part of the game, and you should live in fear of it. Overall, this is not an X game in the slightest, and was released in a state not fit for human consumption. Do not buy, and do not support a company that releases games in such a state. Everyone will tell you that the modders will fix it, or that the company will, and that is not an acceptable excuse for such a mess. 												I wanted this game since release, I’m a fan of the X series since “X2 the threat”. I tried it then and It was terrible. I tried it during a free weekend trial and loved it. I bought it during the sale associate to this free week end. How the devs released the game was a shame but now things are going. And the modders help a lot to get there! So first to be clear in its current state the game is enjoyable (without mods but the mods will make it so much better so mod it!), it is not like the original x series but it not a bad point not at all. Indeed they removed a lot of the micromanagement parts and now your ships are more autonomous, I said autonomous not smart the AI is really weak some times. Now you have a crew and they do have skill which increase the immersion you do have the impression of having people manning your ships. And nothing worth the sight of one of your  capital ship pounding another capital ship, while it send a swarm of drones and the flak lighting all around! All of this to come to a massive explosion of the defeated ship and fearing for crew and there hard to get 5 stars skills. So the battles are enjoyable, and you can just look at them or jump in action. The progression curve is much faster than in the previous Xs a bit too fast to my taste but I’m a bit of a masochist player! For instance you can capture enemy capital ship very early in the game, the gameplay is a bit repetitive but still fun and rewarding. What I mean here is you get bored of capturing them when you have more than enough! Speaking of boring the minigames (there is a mod for to make that much better) are still there, while less mandatory still mandatory to get permanent station price update (there is a mod too)  which you can’t do without it if you want to trade.As well there is only on pilotable ship that you can upgrade while this lack of diversity it feel as well a bit cheated as you end up with an small ship as resilient and power full as a cap ship and as fast and nimble as a fighter. Ultimately while having its shortcoming x rebirth is a really enjoyable game and I’m now more than 40h playing it and I do not plan to stop there. Hell my empire await and I still have to set-up my siege against those PMC stations!

												-- The good --1. Great soundtrack2. Nice visuals3. Flying around with a sense of discovery-- The Bad --1. Broken campaign scripting2. Outdated and CPU dependent graphics engine3. Ridiculous co-pilot AI4. Horrible female NPC models5. Limited field of view6. No exterior cameras7. Can only fly one ship8. Unprofessional acting in dialogues9. Unintuitive UI10. No ship scanner for entire stations (need to go around every station's info points to know what it is selling/buying)15. Unintuitive order assignment / unassignment to other ships (example, trade orders cancelation)16. No "next target" key binding (you have to select enemies with your mouse cursor)17. The station's interiors are copy-paste from one another.18. No "ship radar". You have to steer your ship around to locate other ships (friends/foes)19. I bet i'm fogetting others...-- Conclusion --Thought it would be a nice EVE Online alternative (i'm a pilot there for 9 years) but compared to EVE, X:R is more like a weekend coded game. I dont understand how Egosoft with so many years of experience in the X series could make such a bottom level product, even the trading aspect of it. It seems that it wasnt tested and they sold a beta version. Also, it looks like a console port that was cancelled and rushed to PC... Ppl say it's trandition from Egosoft to ship bugged games and they get patched in the future. This reflects poor or non-existent testing, an incompetent QA department and all around bad managment.Not at all recommended.

content:
ry 16, 2015
												When Egosoft's X3 first came out, I learned first-hand that it installed Starforce malware, so I complained on the Egosoft forums.  They were offended by my complaints and gave me a warning, so I swore off any future Egosoft purchases.  X Rebirth made me change my mind.  (Plus there's no Starforce this time!!!)When Rebirth first came out I did a lot of research and learned that it was a big mess.  So I waited for over a year, did more research, and found that it was faring much better.  This got me to finally buy it during a Steam sale.  Man I'm glad I did!I'm a big sci-fi fan.  I played Freelancer in the past, and am currently playing Starpoint Gemini 2 and Elite Dangerous off and on.X Rebirth is one of the best single-player space experiences I've ever had.  I can see what Egosoft was trying to do with this game, and I think it shines.  Are all the negative reviews warranted?  Early on I'd say absolutely.  But they've patched it up and added to it quite a bit since then.  In my 106 hours of playing I've only had one glitch, and that was getting stuck during docking.  I simply undocked and redocked to fix it.I played the campaign up until the point that I came back to Albion from DeVries and was hostile to everyone.  It was then that I restarted in free mode and have never looked back.  I've upgraded my Skunk to the MK5 shields, the MK3 weapon, and only have 2 more pieces until I have my MK5 engine.  I have the Skunk and 1 Fedhelm freighter, so the plan now is to learn capturing to expand my fleet.  I'd also like to dabble in station building.  There's so much more to do.I've spent a lot of time just travelling around mapping my way and doing missions.  Sightseeing in this game is visually rewarding.  I've gotten used to the flight physics and combat and can hold my own very well.  I've been playing vanilla with no mods the whole time.  I tried changing my cockpit at one point, but none of the others appealed to me.  I've grown used to the clunky large one that came with the Skunk.  I also have no issues with just the one ship.  If I want to get somewhere quick I can dock with my freighter and jump away.Could it be better, sure.  But I think what I've gotten so far for my dollar has paid off in spades.PROS- Visually stunning.- It's as immersive as you allow it to be.- Keyboard/mouse controls are very easy to master and fluid.- Has a decent campaign from what I've played, although I preferred sandbox mode instead.CONS- NPC skins can be horrendous.- Station skins are too repetetive.- Repeating conversations are irksome.- Inability to drop freigher inventory is just plain silly.- Ren and Yisha.  Being able to choose other characters or customize would have been great.Thanks Egosoft!

But they've patched it up and added to it quite a bit since then.  In my 106 hours of playing I've only had one glitch, and that was getting stuck during docking.  I simply undocked and redocked to fix it.I played the campaign up until the point that I came back to Albion from DeVries and was hostile to everyone.  It was then that I restarted in free mode and have never looked back.  I've upgraded my Skunk to the MK5 shields, the MK3 weapon, and only have 2 more pieces until I have my MK5 engine.  I have the Skunk and 1 Fedhelm freighter, so the plan now is to learn capturing to expand my fleet.  I'd also like to dabble in station building.  There's so much more to do.I've spent a lot of time just travelling around mapping my way and doing missions.  Sightseeing in this game is visually rewarding.  I've gotten used to the flight physics and combat and can hold my own very well.  I've been playing vanilla with no mods the whole time.  I tried changing my cockpit at one point, but none of the others appealed to me.  I've grown used to the clunky large one that came with the Skunk.  I also have no issues with just the one ship.  If I want to get somewhere quick I can dock with my freighter and jump away.Could it be better, sure.  But I think what I've gotten so far for my dollar has paid off in spades.PROS- Visually stunning.- It's as immersive as you allow it to be.- Keyboard/mouse controls are very easy to master and fluid.- Has a decent campaign from what I've played, although I preferred sandbox mode instead.CONS- NPC skins can be horrendous.- Station skins are too repetetive.- Repeating conversations are irksome.- Inability to drop freigher inventory is just plain silly.- Ren and Yisha.  Being able to choose other characters or customize would have been great.Thanks Egosoft!

ry 25, 2014
												So you can see that I waited a good while before reviewing this game. I gave the developers time to fix the myriad of experience-killing glitches. I gave them time to fix the game-breaking bugs. It's hopeless at this point. Even if they finally manage to fix the TERRIBLE performance issues on high-end gaming systems, and even if they fix all of the critical flaws in the game, AND even if they go so far as to fix the nearly broken interface -- it won't solve the underlying problem. What is the underlying problem? The basic gameplay is bad. It's just a bad game.Despite some decent ideas and nice-looking visuals (that won't run past 25FPS on my high-end system no matter what I do, a known bug), the game itself just simply isn't good. No matter how much you want to enjoy that classic X3 experience, or how much you want to enjoy a modern space simulator, this isn't the game for you. If you liked X3, don't buy this game. If you like space simulators, don't buy this game. If you like video games, don't buy this game. It has won a place in the hearts of many gamers for being their WORST GAME PURCHASE OF 2013. It is certainly, without question, the worst game purchase I've ever made. Yes, I've purchased some bad games, but never have I paid $50 for a new game and found it so utterly and completely disappointing. Where to begin? Well, the graphics, while decent, are plagued with such terrible slow-down and framerate issues as to be nearly unplayable. The story is tepid at best, with no real attraction. Don't expect the story to pull you in. The characters and voice acting are passable at best, laughably bad at worst. Expect to see the same character models and hear the same voices over, and over, and over. Cut-and-paste characters and space stations are the norm. You'll become very familiar with the two basic layouts you'll encounter dozens upon dozens of times. The music is quite decent, as it does what a good space combat simulator sound track should do -- it creates a nice "cosmic" atmosphere. Nothing that draws your attention too much, but makes you feel like you're in space. The sound FX are also quite decent for the most part, nothing too bad.The gameplay... It's just bad. You can feel like there's a good game deep inside this beast somewhere, but it just can't find it's way out. An attempt to make the game controller-friendly has needlessly obfuscated the interface. Many critical and commonly used functions are buried deep in menus, and you often find that you have to go here or there within the game world just to issue a simplistic command. The "cockpit" that was so painstakingly crafted serves to do little more than just eat up system resources and obscure the screen -- it's not even a HUD integration, it's just a needless visual distraction and resource hog. Whether you use mouse or keyboard, the interface is bad -- just bad. You want some great advice that you'd regret not following? Do not even consider buying this game. Don't look at it, don't watch videos of it, don't make any attempt to think that any amount of patching could fix this mess. It's a broken, clunky, frustrating mess of a game, but it commits the sin of looking like something decent to the uninformed. Consider yourself informed -- don't buy it. DO NOT BUY IT.

												=== Post 2.0 ===I've spent about an hour with the game post 2.0. So far, I am impressed at the sheer number of improvements, I can actually play the game at a more reasonable frame rate (although it still drops below 40 every now and again, especially in the busier sectors). As for the game itself, it’s still single ship – which I don’t mind all that much as long as you can really fit that ship to your needs, something that the original version of the game failed at, This also has been improved upon slightly with the launch of 2.0, I’m very happy to see that the devs are heading in the right direction, but it is still not perfect by any stretch of the imagination.So far I love the new cockpits, especially the mercenary cockpit – an enhanced field of view is very much appreciated.They seem to have made improvements to the traders and cap-ships in general, I’ve seen a couple while flying around the universe – they don’t seem as stuck, lifeless and stupid as the original release – from what I could tell traders were actually trading, combat/defence cap-ships would seek out and destroy enemy craft in the sector and the occurrence of stacks of stuck trade ships in a sector seem to be eliminated.Combat feels a little more difficult – a welcome change, It’s nice to actually feel threatened while engaging a wing of fighters.Dogfighting, while still possible, is a little less reasonable in the Skunk now, forcing a more tactical approach to combat, you can’t just wade in through cap-ships and fighters alike and expect to just survive everything – although that could just be my joystick coming to the end of its life.My Verdict: So far so good, improvements are most welcome, it’s great to see Ego working out these issues and (as always) releasing free content and while the original game was pretty unplayable and hurt fans of the series a quite a bit, it’s nice to see Egosoft not give up on it and just move on to another cashgrab.Overall – I’d recommend this if it is on sale and you found x2 The Threat and x3 Reunion a too complex and daunting but still love space sims. If you can push past some of the questionable design decisions that surely will be phased out over time I think you could find an enjoyable experience in here – one piece of advice though, treat the campaign as a glorified tutorial and go into free play or one of the alt-starts to really experiment and have fun with the game.=== Pre 2.0 review ===A very rocky launch, needs a great deal of fixes, but this might make a good base for future X games. Regardless of what reviews might say I enjoyed this, however progress on patches is too slow. Possibly wait untill they fix the game? Or rather wait for their next ones --- may be more worthwhile.

												X: Rebirth is a game presenting a lot of ideas and potential. The problems is that these ideas aren't always fully implemented or polished. Even though it's been over two years since its release, there are still a ton of bugs and mechanics that doesn't seem to work properly (or user friendly).I love sci-fi, space ships and sandbox worlds. The negative aspect is that you'll need a lot of patience to get to the point where you feel you know what you're doing. I was instantly impressed by the large stations, all the small traffic going on everywhere. This and the fact the game is running a living economy which makes sabotage of stations and trade routes in the end make an impact on prices is the game's strenghts and what makes me want to continue to explore its possibilities.The bad things are a mix of how I would like the game to be:- The total lack of help files or ingame guides of how wares etc are connected.- Some core features that aren't fully thought out and can frustrate the hell out of you - walking in stations and scanning stations to unlock important information are two of those.- A user interface that is more about using the keyboard for chain hot keys than a graphic ui. (Eventually I've gotten used to the interface and more quickly use the Enter 6-6-2 to fast get in contact with a trader remotely. But in the beginning it was something which halted my game experience.*)My final words about this game are these: Egosoft was aiming way beyond their ability to make this game a fully professional and polished product. But since the market for these kind of games doesn't really seem to have the same popularity as Call of Duty etc, the financial funds are thereafter. I admire Egosoft for what they are trying to accomplish and hope they find more people to help them develop future games.* In general I think the keyboard is heavily outdated in design as a control gadget in games...

												I loved X3 reunion and X3 Terran Conflict. They are among my favorite games of all time, so I bought X Rebirth on the strength of how much I had enjoyed them dispite a lot of negative comments. This weekend, Steam had a free weekend which included X3 Albion Prelude which I had not previously played, so I gave it a go and going back to the X3 series has just highlighted to me how rubbish X Rebirth is. I have tried to like X Rebirth, I really have, but Egosoft seem to have ripped out or messed up everything that made X3 enjoyable. No longer do you have a range of ships and weapons to choose from that you can buy and fly. You are stuck with one ship that has a few upgrades available. Trading has been completely messed up. There is remote trading, which is almost completely unfathomable and never seems to offer any profit or there is station trading with half a dozen stock lookalike characters on each station. The best way of making any money in this game seems to revolve around crawling around in air-ducts on the stations and selling the stuff you find there to the locals, which becomes completely boring very quickly.  Combat is another botched up mess. It isn't really clear who you are fighting and I found that destroying Red 'Enemy' ships lost me reputation and unable to dock at the vast majority of stations. Then there are drones. I am yet to figure out what the point of drones are. There is a tutorial in using the spy ones but it failed to explain why you would want to do this. Factory building was great fun in the X3 series and you can build individual or complex factories anywhere you fancy. Not in X Rebirth though. You are limited to a few, game dictated spots and have to hunt high and low for the stuff to make them. The economy is such that it is almost impossible to know what to build where. The transport system has been completely changed. No longer do you have jump gates with the option of jump drives but highways and super-highways to transport you around the universe. This means sometimes you have to go around an entire loop just to move one system. The only good thing I would say about X rebirth, and you would expect this considering the age of the X3 games, is that the graphics have improved.I really looked forward to X Rebirth and perhaps I expected too much after the X3 series but this new incarnation really has torn the heart out of the enjoyment of the game. If you are looking for a good space sim try the X3 series. If you have already, like me, tried the X3 series and liked/loved it, do not buy X rebirth, you will only find dissapointment.To Egosoft - Please think about ditching this disaster and moving on to X4 - X3 with X Rebirth graphics perhaps planet landing options, better fleet controls and even multi-plsyer. You have got it badly wrong with X Rebirth and the reviews on steam show it.

												Update 27/11/2016Ignore positive reviews for this game, its still badly broken, terrible framerates even on a 4th gen I5 4790k /w GTX1060 16gb DDR4Update 29/02/2016One thing, currently mods are somewhat unreliable, waiting for fix to this, since during 3.5 i was using around 200 mods to actually enjoy this game, not to mention self made mods.After "Patch 4.0 Home of Light"So i decided to bite the bullet and buy the DLC for this game, wish i hadn't bothered, after doing a fresh install and removing all my mods and deleting my saves etc, game is still riddled with bugs, instead of writing a long wall of text ill jsut simply put a list of what doesnt work or doesnt work properlyBounty Board - CRASHES! (sometimes 40%)New weapon modifications (some work some dont take effect properly, added 60% range (projectile lifetime)to my plasma cannon and doesnt travel further, there are others...Constant on-screen tooltips 5 hours into game, [ press 1-5 to use your scanner] jeez that one ♥♥♥♥ing bothers me, dont forget to save your game, these among another 20-25 different tips are right in the middle of your screen while your playing, i actually died several times due to missing with the railgun (shooting down missiles) because of these stupid "pop ups" LAZY EGOSOFT!Still no verbose / reduced audio for menus where ren interects, "show your x" instead i've shown egosoft my alt+f4 uninstall deal.Campaign still still broken beyond belief, i wanted to try play through on the new "very hard" difficulty but im still forced to import files and modify my save due to "error walls"Why are the mission rewards so crap? i drove away 7 xenon k's and around 60 fighters and i got given 160k in cash.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Update: 19/02/2015After "Major patch" 3.5 This game still runs like utter ♥♥♥♥, DO NOT BUYThis review is based from my personal experiences from play on my own system 2 other friends system that have similar systems with similar hardware, around 300 hours in total (I bought my system to actually try and get this game to work, this involved a lot of system optimisation)First off ignore the system requirements for this game, they are utter rubbish, I run this on a Win7 64bit I5 4670k @ 4ghz /w 16gb of corsair ddr3 ram /w SLI'd 780's and it runs like utter garbage, 52fps in 1 zone in Devries and the rest of the game is around 20 on average, in the end game zone its less than 10 fps. Game settings are fairly useless, they dont seem to affect performance in any way what-so-ever its almost like that lowering the texture quality for example simply masks the high res texture but doesn't actually change it.Combat:Heres how this game plays its combat:Start game, make a couple of million credits which is around 2 hours work, then go buy the Inertial Hammer MK2 (space shotgun) and then get the Plasma Cannon MK2 (for wasting capital ships) you dont need any of the other guns, the Pulsed Mazser does so little damaged when upgraded that its a complete waste of money. Particle Repeater has such short range and overheats faster than a nuclear explosion.  Missiles are a mystery, Sunstalkers seem either too slow or the script for the missiles AI makes it fly away from the target (and i know what target navigation prediction is)Buy Dashing Shield MK3 since the MK's 4-5 are locked by default and cannot be accessed without hacking the game files, the other shields are pointless the Behemoth shields do not regen fast enough and the steady shield is kinda meh, doesnt feel unique.  Buy Sidewinder Engine MK3 so you can actually dodge missiles are other projectiles.  Supcharger Engine MK3 has very little turn rate and the Equalized Engine is again meh. Trade:Trade in this game does not work, even after over 30 patches they still cant get it to work, and with a broken trade system this means that player station construction starts to suffer and dont even try to build an empire where even your own trade ships assigned to stations wont collect wares to buy or sell from either the world or your own stations.All trade in this game has to be done MANUALLY i.e to trade you must do the following for each tradepress enter to open menu (which is radial btw, xbox port?press 2 for tradingselect at top of screen the ship you want to trade, which btw has to be compatible with trade, energy cells are energy type and missiles are container type WTF EGO!look through a list of wares that have maybe 2 lines of text about the item, this does not contain information of how to make the ware or what type of station sub module that the ware is used/consumed inwhen selecting how many items you want this is where i make a mistake after having 1000's of hours in other X games you move the slider to the left for items you want and right for items to sell, a mainstay of the X series was thier purchase bar, this is a minor gripe but there is also no boxx to type in a step number to buy more items in a simple couple of key pressesYOU HAVE TO DO THAT FOR EVERY TRADE! plus not to mention that every trade is followed for a 5 second audio confirmation from the trade ship that during the confirmation that you have UI control so you have to wait!  So try building a massive trade empire with 20+ stations and manage that, &^$£ that!Trade software doesnt work as intended you can store trade offers without this so why waste time finding it or buying it.Sound DesignI have to admit that the sound design in this isn't too bad, however the fact that 90% of the NPC's that you hire in this game are sarcastic somehow starts to wear my nerves thin as im shouting back at my monitor because some NPC tells me for the 5000th time that the cargo bay in my ship needs a good vacuum and spring clean.  That said the soundtrack itself is fairly well put together, this is proberly the only saving grace of this....im hesitant to use the word "game"Now we come to the major gripe.Gameplay feel and community and maybe modsOh dear EGOSOFT what have you done to us, we spent so many years enjoying this series.  During the launch of this game EGO got hammered by the loyal followers of the X series for a lot of problems during the first 15 or so patches, we found Xbox port evidence in the game data files and the design of the stupid radial menu.  Now I know that a lot of people will just simply slam this review and just downrate it, well we all know that EGO employees where banning people from steam for posting bad reviews, I myself was banned for complaining how bad this game was and I still do say that the game is bad.  This alienates the "die hard" fans of the X universe.Its now christmas 2014 and the game finally drops to 50% off for the collecters edition, in the UK this is £24.99 (you get the DLC with this purchase) but its still not worth it for a game that does not work "as intended"Mods: well if you want to mod this game i would be prepared for mods to not even work properly, this is not down to the bad design of the mods themselves but more down to the fact that this "new" game is still coded in XML from a game engine from 7 years ago, when are companies going to get this into thier thick skulls to stop using tech that is stagnant and dated.

content:
14, 2015
												After playing the game for a while I can tell you it needs serious work.The trading is unenjoyable, the game doesn't help explain anything more complex than keybinds. Some might try to defend it saying it is a steep learning curve but that implies that the game attempts to help you learn. Tooltips on everything would be extremely helpful. If I would suggest anything it is a tooltip system like Crusader Kings 2 where it gives you the conditions to be met or a good description of what is being done.The player faction AI is absolutely terrible. My ships don't even defend themselves, they don't attack targets which I tell them to, I have low ability captains but the option to "Train" them is never explained or available.The UI is okay in some aspects and horrible in others. It would be nice to have filters for stations selling and buying certain products on the map. The map has the most problems as it is really unhelpful when you are trying to find certain buildings in space. That being said I've had a lot of problems buying things only to realize I bought it for the wrong ship, which coincidentally cannot actually sell anything because it has a lack of cargolifters. Maybe a prompt straight up asking which ship you want to use that isn't ignorable would be much more helpful.Player ship combat is decent. There are a lot of different munitions to choose from for missiles but my main energy powered weapons seem very limited.The minigames are simply stupid. Many times I've landed in areas that aren't "purple" and "scored" but sometimes I get it in the purple and the game still fails me. If this is the route you want your game to go then at least make it more defined. Honestly I hated the minigames the most.Controlling other ships is mostly a hassle. Creating a station seems very important but it is woefully underexplained in the campaign "tutorial". Although the one thing I do like is docking in capital ships. That is awesome and I love how I can see the outside while it is flying me across the galaxy.The voice acting for NPC's is god awful. Different lines are few and far between. It seems like whenever I talk to female traders they keep asking me if I want to see their boobs and my captain has expressed their joy in meeting me for the first time... for the tenth time.Graphically this game is pretty decent. Not AAA material but good. Although the NPC models are extremely bland. It's like everyone is bald except for my energetic rebellious do-gooder copilot. I have no way of really gauging how good my ship is compared to others except by looking at their armaments. What good is telling me how much flat damage my missiles do if everything is only measured in percentages?Hireling skills really confuse me. What exactly is the difference between a 1 star and a 5 star? In a game governed by trading and numbers it seems this was an afterthought. Honestly a lot of the percentages and numbers in this game feel very meaningless. Like my cargo allows me to have so much m3 but I can only carry so much of one item. It should probably give more information about this in ship details.The plot of the game is decent, but it really railroaded me along and it felt like that was the only thing that gave the game any meaning. Also, I changed back my ships name from Albion Skunk to Albion Pride but they keep calling me the Albion Skunk, probably should lock the ability to change the Skunk's name.All in all the game feels very empty. I liked the premise but I don't like the feel of this game.

content:

												Here is my first review on steam - of X Rebirth.I review X Rebirth apart from the other games in the X-series and this review reflects my experience with the game as of its state in 2016 with the 4.0 patch and Home of light expansion. I have hesitated, like many of you, as the game saw quite horrendous reviews at launch. Even though I was deterred, I came back years later to find a game that had been patched up, expanded and closer to expectation. Props to the developers for sticking to it.After nearly 200 hours in this game I have explored, built a humble trade fleet, a few stations and seen a bit of combat through missions and mishaps. I have earned millions of credits - and I have lost millions too. Here is what I have found so far:The good:- Stations: Great variety in faction stations and modules - and stations the player can build and expand.- Galaxy: Good variety in atmosphere across systems, many sectors and zones to explore, hundreds.- Many ways to make a living - trade, missions, combat, boarding, piracy, scavenge, mine.- The game feels alive with ships around stations and from different factions - living economy and trade.- Truly build an empire and feel the work you have put into it from your armchair - mourn each ship lost at the hand of your    enemies.- Organize your fleet as you wish. Assign transporters to station managers, assign carriers to tradeships. assign             100 small fighters to yourself and this part is fairly managable with the broadcast feature.- Many types of NPCs, wares, ships, stations, drones, missiles, materials for mining etc. - Play as you wish. Relax and manage your trade fleet in a zen-pace until the alarm sounds - or attack everything and live   dangerously in the outskirts.- Enhance the game with modsThings to improve:- Stations feel similar and repetitive on the inside and small in comparison to their outside dimensions (several km). It would be    nice to see a lot of life and interior.- NPCs stand in the same place in stations and seem a bit dull to interact with as much of the dialogue repeats itself (Good: You   can do a lot of the interaction from your ship without docking)- Weapons are good and have modifications, but It would be nice to see a bit more variety in the hardpoints and effects. - Trading takes a few clicks if you have 20+ ships and upgraded trade software.- I have experienced some clipping with capital ships where you end up inside them and capital ships flying through station   modules. Drones and smaller fighters often fly into capital ships during fights.This is a great game with many aspects and it will take a few hours to get to know all of them. Don't buy this game to play it for 2 hours - buy it to play it 50, 100 or 1000 hours for full benefit.Lastly I suggest watching tutorials by the developers and others to learn more about all aspects of the game.

er 5, 2014
												Update: The Teladi DLC finally makes it playable and i have since stacked a further 40 hours into the game. I am still however going to keep at as not recommended ONLY because it still isn't fixed however i would recommend giving it a go and seeing how far you yourself get on with it.Short version: At the moment this game is about as entertaining as watching a Canadian stockbroker paint his daughters bedroom. Long version: This game holds both elements of genius and failure. It had so much potential. Lets start with the positives. X Rebirths most alluring factor is it's universe; it's Bladerunner environment is a real sight to behold and i loved every minute of flying around this busy and alive space. Watching the capital ships dock and unload their cargo via drones was amazing and watching each and every ship go about it's task was cool. I loved zipping about and popping out of the highways and the sheer scale of the galaxy is immense. Watching your capital ships being built at the shipyards is a joy. There is no question that this game is beautiful but this is where the good things end. Now lets come to the bad points. The trade system even after 25 patches (or however many) is simply broken. There isn't a single element to the trading system that i can name any positives to without stretching to lying about it. Why they thought anyone would want to fly around in circles reactivating trade offers every few hours (instead of using the simple but effective Advanced Satellite option from X3) is beyond me and even though they introduced trade agents later on why on Earth would i want to run around each and every station talking to every single person looking for one?  The other awful feature is your miners. You cannot activate their mining remotely at least i haven't found a way of doing so. You can tell them to fly to a zone where there is ore - you can tell them to sell the ore once they are fully loaded but you cannot tell them to ore remotely without the player being in the same sector. What? Why? Was this basic feature left out purposely or simply forgotten? If i have 40 miners going about their tasks, i would have to go to every single one of them each time to have them start mining (and then go around in circles after reactivating trade offers for them to sell to). Terrible.   From what i could see the stations were an utter waste of time docking to unless you wanted to find crew members for your ships or watch poorly animated character models stand about insulting you. There are only a few weapon types, shield types, missile types and only ONE...yes ONE installable software device for the Skunk. Where did all of the software from X3 go? (I'm holding my hands up in frustration). Where did everything go?The campaign story was dull and not exactly entertaining. The voice acting was bordering on college hired actors sitting around eating coco pops while reading from a script and i ended up eventually going on to play free play just to avoid it. Look, this game has a lot of gripes, some small which are worthless discussing some very gaping as mentioned above. The point is X Rebirth is a game that is missing being given a blank cheque. It's beautiful, truly - i cannot stress that enough. But some of the design choices are unbelievable. If X Rebirth had all of the features, options, wares, fleet commands and brilliance of X3 Terren Conflict and the beauty and busyness of X Rebirth this game would be unforgettable; at the moment it's just completely missable.Until we all risk playing the Teladi DLC X3 Albion Prelude is your best bet.

												After a few hundred hours of playing this game I cannot recommend it.  This game is supposed to be a massive sandbox where you can build and control fleets and stations and create your own empire...  Sadly it is really mostly a large exercise in micro management; you have to set everything up individually and manually.  It is almost as if Egosoft went out of their way to bore you to death.  Ships don’t come with weapons by default you must add them to every single ship using the build menu, you can only build one ship at a time and cannot order multiples, stations have to be built section by section and architects are too dumb to know that you want them to build the next module when they are finished with the first.   I could go on...  Effectively for every half hour you spend in an epic space battle you spend 100 hours preparing fleets and stations in the most mind numbing ways possible.  It is really sad because overall the game has very good graphic designs and a decent engine but clearly Egosoft has forgotten that games are supposed to be fun before anything else.

content:
9, 2014
												As most everyone knows, X: Rebirth was a horrendous mess at launch. It was fettered with problems: a horrible optimization that led to unplayable framerates, gameplay elements that at best were buggy, and at worst were completely broken. It was a game that screamed it was totally rushed to market. Egosoft was pelted with so much bad publicity that the Metacritic score was a complete embarrassment at 27 at its lowest point. That being said, Egosoft took some time, listened to the community, and did a complete overall with the 2.0 update. The big question you should be asking yourself is: is X Rebirth still the unplayable mess, or is it worth purchasing now that the 2.0 update has been released.I scoured the Steam and Egosoft forums for a true, balenced answer to whether or not X Rebirth was worth purchasing since the 2.0 updates. Unfortunately, I was unable to find a true endorsement for buying the game. The weird part was, I wasn't able to find a true condemnation of the 2.0 updates either. Everyone seemed to be mired in hurt feelings over the initial release, and angry over gameplay elements they deemed as stupid. In truth, the more I read, the more I realized that these people were angry over the fact that the game wasn't Terran Conflict. Frustrated with my inability to find a straight answer about whether or not the implemented fixes made the game worth playing, I remembered back to when I bought X3 at launch. That game, too, was a complete train wreck of a launch, but over time was patched, modded, and ended up being one of my favorite games in my collection - a staple that I kept coming back to. So, I took an attitude of let the buyer beware, and dived in to purchase X3 Rebirth to form my own opinion on whether or not it was worth buying. I've been a huge fan of the X series since I first played X2. Bear that in mind, because I'm going to qualify a lot of what I'm saying through that lens as I write this review. The long and somewhat rambling preamble is intended to make you understand that I'm writing this through the eyes of someone who holds the X series near and dear to their heart. I'm not an Egosoft fanboy, nor am I an X fanboy. But I do think that since everyone gave Diablo III and SimCity a fair shake, despite their disastrous launches, X Rebirth should get consideration for the changes that were made as well. So, this review will only consider the game post-2.0.----First, it's important to note that X Rebirth was clearly a game made for the XBox 360 and PS3, and the design philosophy makes it clear that the PC release was an afterthought when some elements were designed (such as the map system). This doesn't mean it didn't translate well to the PC, it's just very clear that the game was really designed to be played with a controller. I don't play with a controller, and play with a mouse and G13, and it works very well. However, fans of joystick/throttle combinations will be very disappointed, as the game really wasn't designed with flight stick enthusiasts in mind. The main fix that was impleneted in 2.0 was the optimization of the graphics through making it 64-bit native, making more use of RAM and multi core threading. I don't have a superpowerful rig, and I run a single NVidia GTX 560 Ti and an I7 Quad Core @ 3.4GHz and 8 GB of RAM. The game runs silky smooth for me, even in sectors with tons of traffic, and I'm running the game on higher graphics settings. It's safe to say that if you're running a halfway decent computer, you'll at least be able to run the game on medium settngs.The game looks absolutely fantastic - with rich, dense sectors that are reminiscent of Blade Runner or Fifth Elemnt. The character models do look somewhat strange, and seem to be kind of a secondary element, but they're not so awful it ruins the experience. The voice acting is extremely mediocre, but again, it hasn't distracted me from enjoying the game. The station designs are pretty much the same four or five models, with extremely little variation, and the novelty of getting out of your ship to meet someone in a station wears off extremely quickly. The stations don't feel alive or vibrant, and there was definitely a missed opportunity to create some variation. The game really shines, however, when you're in your ship, flying around space (which is what you'll spend 90% of your time doing).The game drops you after the events of X3: Terran Confict, and you're dropped into the Albion Skunk, the last and only prototype of an Albion battleship. You pick up a mysterious technician, and events conspire to ruin your status as a neutral party in the galaxy, forcing you to take sides in a conflict against the Plutarch Mining Coproration. The crux of this story, however, is what brings the unique (and sometimes reviled) aspect of X Rebirth that begins to seperate it from other X games - you are only able to pilot one ship through the entire game. You buy or gain other ships throughout the game, but they're micromanaged to take on tasks you set (such as escorting you or trading at stations). This micromanagement can become tedious, but honestly, no more so than X3: Terran Conlfict. There doesn't seem to be any autonomous trading options as there were in X3, so you will have to constantly micro your fleet to take care of tasks to earn you income or fight your enemies. I don't feel like this is game-breaking, since I manually ran trading in X3. There is also a new highway system in the game that allows you to fast travel between sectors without using a time compression mechanic.Unlike previous X games, the game is very forgiving to the newcomer, introducing you to gameplay elements in the campaign to acclamate you to how the universe functions -  from controlling your ship, combat, controlling other ships, hiring crews for those ships, boarding and capturing other ships, etc. It presents gameplay (in my opinion) in a much more accessible way.A main issue you're going to have if you've never played an X game before is relying on community support. The X games have always had an incredible and active modding community, and Egosoft has always done a good job of supporting their games long after launch. The general community (what's found on the forums), however, is an absolute terrible disgrace. They are generally extremely rude to those not intimately aware of the X Universe, and simple questions on how to do things are met with general trolling. As a fan of the X games, I am a bit ashamed that I love a game with such a horrible community that's founded on exclusivity and keeping the "average" gamer out of their space (because, trust me, you're just not hardcore enough to play an X game). There are, however, a ton of X resources on the internet, and once you get past the outright indignance of the community over the launch of X Rebirth, you'll be able to find some decent resources to help you figure out how to do things.So, should you buy this game? That depends. If you're looking for an experience comparable to what you had in X3: Terran Conflict or Albion Prelude, you should probably look elsewhere. This is a totally different game. It's not different in a bad way, though. It's a fresh take on the universe with some issues. This game is far from perfect. There's still some bugs under the hood that need to be hammered out, the sameness of stations gets tiresome, the outright rage of the community over the game is kind of depressing, waiting for your ships to get to their destination to complete a task can be kind of annoying if there's no missions around to complete while that task is being completed can get tedious, the map system can be really unintuitive until you get the hang of it, and the voice acting could be much better. All of these things pale when you see what this game can be, though. I'm having a lot of fun with it, and I'm glad I ignored a lot of the venom that was spit over the game's broken release. Recommended.

er 19, 2015
												So in short, this is one of the best single player space sims out there. Highly reccommended if you love the genre. What I think most people that wrote a negative review did is that they reviewed the early game (which was in fact buggy, slow as hell and generally undeveloped) and most important - they compared it to their predecessor X3: Terran Conflict (X3TC). More explanation below if you care to read.X3TC is simply the best single player space sim out there, period. Rebirth is a different game that borrows some things from its predecessor but is essentially completely new. Most people (including myself) expected just a better X3TC which, thinking back, would in fact be almost impossible to achive (in my opinion).So what made me play X:Rebirth so much? Because is without doubt one of the best space sims out there. Most of similar games have a much shorter life span, meaning that you reach a point when there's simply nothing to do. X:R is a sandbox. You decide your own rules, you shape the universe (literally), you can play it almost infinitely. Want to ruin the economy in AI controlled sectors? You do it. Wanna be a hoarder and own every acquirable ship and every buildable station in the game? You do it. Wanna play the pirate that plunders one or more factions? You do it. Wanna have a fleet of 500 capital ships and lay waste to the entire universe? Well you can do it but it's not permanent since the AI will eventually rebuild space stations. After almost 400 hours of gameplay I still find many things to do, many things that would get me occupied for at least 100 more hours. And then I'd set myself a new goal and play 100 hours more.Like I said, the game is a sandbox. Play the story mode once, and then start a new game and set yourself some personal goals and rules to stick to - i.e. play a merchant that cannot own any combat ship and can only defend itself if attacked. or play a pirate that plunders all but one or two factions. Compared to some other space sims I've played (and I've played many) X:R is not the best but it's in the top 5 for sure.Pros:- you can acquire almost everything you see in the universe- it's a sandbox so basically infinite lifespan- combat is dynamic and fun- combat can be HARD if not approached without a plan - you can't just go in alone and fight a destroyer with escorts. They will rip you apart in seconds regardless of your ship mods.- build, fight, trade and THINK - sometimes you face an ingame problem that might seem as a bug, but it can be resolved ingame (i.e. resource shortage and the economy won't produce the affected resource - once you're familiar with the game mechanics, you can solve this by yourself))- the interface has been GREATLY improved since the game came out and is now really user-friendlyCons:- only one flyable ship - but in the long run it doesn't matter that much because you always end up flying one most of the time- can't really customize the fleet (i.e. different weapons for your ships)

er 14, 2013
												Buyer beware! (minor, vague spoilers follow, just thought I'd mention that to those who are.. picky.) Many people expecting the gameplay of previous games in the series WILL be severely disappointed. X:Rebirth has apparently attempted a new, and poorly informed direction, and no one knows why. As a first time X series player, with no previous expectations, I am superbly put off by this game, and shocked that they are allowed to charge the price that they do for this amount of low quality. Let's outline some of the areas where you'll probably be annoyed. First thing's first, as you take control of your ship, you immediately notice the horrible voice acting and rotten, choppy framerate. I have an obscenely well built custom computer which i take a bit of pride in, and running the game on maximum graphics causes it to have a choppy, unplayable framerate. Every so often, you notice the graphics engine seems to 'derail' and send you into the abyss of poorly rendered polygon shadows. Voice clips are often choppy, low quality, and poorly cut. I know quite a bit about remixing music and post processing, and the effort is not to spec at all. By your fifth, 'Now shut up, betty!' you'll understand what I mean. Repeated, annoying animations, and floating text that will not go away plague you, as you try to understand the complicated nature of the menus which are not logically arranged at all. You feel right away that this game was meant for a console. Soldiering on, you go to your first station. You are assigned a kill mission, and just as you engage your opponent, the game locks up. Your first crash sets you back about an hour. Mostly due to the painfully slow flight speed of your bucket of bolts called a ship. You get back to your bounty mission, and your bounty target is now attacking you. You put it down with ease, yet score a plethora of friendly fire hits on the friendly station, which now starts attacking you. Oh yes, some real thought was put into this game. Reload your save, you restart the bounty mission, which has changed, and start thinking about how you're going to kill a giant freighter with your small peashooter laser.. so you think you need some new guns first. I did. There are no ship customizations, or upgrades beyond that of 5-6 core weapons (which span from mark 1 to mark 3), 4-5 projectile (missile type) weapons and 3 types of forcefields to choose from. Engines and scanners are upgradeable however this is where you notice the cost.. And start to try to create your own trade empire. Or would, rather, if you could get past the first tutorial mission where you are guided through a 'trade'. Your first freighter seems to get stuck on 'Follow' mode, and will never release. There is no 'cancel order' or 'cancel last trip' command. So once this happens, you had better have a save or else your game is kaput, as you now have no hope of acquiring currency en masse. Even if you do buy another freighter and get something going, it eventually locks into the 'follow albion skunk' command. At this point, I became frustrated and tossed in the towel. I'm a guy known for liking complex, absurdly large learning curve games, but this isn't a game. It's a piece of junk that the developer is scrambling to repair before people turn away from their company, for good. And because I'm slightly insane, I loaded the game again, jumped into a superhighway, and got randomly dumped into space 1.4M KM away from anywhere, with no jump drive. That's about when I hit my threshold. This apparently 'rare' bug, is just one of many waiting to frustrate you. People, I implore you. Understand that even a RUDIMENTARY quality control program would have prevented any of these issues from occurring, but this developer seems to be lacking in common sense. I feel like I've been the victim of a scam, as I paid decent money for what I was to understand was a working product, yet received a game that should still be in alpha, or earlier. If they had stated 'Well we're doing an alpha early-access' that would have been fine with me. But I would not have paid 40 bucks for it, let me tell you. Don't make my mistake. Turn your back on this one, and walk away. Though, there is one thing they got right, naming the first ship you get 'Albion Skunk' cause this game just stinks. (they're not getting a point for that though.) And I'm afraid no amount of patching is going to erase that stink, since the flaws are on a fundamental, conceptual level.

I have a copy, but I will pray for anyone with good hearth to merge the X Rebith space graphics with X AP/TC gameplay with some improved performance. 												Withe the release of 3.5 and the free weekend I must say I am impressed.X Rebirth is an extensive and immersive space sim that provides a complete space experience. I played a whole load of X3 years ago and with this offer on steam I decided to try the next generation and I haven't been dissapointed. Be warned tho, you'll find yourself "a few minutes" into the game and look up to find your whole afternoon gone.This game has a depth and scope like no other and is definitely worthy of your time, you will just need alot of it to get to where you'd like to be in the game and able to explore the vastness of the game's options.Pros:-Vast scope that provokes no end of questions and inspires interest.-Beautiful space-scape.-Immersive environment with countless options for progression.Cons:-Very poor campaign that bugs out on nearly every objective leaving you unable to continue. If you choose to play it get a guide and follow it to the letter any deviation and its game over.-The game from a personal perspective isn't as inspiring as from your ship, stations feel a little lifeless and labarythine.-Learning curve is steep and the tutorial whilst a good effort lacks a little, such as being told to shoot asteroids is all very well if you already know the control to press to do it... Overall it seems an excellent game that you could grow to love, but dont expect any casual gameplay here. Simply learning to play is a case of weeks or months not minutes and hours, if thats what you are looking for you will not be dissapointed here. A very well done job.

content:
9, 2014
												As most everyone knows, X: Rebirth was a horrendous mess at launch. It was fettered with problems: a horrible optimization that led to unplayable framerates, gameplay elements that at best were buggy, and at worst were completely broken. It was a game that screamed it was totally rushed to market. Egosoft was pelted with so much bad publicity that the Metacritic score was a complete embarrassment at 27 at its lowest point. That being said, Egosoft took some time, listened to the community, and did a complete overall with the 2.0 update. The big question you should be asking yourself is: is X Rebirth still the unplayable mess, or is it worth purchasing now that the 2.0 update has been released.I scoured the Steam and Egosoft forums for a true, balenced answer to whether or not X Rebirth was worth purchasing since the 2.0 updates. Unfortunately, I was unable to find a true endorsement for buying the game. The weird part was, I wasn't able to find a true condemnation of the 2.0 updates either. Everyone seemed to be mired in hurt feelings over the initial release, and angry over gameplay elements they deemed as stupid. In truth, the more I read, the more I realized that these people were angry over the fact that the game wasn't Terran Conflict. Frustrated with my inability to find a straight answer about whether or not the implemented fixes made the game worth playing, I remembered back to when I bought X3 at launch. That game, too, was a complete train wreck of a launch, but over time was patched, modded, and ended up being one of my favorite games in my collection - a staple that I kept coming back to. So, I took an attitude of let the buyer beware, and dived in to purchase X3 Rebirth to form my own opinion on whether or not it was worth buying. I've been a huge fan of the X series since I first played X2. Bear that in mind, because I'm going to qualify a lot of what I'm saying through that lens as I write this review. The long and somewhat rambling preamble is intended to make you understand that I'm writing this through the eyes of someone who holds the X series near and dear to their heart. I'm not an Egosoft fanboy, nor am I an X fanboy. But I do think that since everyone gave Diablo III and SimCity a fair shake, despite their disastrous launches, X Rebirth should get consideration for the changes that were made as well. So, this review will only consider the game post-2.0.----First, it's important to note that X Rebirth was clearly a game made for the XBox 360 and PS3, and the design philosophy makes it clear that the PC release was an afterthought when some elements were designed (such as the map system). This doesn't mean it didn't translate well to the PC, it's just very clear that the game was really designed to be played with a controller. I don't play with a controller, and play with a mouse and G13, and it works very well. However, fans of joystick/throttle combinations will be very disappointed, as the game really wasn't designed with flight stick enthusiasts in mind. The main fix that was impleneted in 2.0 was the optimization of the graphics through making it 64-bit native, making more use of RAM and multi core threading. I don't have a superpowerful rig, and I run a single NVidia GTX 560 Ti and an I7 Quad Core @ 3.4GHz and 8 GB of RAM. The game runs silky smooth for me, even in sectors with tons of traffic, and I'm running the game on higher graphics settings. It's safe to say that if you're running a halfway decent computer, you'll at least be able to run the game on medium settngs.The game looks absolutely fantastic - with rich, dense sectors that are reminiscent of Blade Runner or Fifth Elemnt. The character models do look somewhat strange, and seem to be kind of a secondary element, but they're not so awful it ruins the experience. The voice acting is extremely mediocre, but again, it hasn't distracted me from enjoying the game. The station designs are pretty much the same four or five models, with extremely little variation, and the novelty of getting out of your ship to meet someone in a station wears off extremely quickly. The stations don't feel alive or vibrant, and there was definitely a missed opportunity to create some variation. The game really shines, however, when you're in your ship, flying around space (which is what you'll spend 90% of your time doing).The game drops you after the events of X3: Terran Confict, and you're dropped into the Albion Skunk, the last and only prototype of an Albion battleship. You pick up a mysterious technician, and events conspire to ruin your status as a neutral party in the galaxy, forcing you to take sides in a conflict against the Plutarch Mining Coproration. The crux of this story, however, is what brings the unique (and sometimes reviled) aspect of X Rebirth that begins to seperate it from other X games - you are only able to pilot one ship through the entire game. You buy or gain other ships throughout the game, but they're micromanaged to take on tasks you set (such as escorting you or trading at stations). This micromanagement can become tedious, but honestly, no more so than X3: Terran Conlfict. There doesn't seem to be any autonomous trading options as there were in X3, so you will have to constantly micro your fleet to take care of tasks to earn you income or fight your enemies. I don't feel like this is game-breaking, since I manually ran trading in X3. There is also a new highway system in the game that allows you to fast travel between sectors without using a time compression mechanic.Unlike previous X games, the game is very forgiving to the newcomer, introducing you to gameplay elements in the campaign to acclamate you to how the universe functions -  from controlling your ship, combat, controlling other ships, hiring crews for those ships, boarding and capturing other ships, etc. It presents gameplay (in my opinion) in a much more accessible way.A main issue you're going to have if you've never played an X game before is relying on community support. The X games have always had an incredible and active modding community, and Egosoft has always done a good job of supporting their games long after launch. The general community (what's found on the forums), however, is an absolute terrible disgrace. They are generally extremely rude to those not intimately aware of the X Universe, and simple questions on how to do things are met with general trolling. As a fan of the X games, I am a bit ashamed that I love a game with such a horrible community that's founded on exclusivity and keeping the "average" gamer out of their space (because, trust me, you're just not hardcore enough to play an X game). There are, however, a ton of X resources on the internet, and once you get past the outright indignance of the community over the launch of X Rebirth, you'll be able to find some decent resources to help you figure out how to do things.So, should you buy this game? That depends. If you're looking for an experience comparable to what you had in X3: Terran Conflict or Albion Prelude, you should probably look elsewhere. This is a totally different game. It's not different in a bad way, though. It's a fresh take on the universe with some issues. This game is far from perfect. There's still some bugs under the hood that need to be hammered out, the sameness of stations gets tiresome, the outright rage of the community over the game is kind of depressing, waiting for your ships to get to their destination to complete a task can be kind of annoying if there's no missions around to complete while that task is being completed can get tedious, the map system can be really unintuitive until you get the hang of it, and the voice acting could be much better. All of these things pale when you see what this game can be, though. I'm having a lot of fun with it, and I'm glad I ignored a lot of the venom that was spit over the game's broken release. Recommended.

												A game that has improved with time.I bought this game on pre-order and was disappointed along with just about everyone else at its horrible quality.   At the time of this writing, the game is up to version 3.61 and includes the secret service missions and teladi outpost expansion.   I'm generally happy with the game now.  Many dislike the core design decisions of this X game.  The limits imposed by the game design are balanced by some things that the developers tried that were at the time very new in this genre, such as combining first person and space combat into a single experience (this is now being tried more extensively and seamlessly in upcoming titles such as Star Citizen).  I think this different approach gives this game an interesting environment to explore and provides a great launchpad for mod developers.   Another plus is that the developers have been actively working on this game ever since launch.  Their work has really improved the game, although they should have waited a little while until the game was in a releasable state.  Had the game been released in the state it is in now (3.61) the reviews on Steam would likely be similar to the reviews of their expansion "Teladi Outpost" which are more positive.7/10

Their work has really improved the game, although they should have waited a little while until the game was in a releasable state.  Had the game been released in the state it is in now (3.61) the reviews on Steam would likely be similar to the reviews of their expansion "Teladi Outpost" which are more positive.7/10
