er 19, 2015
												So in short, this is one of the best single player space sims out there. Highly reccommended if you love the genre. What I think most people that wrote a negative review did is that they reviewed the early game (which was in fact buggy, slow as hell and generally undeveloped) and most important - they compared it to their predecessor X3: Terran Conflict (X3TC). More explanation below if you care to read.X3TC is simply the best single player space sim out there, period. Rebirth is a different game that borrows some things from its predecessor but is essentially completely new. Most people (including myself) expected just a better X3TC which, thinking back, would in fact be almost impossible to achive (in my opinion).So what made me play X:Rebirth so much? Because is without doubt one of the best space sims out there. Most of similar games have a much shorter life span, meaning that you reach a point when there's simply nothing to do. X:R is a sandbox. You decide your own rules, you shape the universe (literally), you can play it almost infinitely. Want to ruin the economy in AI controlled sectors? You do it. Wanna be a hoarder and own every acquirable ship and every buildable station in the game? You do it. Wanna play the pirate that plunders one or more factions? You do it. Wanna have a fleet of 500 capital ships and lay waste to the entire universe? Well you can do it but it's not permanent since the AI will eventually rebuild space stations. After almost 400 hours of gameplay I still find many things to do, many things that would get me occupied for at least 100 more hours. And then I'd set myself a new goal and play 100 hours more.Like I said, the game is a sandbox. Play the story mode once, and then start a new game and set yourself some personal goals and rules to stick to - i.e. play a merchant that cannot own any combat ship and can only defend itself if attacked. or play a pirate that plunders all but one or two factions. Compared to some other space sims I've played (and I've played many) X:R is not the best but it's in the top 5 for sure.Pros:- you can acquire almost everything you see in the universe- it's a sandbox so basically infinite lifespan- combat is dynamic and fun- combat can be HARD if not approached without a plan - you can't just go in alone and fight a destroyer with escorts. They will rip you apart in seconds regardless of your ship mods.- build, fight, trade and THINK - sometimes you face an ingame problem that might seem as a bug, but it can be resolved ingame (i.e. resource shortage and the economy won't produce the affected resource - once you're familiar with the game mechanics, you can solve this by yourself))- the interface has been GREATLY improved since the game came out and is now really user-friendlyCons:- only one flyable ship - but in the long run it doesn't matter that much because you always end up flying one most of the time- can't really customize the fleet (i.e. different weapons for your ships)

r 9, 2015
												First off, the whole xbtf series is a great series. the xbtf games have always required a bit of a learning curve and ALOT of patience to really get into, so if your looking for an arcade space sim/shooter, this probably isnt for you. the best way i can describe this game is, like skyrim in space. i dont have to tell you how good it looks you can watch the trailers.  albeit all the xbtf games are a bit buggy, and this  one is no exception. its still a great game. ive been playing the x series since the first one and they all just get better and better. things im not so crazy about,, well, theres no way to com to a station to apologize if you accidentally let a round off at one in the middle of a dog fight, this tends to happen alot if your not extra careful, especially when your defending a station and you have to get close to stay in the fight. so something of that nature would be nice as it can instantly cost you a reputation that takes a rather long time to build up.  the space highways are neat but not practical or realistic feeling for a game that is heavy on the realism in terms of space flight and combat and its very huge and deep economic system. i think it would be cool to just set your course and fly at super high speeds to the next system or sector, like the cap ships do, or have to charter and dock with a cap ship that is dedicatied to that purpose, instead of having these highways that bend and twist and often enough send you flying thru giant asteroids and other debri that should pulverize your ship instantly.  granted im trying really hard to find bad things to say about this game and its not just becuase im a fan of the series,  you do have to make up for bugs and such by saving often and having multiple save states so you dont get really far or end up in a situation you cant get out of or a stuck in a glitch, or you just saved your game by landing on a station and as soon as you leave your being blown to bits by a xenon cap ship that just jumped in whil you were bar hopping. this is rare occurance that some may never experience but its happend to me.  the npc's you encouter inside the stations are like static objects, and where you can go inside of stations is very very limited, even on the same station,, you cant travel on foot from one place to another, only run around inside the actual area you landed, itd be awesom to see the stations fully opened up and explorable, as well as npc's that travel the station rather than just sit or stand in one place. it would be cool to maybe be able to carry a weapon and get in to gun fights inside stations, particulary with guards that see you hacking into a terminal.. so so often your hacking a terminal and theres an armed guard standing right next to you, that just seems kinda dumb,. it would be great to be able to buy home on a station, like and apartment or space condo or whatever, and buy civilian class, space cars like you see flying around in traffic around all the stations. and itd be cool to see npc actually living and playing in the stations, i also think it would be cool to be abel to fly all of the ships in the game not just the albion and it would be REALLY awesome if you could explore the innards of the cap ships to their entirtey, even be able to join the marines on foot to take one over from the inside,, that would be awesom, being able to fight it out inside the capships like your imaging it would happen when you send the marines in to try to take one, but,, all of the ideas they built this game on are excellent, just a little more detail in the mentioned gameplay aspects and i probably wouldnt play any other games any more. what id like to see added to this game is more rpg style, like skyrim,, the ability to customize your armor, have weapons you carry on you, actually interact and combat and shop with npcs, by that i mean, for your character, not just tradeable goods, to have a personall inventory you can access when your walking around that looks more like somehting out of an rpg for when you interact with other npcs and want to buy things like armor, weapons for your character,, not the ship,, maybe be able to purchase homes in stations.  because who would really live in their ship.  Egosoft has always been great about working out bugs and adressing issues, and also theyve always been super awesome with how they are invloved with the modding comunity, theyve always seemed to promote it even.   most likely if we ever see any of the things ive mentioned implemented it will be teams of modders that pull it off,, i belive the rpg style customizeable character and ability to land on planets and explore the home worlds of all the alien races and human,, was brought up back in the days of x2, to wich if i rememberr correctly, egosoft expressed that these would take a way from what they intend this game to be all about, howver i say, it would only greatly add to it,, thats for hoping..  dont spend your money if your really picky and want a game thats easy to learn and easy to conqure, there is NOTHING easy about x rebirth or any of the x games,, if you enjoy a challeng and have a good learning curve and the patience of a rock, then its deffinately worth having, i run the game on toshiba laptop with a mobil amd card, quad core and i do have 16 gigs of ram and i think that helps,, and it runs fine, im not playing with all the graphic settings maxed but the game is still beautiful and plays smoothly even in heavy combat situations.. so if i repeated my self, sorry,, all in all, i personally love this game and would definatly reccomend it to others,, and in a nutshell, adding the fps/rpg elemnts you would find in games like skyrim or the fallout games, would be awesom, fully explorable stations, some of the stations are HUGE and you could spend days roaming around in one if they were truly opened up, at least one homeworld planet with cities for each race you encounter in the game and thats about it.

content:
, 2014
												This "game" if you can call it that, is still in Beta.  This shouldn't even be publicly released yet.  It's probably closer to Alpha or internal beta.  What are the problems?  Far too many to list, but I'll break it down based on my top gripes.First, I'm stuck in the same ship.  Any X fan knows that one of the best parts of the game has always been the ability to pretty much fly anything in the game, including caps.  Not here.  No.  You're stuck with the "Albion Skunk" which was a hilarious joke to play on all of us, considering that the advert said the ship was called "The Pride of Albion", only to get in game and find out that "some joker thought it would be funny to rename the ship Albion Skunk" and of course, no option to change it back.  The ship model blockout for the interior looks like it was done in maya by a frosh graphics student in college.  Actually, there are better modders out there than what these guys made.  The textures are terrible and the character feels like you're playing ROTT or DOOM back in the 90's.  Not to mention the space station interiors, which leads me to the next point.You have to land, get out, and go run through the station to go find someone to buy something from or sell to.  So, these guys have developed faster than light travel, but apparently can't communicate more than 2 feet away.  Ridiculous.  I know they said it was because they wanted us to go explore the station... all 3 variants of the same junk, while we load up our pockets with stolen stuff from lockers and boxes just sitting there while a guard, who apparently isn't guarding anything, looks on.  The character models look like something from the 90's too.  I've seen F2P MMOs with better character models than this junk.  Not to mention the interactions with the characters..."Go boil yer head".  Really?  Who says that?  Is that some kind of norseman joke or something because I don't find it funny or quaint and I get sick and tired of hearing that... along with "nice chat... NOT" every time I exit chat with an NPC, as if the scripts were written by a 12 year old who thought Wayne's World was a good movie.  Not to mention the "token" co-pilot, who has this awkward accent like English is a second language and it's the first time she's voice acted anything other than badly singing in the shower.  Seriously.. was it really necessary to have her "cutout" in the front near her cleavage?  On a suit that is supposed to survive in vacuum?  I guess this is coming from that same 12 year old who still hasn't scored with a chick and thinks objectifying women is socially acceptable with gamers because, you know.. we're ALL nerdy pimply kids in our grandparents basements and the closest thing we ever get to scoring a chick is google images, right?Next is the fact that pretty much everything is broken.  I started building a station.  I checked back a bit later, and nothing was done.. I kept checking back... nothing was done.  I let the game run overnight and came back.. nothing was done.  Let it run again overnight the next night, came back, and yay there's a little tiny bit of scrapmetal put in place.  Once that one was finally done after about a week of leaving it run all night, I started another station and, well, it's just sitting there waiting for people to sell resources to it and apparently it's just too far to have to go from the next block over to bring them.Then there's the terrible ship management and UI.  It's clumsy and sometimes there are game-breaking glitches that happen with the animations which cause you to lose progress and have to restart the game.  Also, the fact that you get punished for having a high-end system, because apparently these geniuses decided that most of the graphics should be dedicated to the CPU instead of using all this incredible GPU hardware we have nowadays...  because you know, who needs graphics cards, right?Then there's this "highway" travel thing, which is nothing like the highway we saw in the previous games, with what looked like a tunnel of accelleration rings.  No, this is just one snaky path of light that is somehow magically broken into tubes of "lanes" and everyone travels faster than you no matter what, which gives you reason to slipstream behind people to draft them and go faster.  Really?  drafting?  IN SPACE?  Who was the genius who came up with THAT miracle of physics???I could go on and on but suffice it to say that this game in its entirety is nothing but failed promises and dropped balls.  This game is a slap in the face to everyone in the sci-fi gaming community.  I know that they supposedly fixed a bunch of things and added a bunch of other stuff too, but it is too little too late guys.  Fool me once....     there's a reason the metascore is 33, and honestly, I'm suprised it's even THAT high.  This is one of the worst heaps of scrap code that ever was labeled a game.

content:
, 2014
												This "game" if you can call it that, is still in Beta.  This shouldn't even be publicly released yet.  It's probably closer to Alpha or internal beta.  What are the problems?  Far too many to list, but I'll break it down based on my top gripes.First, I'm stuck in the same ship.  Any X fan knows that one of the best parts of the game has always been the ability to pretty much fly anything in the game, including caps.  Not here.  No.  You're stuck with the "Albion Skunk" which was a hilarious joke to play on all of us, considering that the advert said the ship was called "The Pride of Albion", only to get in game and find out that "some joker thought it would be funny to rename the ship Albion Skunk" and of course, no option to change it back.  The ship model blockout for the interior looks like it was done in maya by a frosh graphics student in college.  Actually, there are better modders out there than what these guys made.  The textures are terrible and the character feels like you're playing ROTT or DOOM back in the 90's.  Not to mention the space station interiors, which leads me to the next point.You have to land, get out, and go run through the station to go find someone to buy something from or sell to.  So, these guys have developed faster than light travel, but apparently can't communicate more than 2 feet away.  Ridiculous.  I know they said it was because they wanted us to go explore the station... all 3 variants of the same junk, while we load up our pockets with stolen stuff from lockers and boxes just sitting there while a guard, who apparently isn't guarding anything, looks on.  The character models look like something from the 90's too.  I've seen F2P MMOs with better character models than this junk.  Not to mention the interactions with the characters..."Go boil yer head".  Really?  Who says that?  Is that some kind of norseman joke or something because I don't find it funny or quaint and I get sick and tired of hearing that... along with "nice chat... NOT" every time I exit chat with an NPC, as if the scripts were written by a 12 year old who thought Wayne's World was a good movie.  Not to mention the "token" co-pilot, who has this awkward accent like English is a second language and it's the first time she's voice acted anything other than badly singing in the shower.  Seriously.. was it really necessary to have her "cutout" in the front near her cleavage?  On a suit that is supposed to survive in vacuum?  I guess this is coming from that same 12 year old who still hasn't scored with a chick and thinks objectifying women is socially acceptable with gamers because, you know.. we're ALL nerdy pimply kids in our grandparents basements and the closest thing we ever get to scoring a chick is google images, right?Next is the fact that pretty much everything is broken.  I started building a station.  I checked back a bit later, and nothing was done.. I kept checking back... nothing was done.  I let the game run overnight and came back.. nothing was done.  Let it run again overnight the next night, came back, and yay there's a little tiny bit of scrapmetal put in place.  Once that one was finally done after about a week of leaving it run all night, I started another station and, well, it's just sitting there waiting for people to sell resources to it and apparently it's just too far to have to go from the next block over to bring them.Then there's the terrible ship management and UI.  It's clumsy and sometimes there are game-breaking glitches that happen with the animations which cause you to lose progress and have to restart the game.  Also, the fact that you get punished for having a high-end system, because apparently these geniuses decided that most of the graphics should be dedicated to the CPU instead of using all this incredible GPU hardware we have nowadays...  because you know, who needs graphics cards, right?Then there's this "highway" travel thing, which is nothing like the highway we saw in the previous games, with what looked like a tunnel of accelleration rings.  No, this is just one snaky path of light that is somehow magically broken into tubes of "lanes" and everyone travels faster than you no matter what, which gives you reason to slipstream behind people to draft them and go faster.  Really?  drafting?  IN SPACE?  Who was the genius who came up with THAT miracle of physics???I could go on and on but suffice it to say that this game in its entirety is nothing but failed promises and dropped balls.  This game is a slap in the face to everyone in the sci-fi gaming community.  I know that they supposedly fixed a bunch of things and added a bunch of other stuff too, but it is too little too late guys.  Fool me once....     there's a reason the metascore is 33, and honestly, I'm suprised it's even THAT high.  This is one of the worst heaps of scrap code that ever was labeled a game.

content:

												Yes and no.It's very different from most games around, and even different from most space sims around too. Complex and indepth, the game clearly has potential for those who have interest, but the learning curve and rough edges can be initially offputting (or entirely).It is and isn't my sort of game; it looks like the sort of game you invest a lot of time into over a long period of time, versus the sort of game that throws you straight into the action - a game that potentially requires that you have a lot of free time on your hands, both for playing and possibly for learning stratergies and initially the basics.My initial impressions were good and it appears that most of the reviews are due to people A. not being able to launch the game or B. due to problems and bugs I haven't yet experienced or were long fixed in previous patches.Haven't had any issues at all after my very limited playtime (I did play an hour or two which isn't recorded in offline mode due to my internet going poof), though the game does seem very slow with quite a lot of mechanics - probably a very good game, but not the sort you can sink into casually without some effort and learning. Probably the sort of game you play for a good few hours before you can really begin to enjoy it as the ropes seem a little difficult to get the game of.Some notes:- Voice acting is terrible. There is literally only a handful of lines for generic npcs and overall the quality of the voiceacting is off (characters all seem emotionless and repeat the same lines). Not sure why they did not settle with text instead of voice acting. Would have (in my opinion) improved the game if they just stuck with text chat in windows for communication (think Stalker, where only specific unique characters have voice chat, generic characters are just text).- Playing through the campain - pretty tedious as you mostly move around doing one job or another. I wonder a little if the game is built more for free play than story. That, and whilst looking for crew members, a swarm of hostiles keeps taking out my ship & capital ship...- Seems to be some performance issues. Probably related to my crappy CPU. AMD FX4100 & a GTX770 - can't run above medium without the game turning into a lag fest.- You can walk around stations. Initially cool, but very quickly lost interest in the concept after a few times -- they all basically look the same inside and have the 'same people' in the regard that each and every npc has the same tiny set of voices and conversations (please oh lord, quit with the '40 years we didn't even have highways!')- The GUI is terrible, in my honest opinion. Often lacking visiblity and ease of access, the GUI/UI overall is a right mess - it has strange ways of functioning and has made me accidently shoot stuff I intended to communicate to/interact with.= Slow paced  gameplay. May or may not be your thing - it depends on how much time you have available. For example, I started and escort mission and half an hour later I was still escorting a ship. Got bored in the end and quit, but that is because of impatience and lack of time.+ Atmosphere seems overall good. Well, bar the poor voice acting. Combat is typical space shooter, so nothing special in that regard, which I have no issue with.+ Mods. Always a plus for me when a game has a modding community.I won't recommend it to people like me, but I can see exactly why people do like it, which is why I'm giving an overall recommendation. The game is good for what it is, but I currently don't have the time and patience to sit down and learn the ropes and immerse myself - in the future I might, but for now I do not.

												First off, I have never played any of the X series games before, And I have not played but a few hours of this one.In the first couple hours of mucking about trying to fix the controls *thank you for the ability to remap the controls*, and then just fly around the starting station. Hit a fast area, I guess the space lanes. The issue I found was slow to tab in and out of the game, takes it's sweet time "loading" what should already be loaded in the background = Minor inconvenience. So far my game hasn't crashed, and I hope it stays that way.During my Fly about, my ship keeps trying to roll one way or the other, and won't stay where I stop it at. more than likely some setting that I overlooked, or don't understand.I didn't see a way to set up my character, not even the name. They best be calling me Ma'am! *Sir is militaristic, and a choice for each female officer to choose to be called sir or ma'am.*I am not into combat, so my main focus will be trying to mine, I unloaded all my missiles, and think I even blew something up accidentally.Good thing about being knew, if the bug is already known, I won't have to mention it, unless it really does something that ruins the game for me, then I can mention it.*more to come as I have a need to add*Space Graphics Are just WOW!3ed hour, finally landed on a station, And whoopsies, turns out you play a male... bleh! *when my character spoke it made me cringe, could of at least had a hot guy voice* This I didn't know about! Game would be fine for my husband, he likes fighting games, so I will let him play it instead. *need to be able to swap between ships at some point, if that isn't already in the game.*I have seen segments for being able to upgrade your own ship, but I wanted to actually fly a mining vessel. Haven't gotten very far to start with, and had higher hopes to begin with.If you want the game to lead you by the hand and tell you what to do, go somewhere else, leave this game for the pro gamers that just love to muck around in space and do their own thing.If you love open world games as much as I do, and don't mind playing as a male, then this is the game for you.So I would recommend this game to people I know who will enjoy this sort of game.Edit Add: (Feb 20th)After getting over 100,000,000 km (103,xxxK km), from my comendered mining vessel. And still not reaching half way across the solar system catty-cornered from the sun, I gave up trying to find the end of the solar system I was in. No loading screens passing betweens the systems with the jump gates either. There is no way that this is a small game by a long shot. (When in range, it loads)

content:
y 31, 2014
												This will be my first review of a game on steam, actually, first review ever. English isn’t my first language, so I will apologize in advanced about any grammar and spelling mistakes.My opinion about this game varies from day to day and from event to event. I will try to make this review as consistent as possible. I’ve been thinking of doing  this review for a long time now. I kept putting it off because I find it very difficult to get my opinion on paper.For those who think this review is too long to read, I’ve put a list of pros and cons at the bottom of this review. The current version of this game is 1.22. a lot of bugs and issues have been addressed by Egosoft at this time. I won’t be writing about earlier issues in this review. There will be issues of course that I haven’t encountered or don’t find annoying or broken. These will not be mentioned either.As you all might know by now, the game is riddled with “major” bugs and flaws. Many of them are annoying, but to say the break the game? I think not. I will try to explain why I think that is. To do this as correctly as possible I’ve divided everything in three categories, bugs, flaws and  wants. But before I do this, I want to stress the fact that Egosoft has been working hard to solve the issues the community has pointed out to them.Bugs:-	Capital ships sometimes fly through stations, this bug isn’t game breaking at all, but it does kill the emersion quite a lot. I’ve encountered this bug at a solar energy plant, where the ship kept flying  through most of the solar panels of the station. It then proceeded to crash into an array of smaller ship which catapulted in to space. Which was cool to see.-	The game sometimes slows down for no apparent reason. For me using the alt-tab keys to go back to Windows and then back to the games, solves this issue. Or else restarting the game entirely.-	Enemies getting stuck inside the station building. Sometimes, enemy drones / fighters fly into or spawn in a solid block of a station. They are then impervious to attack and they don’t go despawn. Missions can’t be completed then because not all enemies are destroyed. When you abort said mission and accept a new one in the same zone, the enemy inside the station gets activated again and you can’t finish the new mission either.Flaws:-	Enemy NPC’s and the police patrols act as they have been trained by monkeys and not very bright ones at that. AI combat and manoeuvring in space should be improved greatly. This will affect the emersion a player can have with the game. -	The game economy is based on trade ships, the trade ships however don’t leave the station. They just fly around it in circles. There are however capital ships that jump between stations and systems to trade.-	Using the jumpdrive of a capital ship should be made easier and more clearer. Look at EVE online for a good way to jump capital ships.Wants:-	Either redo the entire station walking  side of the game or make it so the player doesn’t have to get out of the ship anymore. Trade and talk to people remotely. This however means there has to be a way to make more money in space. Since when you avoid going on to stations you can’t rob said station of its goodies.-	Better galaxy, system, zone, etc. maps. Navigating through these is a pain which, when resolved improves the gameplay drastically.-	Third person view in space! I really want to see what my ship looks like when flying around and blasting stuff.-	Modular ship design of the player ship. It should be possible to remake the ship into a fighter / trader / miner or something else. Now you can only get upgrades, but you aren’t able to trade with energy cells or other materials. You need specialized remote controlled ships for that. For example I should be able to make my ship be able to mine asteroids, but the trade-off should be that my ship is slower and not as well armed. This will al so eliminate the need to crawl around mostly empty stations and robbing them.-	Bring back automated commands on the other player owned ships! Building an empire should be about delegating and getting other people to work for you. Not ordering around brainless monkeys!Stations: Stations are constructed out of modular blocks, which is logical. They have been put together into massive city like  structures which you can fly through / scan  and destroy with your ship. So far so good. On the outside the station look great and they really give off the immense scale of the game.On the inside however they are very underpopulated and at the same time feel very cramped and small. The immenseness is completely lost.AI: The general AI used by the NPC pilots is poor at best. Capital ships tend to fly through stations and bump traffic circling said station. Pirates attacking stations actually bump against it and sit on its outer hull. Fighters / drones defending a target only react when tacking direct fire.Emersion:I find the emersion to be great when flying the ship in space, but completely lost when existing the said and entering the station. Docking in capital ships and such is a great feature. But the walking around needs a lot of work. I am betting the community is making mods as we speak to greatly improve or disable this feature completely. If not, Egosoft should be doing something about this.The space environments are wonderfully made and really get you in a sci-fi mood.Pros:-	Awesome space vista’s, the stations look great, despite the fact they are modular and the asteroid field and the backgrounds simply look great!-	Flying the “Albion Skunk” (the player ship) is as smooth as a baby’s bottom. Especially when the engines have been upgraded a bit.-	Great emersion when flying around in space. Exploring the stations and the asteroid fields in all their details is quite captivating.-	Being an X game, it’s quite challenging, a lot of stuff to figure out. This can be fun, but all so frustrating at times.-	There seems enough to do in the game so people won’t get bored easily. It takes a lot of time to figure out how everything works, but that is a reward in itself, at least for me It is.Cons: -	In station walking is a failure. All the stations are exactly the same on the inside, including the rubbish people leave around. Stations are only populated by 10 – 15 people, which is strange since they are as huge as cities! Rooms and bars are empty and I as a player lose my emersion when walking in a station. Furthermore not many items can be interacted with. When a station is damaged, the internal damage seems massive and the people in it simply don’t care!-	In early game, you will spend a lot of time crawling through stations in search for loot. More simply put, you need to rob the stations blind to get enough stuff to sell back to the few people who live in those stations. Ships that you can buy to start building, shooting, trading or mining your way across the universe are too expensive to get with just simple mission running or doing other stuff in space.-	The voice acting of NPC’s is terrible, they only have a few lines they keep repeating over and over. (I only tested the English voices.)-	The textures for people -	 Bugs, the game doesn’t run as good as it could be, some people still have performance issues and the game does have some odd behaviour now and again. Conclusion:Reading back on this review I can see that it has been somewhat negative and there is indeed much room left in the game for improvement. But the feeling of flying around in that ship and skimming the surface of stations, asteroids and capital ships alike, is just too damn great. So I will recommend this game. When Egosoft (maybe with the help of the community) fix most of the bugs and the whole station walking debacle, they will have made space simulator gold.

												The best example i got under my hand to describe X rebirth is that feature i found after 15hours of playtime. There was a little arrow around my reticle telling me in which direction my target is but it was so tiny i didn't see it until then. The universe is huge and fun to visit, either it's about discovering new stations to enhance your choice of action in trading or fighting, flying in an asteroid field looking for glorious profitsss or tracking an isolated massive transport ship to board, there are tons of things to do. Each part of the gameplay is a game in the game and traditionally, egosoft like the player to set his own goals and mine has been to develop an empire, flying around with trusted wingman and some capital ships, deploying a trade company made of stations & trade fleet.Again, you're warned, X rebirth won't hold your hand and requires a wikipedia or a research in the steam forum from time to time. It's not your classic X3 experience where you start in a fighter and end with a carrier with 50 of those docked in. But honestly, Egosoft devs knows what they are doing when it's about to make you feel in space. Recommended

												this game gets a lot of bad reviews, and i dont think it entirely deserves it. REVIEW 1-- (for fans of the series, and veteran X players)if it is taken entirely within the confines of the X series (up to this point), it is certainly a rebirth for the series, and it is also a throwback to the first (remember that one, folks? we could only fly one ship there too...). now that version 3.0 has been released, much of the functionality of the previous titles in this series has been restored. taken within the boundries of the X series alone, i would rate this one 8/10 at this point in time. REVIEW 2-- (for new players lured into the series by this title)taken out of the context of its predecessors, however, it is a different story all together. this game has a cumbersome menu system that takes quite some time to get used to, as the assignments some functions are given often make little sense (for instance, changing budgets for station managers took a look up on google for me to figure out) so it loses points there, the graphics are a cross between "woah! thats awesome!" and "WTF is that? a person?" so it loses points for that as well. building an empire takes a lot of time, so its not for casual players. this is the kind of game that you need to get in to, and really it doesnt have much of a problem achieving that sort of immersion if you are playing the story (even if you arent familiar with the previous titles in the series, you can be drawn into the high stakes world of multi galaxy war easily). its easy for me to care what races win the war, and what races are exterminated in the process. but the fact remains that if you intend to play this game and enjoy it, you must also intend to spend 20-40 hours learning the game systems as well. for a lot of people, this will drop the score. for me, this increases it. the more complex the systems are, the more freedom we are generally given to play our way. and in this series, and this game in particular, playing our way is the key. the music seems deliberately strange (it always has in x games though). traveling around in space is also quite boring at times. if you want to know why, read the hitchhikers guide to the galaxy's entry on the size of space to understand why. the number of mods available on the workshop to enhance the game is gaining momentum as new fans are brought in to the series by this title, and often egosoft turns to the modding community when deciding what dlc or patches should be applied to their product so they not only listen to community input, occasionally they use it directly. but new players to the series need to remember one thing- you are playing a sim of sorts. this is not intended to be all action all the time. there are lags of hours and hours spend making the credits you need to continue, and it can be a little tedious. and frustrating when that ship you just spent the day making money to buy gets destroyed cause it had no excorts protecting it. but, this game is also easy as pie to cheat at so... taken out of its own context, i would rate it 6/10. hope you found this review helpful!

												Whatever you find attractive in this game with the exception of the empire / industry building, find something that can do it better. Won't be hard, but finding something that does it great and looks great too (equal or better) if you are into "oh I want to get into the space sim genre and this game might be good for me", DO NOT BUY THIS.It is broken from the first to the last feature. The AI is completely dead, which is unforgivible and utterly destroys the whole pure sandbox economy world. Ships are running into each other, local forces are made to be weird (anyone shooting at you is fine, if you shoot back 6 cops are shooting you to death without question). The story is unplayable since 2.0 since the main concept is that you have one ship and you cannot fly another at all. So it was the "superhero never dies" kind of ship, until it was nerfed back to "just one from others" level. Good luck doing story stuff that was designed for the original and puts you up against 6-10 other hunter ships. Attacking other people you were supposed to help, so they can just stand there and watch you die while nobody shoots at them the moment you show up.The controls are terrible. They DESPERATELY wanted to make it work with a controller. Imagine using an Excel table with controller. 5-6 circle menus and submenus in a row to find ANYTHING. Illogical, uncomfortable, weirdly working features accessible from even worse menus. And on top of all this, it is the most poorly optimalized game of the recent years more broken than AC: Unity was at relase. No joke.Whatever you want from this genre, whatever you look for in space sim games, get Elite: Dangerous instead. Or anything else but this. It took the devs several YEARS of patching to make X3 titles good. May be worked back then, but the genre   is starting to live it's second golden age and there are PLENTY of other titles to choose from. No matter what is your goal with them, I can guarantee NOTHING of them can be fulfilled with X: Rebirth. It takes a few hours of playing to understand why and how disfunctional and hopelessly broken it is, so belive me (and countless negative reviews) when I say you better throw that money out of the window than spending on this.

content:
, 2014
												bugs, bugs, bugs, bugs, bugs, bugs and oh...did I mention bugs?  I had a lot of excitement for X Rebirth.  The idea that I could walk on stations, and on the bridge of my own ship, was very enticing.  Unfortunately, the reality was a far cry different than any other "X" game out there.  While you CAN walk around on stations, and inside of your own ship, a lot of the interactions were buggy and time consuming.  Even worse, you are pretty much STUCK on your ship that you begin the game with.  While you can buy additional ships, and hire people to crew them, you cannot pilot them yourself, which is probably one of the main things that ruined the overall experience that has traditionally been a part of "X" games for years.Also, the control scheme has, if it is even possible, become even more convoluted.  While some things were improved upon, such as the ability to order your traders to buy or sell (A nice little menu, once you get used to it), the overall way you interact with stations has been dumbed down to become "XBox Controller friendly".  I understand WHY they did this, but it didn't quite work.  It just didn't FEEL right.The voice acting is horrible.  In a game like this, it usually isn't that important, but where EVERYTHING is voice acted, I quickly found myself wishing I could turn off the voiceovers - especially where my so-called co-pilot is concerned.  It went from charming to annoying very quickly.Over the last year, they've done a lot to patch the game, which is commendable.  The game was simply not playable when it first came out.  In fact, I suspect the game should have been considered early access, not retail release.  It made me wonder if they have a QA department at ALL.  If they did, they should fire their whole department, because they obviously did not do their jobs.  In my opinion, the game could not be considered "retail" until the last couple of patches.In summation, if you are a fan of the "X" games, I would suggest that you may wish to stay with Albion Prelude and hope that either egosoft scraps this new direction and returns to its roots, or looks at some of the emerging (and perhaps more promising) development efforts under way at various studios, such as Limit Theory.

												Even for 25$ this game is not worth it. Even I, a long term fan of this series cannot find enjoyment in this X game. It is true most X releases required a year or so of patching to get them in a good state but at least even without the patches for performance and bugs, the previous X games had something going for them. A huge universe filled with tons of interesting things and dozens of ships to fly and equip with countless different weapons. There are dozens of "sectors" but they are separated between a mere 4 systems and as such the scenery ends up looking the same in many sectors as opposed to X2 or X3 and that makes the world seem uninteresting to me. Another problem I have with Rebirth is the decision to stick you in one ship and give you a poor 8 choices of missiles and maybe 6 weapons. No longer can you fly what you want to fly, now you are in the Skunk and that is it. Even now after such a long time and so many patches I do not recommend this even at it's reduced price. The performance HAS increased but sadly the game itself remains dull and quite frankly boring due to all of the poor design decisions that were made. I will personally be waiting for the next game in the series (if it is to be) and hope they will return to their roots and give us a proper X with sectors by the dozens accross the galaxy and the choice of any ship that is present in the universe.

												Definitely a no.Graphics are mediocre, with NPC's that look like balloon people, though stations and effects are good.Interface-- what can be said? It is non-intuitive, repetitive, non-game enhancing. Instead of being a means to navigate the game (not the ship) it is a challenge to overcome, like a never ending mini-game. Gameplay-Haltingly challenging, not by AI standards but just to play. Crashes and failure to control varied assets is just not viable for playing.Bugs-This game has more than is reasonable, especially considering the expense of the game, and the time investment put into it.  Seriously... wait for at least the new year before even thinking about purchasing this product. I can't remember the last time I actually got STUCK in a game (I mean avatar physically stuck!)... maybe 2007 or 8? Unfortunately this is one of those games that looks like it is going to be a beautiful game and just simply does not deliver.I'll hazard a guess, the game took so long to deliver that there was enough debt/cost that they had to deliver something quickly to "break even" and go.  If Steam gave refunds, I'd be asking for one. Unfortunatley Steam is just the vendor, like a soda or snack machine.  They give you the options and price, but don't control the product.   I am sincerely disappointed in the game, and experience. While some folks "seem" to be happy about the game, I am not sure how they are able to bypass the bugs to find it enjoyable unless they are able to limit with specificity the areas they are exploring. Lastly I thank Steam for this review page, so that in the future I can look to see if the game is worth it. I hope that there isn't any other games that have this level of negativity.

												I've been a fan of this series for a long time. I held off buying Rebirth due to the very poor reviews it got on first release. So I was pleased to try it out for free this weekend on Steam. And I'm afraid that after 2 hours of playing time it is a firm thumbs down. I know 2 hours is not long, especially for a game like this which requires a lot of practice and perseverance. But 2 hours is long enough to know whether the basics are right. To decide whether you want to spend more time with it. And I don't. At the end of the 2 hours I am bewildered at the direction the studio has taken and the way the game has been implemented. Frustrating flight controls, mystifyingly pointless time consuming elements (highways, scanning, wandering around stations), uneven graphical quality (some aspects are good, some are appalling). What did the designers, developers and testers think they were doing? The studio should be embarrassed that it released this after a string of increasingly engrossing, enjoyable games. Yes, new ideas need to be dreamt up and encouraged. Games need to grow and develop. But ideas should only implemented if they add to the enjoyment of the game. This feels like a vanity project. Like someone important at the studio came up with a bunch of second rate ideas and no one else had the guts to stand up and say "No!" Well I am saying no - you are not getting my hard-earned cash for this nonsense. Terran Conflict wasn't without its challenges and frustrations but it had the basics right. What was being reborn here? A brain dead shuffling zombie, banging it's head against the cockpit door? This game is high on frustration, low on fun. Very disappointing.

content:

												Hoo boy, what happened to this game? Prior to this one the X series had been rehashed an absolutely ridiculous amount... This time Egosoft decided to try something completely new it seems. Of course they only have like 20 people, so that may not have been the best course to take even with 5 years or so to work on it. As a fan of the X series I can tell about 30 minutes in that they tried to change way too much in one game and it really didn't work out for them. Does it deserve the metacritic it got though as of this writing? I can't speak for the release of the game but in its current state absolutely not. The game is playable and better than a lot of space sims I played, it's just not up to the standards of the X series.First things first, the interface. X has always had a god awful interface that was the number one driver of the learning curve, so for Egosoft to make it even worse really is quite a something. This game isn't quite the menu hell that the others were, which really is shocking considering the number of complaints I see calling it that. There are plenty of menus, but I'd say overall it is fewer than prior entries to the series. However, even so everything is FAR more clunky. Far, FAR more clunky. The most glaring thing that stands out is that menus are no longer popups. You turn to the side and look at a screen as your ship comes to a complete stop. Greaaaaaaaaaat. No more multitasking allowed. One thing at a time only. And docking... goodness. Docking is even worse. You autodock now but you have to find the port since you can't lock on anymore. Then you get to walk around in the terribly optimized stations to do lots of things if you want to save money. This is particularly bad when it comes to repairing or dealing with black marketeers as you cannot even comms the people in question. It's neat that they added walking in stations to contribute to the atmosphere... unfortunately it seems like most of them look like carbon copies of one another.On the upside because of all the interface changes the game is actually legitimately playable on a controller. Quite playable in fact. For all the complexities of X they actually managed to fit enough on an Xbox controller using every single button. That is impressive. You're still crippled as far as targeting goes but targeting in general seems very poor anyway. Space sims have always been a rather relaxing genre to play, so I would count being able to use a controller without a keyboard backup as a major plus. Just chilling, relaxing... flying... Don't expect to sit far away from your screen though as the fonts are incredibly tiny and a strain to read even sitting at the desk. For a space sim and especially the X series you need to play a lot more actively than usual too. It's pretty clear this was an intentional design decision as early on in development Egosoft had stated SETA (up to 10x speed time skip) was going to be going away. Although I recognize and agree that it's not the best of design mechanics, I don't really agree with the design changes they made to fill the gap. The space "zones" are smaller and focused, with green streams along them called highways. While you are in a highway you basically play Andy's Asteroids from Earthworm Jim, either going really slow or dodging ships. It's kind of neat at first, but it gets old rather quickly. The autopilot is also completely and utterly unable to do this, so it never ever goes away. It also means no more autopiloting to distant sectors. You have to fly ever single kilometer on your own. I can't think of a single decent spacesim in recent history where this has been the case. Not necessarily a bad thing, but its definitely a major detractor for me when I was sitting in a capital class transport just giving orders to my massive fleet near the end of X3TC.Other smaller problems are the performance and a glitch. X3TC was quite difficult to run so this is nothing new, but this is for so little! The graphics are better but not by much. All the humanoids of the X Universe have awkward animations (most of all your lovely co-pilot whose comments you cannot turn off), poor quality models, bas voice acting... The aforementioned space stations run absolutely horribly for a narrow hall, worst I've ever seen. In space the stations are big and there really can't be a draw distance limit in space, but seriously? What happened to LOD?  There was only two sectors that had mega fps issues back in X3, but it seems ever present in Rebirth which is a real shame. As far as glitches go... Based on everything I heard about on release it must have been way worse on release. Now it seems relatively bug free, save for one thing. The combat. I still see enemy ships just frozen in place about 40% of the time. Once was even during a story mission where the objective was 'Survive' and I was horribly confused... The game is not bug free, even now, over a year later. Not terribly surprising given the fact that Egosoft never fixed a bunch of simple things in their older games, like the landing music being five times as loud as everything else.Even with its issues it's better than a lot of space sims out there... but if you compare it to its predecessors in the franchise it simply is not up to snuff. So much is gone for so little gained; I've tried to be objective in evaluating it as its own thing but it's very difficult to do so when you look at how much you could do in prior games vs. this one. On it's own, X Rebirth is mediocre. As a franchise that has built on itself incrementally, it is easily the worst entry. The thought that I may never get X4 or that it'll be similar to Rebirth makes me very sad.

												Definitely a no.Graphics are mediocre, with NPC's that look like balloon people, though stations and effects are good.Interface-- what can be said? It is non-intuitive, repetitive, non-game enhancing. Instead of being a means to navigate the game (not the ship) it is a challenge to overcome, like a never ending mini-game. Gameplay-Haltingly challenging, not by AI standards but just to play. Crashes and failure to control varied assets is just not viable for playing.Bugs-This game has more than is reasonable, especially considering the expense of the game, and the time investment put into it.  Seriously... wait for at least the new year before even thinking about purchasing this product. I can't remember the last time I actually got STUCK in a game (I mean avatar physically stuck!)... maybe 2007 or 8? Unfortunately this is one of those games that looks like it is going to be a beautiful game and just simply does not deliver.I'll hazard a guess, the game took so long to deliver that there was enough debt/cost that they had to deliver something quickly to "break even" and go.  If Steam gave refunds, I'd be asking for one. Unfortunatley Steam is just the vendor, like a soda or snack machine.  They give you the options and price, but don't control the product.   I am sincerely disappointed in the game, and experience. While some folks "seem" to be happy about the game, I am not sure how they are able to bypass the bugs to find it enjoyable unless they are able to limit with specificity the areas they are exploring. Lastly I thank Steam for this review page, so that in the future I can look to see if the game is worth it. I hope that there isn't any other games that have this level of negativity.

Until you realize that you're in the vacuum of space, the one place in real life that doesn't have random 'stuff' making the light scatter, and causing soft shadows.The campaign is so full of plot holes :- Oh, yeah, here, have some free guns.  It's cool.  - I just happen to have a massive freighter floating around unmanned, I'm sure nobody will steal it. - Hey black market guy, over here!  I've got some illegal drugs to sell you!  Don't worry about that security guy standing next to me, he's not programed to care!- Direct quote: "Steal anything that's not bolted down." from inside a station with no repurcussions. Heck, shooting a station a few times is just an 'accident'. But scanning that same station gets your reputation ruined.I didn't get far enough to have anything other than the 'noob ship', but I have to assume it doesn't get any better.

er 28, 2013
												Aside from what I wrote when this game came out.  This is the ONE game that soured every game I purchase now.  I am EXTREMELY careful about what I buy.  I wait until I see the reviews.  I look at the broadcasts.  I check metacritic.  This game was the worst piece of crap I have ever purchased at 50.00+  and steam would not give me a refund on this.  About the only other game I regret buying was minerwars 2033 at 25 dollars in alpha mode when they promised an MMO.  This game is absolute and utter garbage.------------------Please don't even consider this game or otherwise pile of crap.   The numerous bugs will not let you continue, the graphics are recycled in every spacestation with absolutely no change between stations.  The controls are not intuitive.. absolute crap.  The worst part about it is the $50.00 they are charging for this.  Highway robbery.  The developers knew what they were throwing out there and unfortunately many people took the bait.  If you really want to know more about this game, read on:1) From the very begining you are completely lost.  You will not be able to figure out what controls do what.  People have taken 30 minutes just to figure out that a very small little button is used to dock.  This button might not even pop up unless you are a certain distance from where you need to be and in a precise location.  On top of that, there is a bug which sometimes even prevents this little icon from coming up!  I thought I was a complete idiot for not finding this thing.. until I restarted the game and reloaded a save, the icon to dock came up.2) Every spacestation you go to looks EXACTLY the same.  The developers want you to go in the "Air Ducts" to find random money (who leaves money in the ducts?).  It really is frustrating for someone to go in the space station, look for a duct and try to find a pitance for all that work.3) The trading system is absolutely horrendous. In the real world you go to Walmart (or you find an advertised price) and you can go, Mmm lets say ebay and see that people are buying a certain item for more.  So you go to walmart, but the item cheaper and resell it at ebay for a profit.  Done deal.  In the game, you buy an item and you thinl "ok.. I am going to sell this item for more.."  but then you look and look and you look.  It will take you at the very least 5-6 hours just to find any other place that sells or buys that same item!!! on top of that you can't even figure out the price of it.  Even if you do sell the items, you will make a very small amount of money to not even make it worth your time.4)  When you go to a vendor.. they all look the same, they all say the same thing.  For a game that was in development for 7 years you would think they would at least have different vendors say different things or something a bit more interesting.  You have one of 3 different stories you can hear from them.  "Show me your warez"!  5) When you do take these space highways you have NO idea where you are going.  You just take one and hope for the best.  You have no maps, or anything that gives you a semblance of where here might be.  On top of that, you have to tailgate a ship to go faster??  Wouldn't you be afraid of that if you are traveling close to the speed of light?6) Space in Xrebirth isn't very big.  It feels actually extremely small for what they have.7) There are game breaking bugs that prevent you from continuing further in missions (like the Energy cell mission)8)  When someone is attacking you and you are defending yourself.  You are using a joystick to try to hit the enemy.  The enemy might be in between you and the spacestation.  You gun will now hit the spacestation and now you become the bad guy.  Be prepared for the police to start aiming you.9) did I mention you can hear the police siren?  WTF.  Space is void of air, how the hell does the sound travel?10)  Whenever you want to see the stats of an NPC you are hiring.. you click on a menu item to allow the NPC to show you their qualifications before you hire them.  That is broken as well.  You see nothing there (only stars)11) You can steal items from your own ships and resell them (how does that work?  you find stuff in crates in your own ships and resell them)I don't know.. I can keep going on and on and on.  I would've been more descriptive had I known that steam was going to be launching this whole steam review.  This game is very poorly made and the developers knew what they were throwing out there.  It is extremely sad they charged 50 dollars for this.  This game has just ruined it for all pre-orders on steam since I will never ever purchase another game on pre-order even at a discounted price without seeing what people are saying about the game.

content:
20, 2015
												TL;DR---------------------- Don't buy it in a year or however long someone told you it would take for this game to be ready- Don't buy it on discount. No amount of money should be paid for this game.- Dont. Buy. It.---------------------The X games have always been close to my heart. X3 did so many wonderful things for the genre. It improved upon the issues of the previous titles while adding what seemed to be boundless possibilities for customization and replay. X3 was the “be anyone you want” of space sims. Beyond that, the games always had a robust following of experienced and talented modders that provided even more customization and options to make the universe more alive.It was that consistency of greatness that drew my eye to Rebirth. I was captivated by amazing visuals and the promise of an even bigger universe than the previous games. All of this came crashing down, however, on the day of release. Steam comments flooded in claiming the game was nearly unplayable, and that the new features had drastically reduced the diversity of the gameplay. There was hope, however, as Egosoft heard the public’s plea and promised to introduce fixes in the future. Additionally, the modding community could pick up any slack the developers left behind, right? Wrong.It is now more than a year after release and the fundamental issues that make this game such a poor installment in this universe are still going strong. What was once a complex and diverse universe is now nothing more than a light framework for a space sim. The degree of customization and control has been stunted to an awful degree. Control of ships is absurdly confusing and requires you to continuously jaunt through infuriatingly vague menu commands that ultimately lead nowhere. You are confined (piloting-wise) to one ship, which is not as big a deal as it might seem, but the lack of control makes it too much of a hassle to play.Even the mods for the game are surprisingly unimpressive. There is no XRM or CODEA. That’s not to say there aren’t helpful mods out there, but they just don’t add the same degree of life as the mods of the previous X games. If you aren’t a German speaking player, you are also subject to some of the most awful (often to the point of hilarity) voice over work ever presented in a game. It shouldn’t be difficult for Egosoft to find native English, French, or Russian speakers to handle the localization and voice work for the game. The arduously broken English doesn’t just pull you out of the game, it makes you feel like there wasn’t really any effort put into it. It honestly would have been better if there weren’t any speech at all, just text.I feel very badly for those who paid full price for this. The game seems like it was made by children. Some of the “features” seem like something your 12-year-old nephew might suggest. The rest of the game is stale, lifeless, and oversimplified. I get that this isn’t supposed to be “X4,” but does that really justify the release of such an lack-luster product?

												This is a total waste of money.It has poor interface. It feels like it was planned to be released as a console game but the devs changed their mind at the last minute and converted it to PC only. So now we have a gamepad optimised UI that is very difficult to interact with a mouse and a keyboard, specially because it is incredibly small.It has a cockpit... that is constantly in your way when you try to play the game taking a lot of viewing space (nothing like the clean X3 view) with annoying animations, ♥♥♥♥♥ing Betty constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ing about everything, and the female companion competing against Betty to see who can talk and annoy you more. Also, there are no external views whatsoever.The "walk outside of your ship" every time you dock at a station is pointless, inefficient, frustrating and annoying. Besides it seems like there are only 2 or 3 different “looks” for the hundreds of station and ship docks which, after a while, gets quite boring.The map is utterly confusing and awkward, nothing like the ugly but efficient map of X3.Performance issues. The game feels quite responsive and fluid until you get hit with a performance drop out of the blue.Bug ridden. This game has so many bugs it feels like an alpha. Some of them can break your game progress forcing you to restart from the very beginning. Other bugs are quite frustrating like ships not following commands or factories not building and the like.But finally, what was a deal breaker for me, something I couldn’t get over with no matter how many times I tried to convince myself that this was something trivial, was the fact that you CAN’T use other ships than the fugly and crappy Albion Skunk. What the hell man? I mean, in X3 you could use tons of ships. That was something that made that game great, that’s not possible here. It is also worth commenting that there are far fewer ships through out the universe that in X3 so get used to see the same ships all over the place.There are many other annoying things that add up to the frustration of this game like the “highways”, the limited selection on weapons, multiple docking ports on the same station that you have to visit to access the wares or the people there, having to fly around stations to find the right dock, and much more that is not worth commenting anymore.Good things that I really like about this game are the graphics (just gorgeous), the music (quite nice and relaxing) and that there may be some tinny, little, microscopic potential in this game IF (AND ONLY IF) the devs get their act together and fix all the bugs, PLUS if the modding community feel sorry enough about this excuse of a game to try and fix it. Otherwise, I don’t see any future for this crap.So, all in all, this game is a perfectly done turd. If you want to waste $50 bucks go for it. In fact, burning those $50 bucks right now seems like a better idea than buying this game.You have been warned.

												8.8/10This is probably one of the most awesome space games that exists right now. In X-Rebirth you are allowed to pilot a ship and command your own fleet of drones/small ships/capital ships while you can literally do anything in this huge and gorgeous universe, filled with trading opportunities, beautiful stations, pirates, huge factions occasionally battling each other, etc.Ignore the bad reviews since they are directed to the earliest stages of the game. As of now, it is very simple and intuitive to navigate through the menus, recruit officers, contact traders, use the map to travel, do missions, go to stations, etc.There are only a few problems with the game that Egosoft won't probably fix, but they're OK since you can easily ignore them because there is so much to see. However, you can easily feel the game engine's limitations because they are somewhat superficial.The only problem in this game (which I don't have issues with) is the end game, that might be considered frustating to some. The trading is very limited in depth and the whole game can feel meaningless at some point, and you can easily exploit the game to a huge advantage. But I'm brave enough to say this is one of the best sandbox games I've ever played - 8.8/10

It is a good ship, but, I would love the chance to fly different ships.Overall, space sims are all far from perfect. If this game had other flyable ships, it would be the perfect space sim regarless of the other stuff.

"Freighter, go trade this" *continues to explore and fight until trade complete message occurs*Cons:-The UI is insanely in depth to the point that it's awkward and hard to learn-quite a few little bugs left-Voice acting is pretty bad-Some NPC models were added, but the originals are still there and BUTT UGLY as ever... why is it the ugliest ones hit on me!?-My biggest problem... you are stuck with one ship for the whole game. It is a good ship, but, I would love the chance to fly different ships.Overall, space sims are all far from perfect. If this game had other flyable ships, it would be the perfect space sim regarless of the other stuff.

												-version 3.whathever- Now that the game "works", this is what X-Rebirth is: a pretty, pathetic shadow of Terran Conflict. You are stuck in ONE SHIP, and can´t control capital ships that you own directly. Feel the rage when dumb captains take forever to position ships for trading, or battle without strafing from enemy fire. Remember when you wreaked havock onboard M7s in X3? Forget it: you´re stuck inside a flinsy little m3 that´s also a marine frigate - FOREVER. In X3 you would fly her a lot to board capitals, but never into battle against large enemy squads. Here, you don´t have a choice: it´s a flimsy M3 forever and take it.  And try to build a station in this game: Egosoft created a whole new level for the word 'imcompetence' when then maded decisions for this crap - essential resources unavailable due to plotline and complete lack of tutorials will make you rage, but not as much as when a 'captain' is limited to only transfer FIVE goods at a time to the construction vessel, pausing for almost 30 minutes to reposition his ship into dumb waiting mode.  X-Rebirth is NOT worth an AAA title price.  It´s a bargain bin game that you may play while waiting for X4.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Released broken.  They completely ignored the fanbase, trapped the player in a single ship, messed the menu to be "controller" friendly and REMOVED ALL THE CONTROL MENUS THAT MADE X GAMES PLAYABLE. The human models are horrible, and most of the capital ships functionality aren´t intuitive at all - they tried to dumb the game down, but that just broke it. You´ll see that if you play it - the game simple break and stop to a halt in a plotline food delivery mission because only ONE type of capital ship can do it. If you remember how messy was the launch of X3: Reunion, then ask no more - Egosoft did it again. Imagine you playing Terran Conflict WITHOUT being able to control your ships remotely... you get the picture. All it needed for it to NOT to bomb was an "early access" sign... this is NOT the sequel to X3:terran conflict or X3: Albion Prelude. Don´t dissapoint yourself, and wait for X4.

												I could rant for hours on this game's flaws, but I will instead condense it down to as few words as possible to save you and me some valuable time.Cons:Buggy. Poorly optimized for high-end PC's. Terrible voice acting and character animation. Missing core features (Like the ability to command your fellow ships) Anti-Intuitive interface. Sometimes game-breaking bugs. (No info on where things are and what things do in the game universe.)Pros:Beautiful to look at.Egosoft over-hyped and exaggerated this game's features for months, only for it to fall far short of any reasonable expectations. The game was rendered almost completely unplayable due to the amount of bugs on launch, which is inexcusable due to the amount of time, money and testing resources they had access to. I don't expect a flawless experience, there will always be at least a few bugs that slip through on launch, and that is always understandable. But they released the game with entire features of the game missing along with the many horrendous bugs! It's like they got three fourths of the game done and said 'ehh, that's good enough'. Many people are requesting refunds on steam for this game, but to no avail. They got ripped off by at least $50, dont let yourself do the same.Wait at least a few months for Egosoft to get their game fixed, and check it out carefully before buying.

content:
er 13, 2013
												I'll start of with the good things about the game, most notably its graphics in space. The game looks really nice when you're flying in space. There's very little to remark about the graphics in general, and the visuals in the game give you the impression that things in space got a bit bigger compared to the other X games.But sadly, the good news ends there. I've waited until patch 1.19 until writing this, and the game is still a horrible unfinished mess, well after the initial release. The AI in the game is seriously broken, up to the point where tradeships are stacked on top of eachother like a game of Jenga. While initially this doesn't seem to be that much of a problem, as the game progresses the situation grows to such proportions that almost all trade grinds to a halt. Bugged NPC traders will hinder the construction of stations, and the in-game economy generally will grind to a halt. While capturing a capital ship, the AI will occasionally think that the ships missing fire on me are also hostiles, reducing the capture of capital ships to "Hide behind/inside the ship and wait for the marines while the capital ship takes care of the trash mobs".The campaign itself is barely playable due to these kinds of bugs, although some people have reported success to a certain degree. I personally have given up on the campaign completely in favour of the "free play" mode. Sadly the bugs do not lend to a wonderful experience in that gamemode either. The game at some point will require you to walk around in stations, and while this unconventional for an X game, I can see how this can add to the experience to a certain degree if done right. However, the experience itself is horrid, leading me to believe that it was a nice-to-have feature on a wishlist that never was properly finished and shouldn't have become a core mechanic of the game. You get stuck in the terrain, the NPC character models are especially disappointing, and the gameplay of this mode is lackluster, boring and repetetitve. Of all the features in this game this one strikes me as something that was unneeded, and actually serves only as a demerit to the game in every way.As far as audio is concerned, while the game has fairly decent sound effects, the voice acting used in the game is below all standards putting even Oblivion to shame. The lines in the subtitling are quite often different from what the voice actor is reading. The voice actors often misread words, including the voice-over computer which will occasionally warn you that its "master" is malfunctioning or destroyed instead of its "maser". In previous X games it was less of an issue due to the nature of those games, but in Rebirth it quickly becomes a huge downside due to the amount of time you spend interacting with NPCs. The voice acting itself varies from lacklustre to dreadful, is generally uninspired and repetetive as the protagonist for the 8154th time asks in the exact same tone "Show me your wares", while your plot-device of a useless copilot will feel the need to utter the words "Shut up Betty" every 2 or 3 minutes.A minor but quickly annoying quirk is in the music. While in general I don't find music to be much of a big deal, there as a small timing error in the music used in the highways and super-highways. The BGM loops in 8 or 16 bars (2 or 3 seconds in this case), but due to the way the game handles these loops there is the shortest pause in between each loop effectively ruining the tempo of the music. While in general this shouldn't bother you too much, the sheer amount of time spent in the highways and super-highways makes this a really obvious issue, and while it is a minor glitch it quickly becomes terribly annoying. This sort of issue just shouldn't be present in a 50 euro game as it's trivial to do properly and should've been fixed very early on in the sound engines development cycle.All I can say about this game is that it was shipped as a defective product, and after a number of patches the state of the game has hardly improved to anywhere near a playable state. While I have waited a fair amount of time and tried a considerable amount of patches over that time, I feel that I've grown tired of fighting with this game and its broken design and bugs.Sadly, the game has lost the charm that it's predecessors offered in gameplay as well. It's clear that the game was obviously not intended to be a direct sequel, and while in general I approve of moving away from the tried and tested formula I don't feel the gameplay took a step in the right direction. If you are expecting to build a giant empire and conquer the stars as in the previous installments you're better off reinstalling one of the previous games. There is very little control over the other ships you own, and what little control you do have has been made as tedious as possible by terrible UI design. After 22 hours of gametime, which is an alltime low for any game in the X series, 2 corrupt batches of savegames, having to manually edit the savegame to fix bugs in the campaign, clipping through stations and getting stuck, a broken price system that miscalculates how a discount works, getting thrown out of a highway into the void and gritting my teeth at the lack of progress in fixing what is obviously a defective product I have decided to uninstall this game and not look back. The only thing I can recommend about this game is the amount of money you'll save by not buying it.

content:
er 27, 2013
												What started with gorgeous, promising trailers of X Rebirth turned into an unfortunate case of developer myopia on release.  It's bad enough to speculate that perhaps their publisher, Deep Silver, strongarmed them into an early release because, come release day, we were given something riddled with enough show-stopping bugs that this is an "Early Access" game without the benefit that title brings as an excuse.It's possible you might have a little fun here, just scoping out the huge the stations and shooting some things down but, before long, your fun will be soured by nasty performance bugs, broken core systems, and a sorely pointless station interiors.  X Rebirth doesn't just need polish; it needs a massive low-level revision.If you've already bought the game, I wouldn't bother waiting for incremental patches on this one - come back around April or March '14 and see then if X Rebirth is worth playing.  Also, be sure to check out the community mods.Until then, I recommend paying no more than $10 for this game, and cross your fingers that the next game in the X series actually remembers what an X game is.  Terran Conflict or Albion Prelude are entirely different games, and remain reasonably worthy purchases.

												This is by far the worst and most expencive game i have bought in a very long time. At first it seemed to be a boring training session to get used to how the game works but i realised it was not going to improve. I loved the other bug ridden X games but after my second day playing i cant see me playing much past day 3. I will read other reviews to see if the game gets any better further in, if not it will be going in the trash. I fealt the price for this game was a little high but expected the content to reflect this. I was oohhh so wrong.
