24, 2014
												Ok, I finally got the joystick working with this game, so now I've gotten a chance to actually play it (since I refuse to play flight/space sims without a joystick) it's actually a pretty good space sim, waaaayyy better than Elite Boredom, that game has nothing over this one other than graphics (the few it has). My main gripe against rebirth is that they limited you to one ship, I get why, but it's just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. It is cool you can control multiple ships though. All in all it's shaping up to be a good game and performance is ~37 FPS Maxed out with 2xAA at 3840x2160 on my 780TIs; at 1920x1080p @144Hz I get 57 FPS average maxed out. I would recommend this game to anybody who is dismayed by the absolute lack of game in Elite Dangerous, that's why I revisited this one and I'm glad I did. It has way more substance, you can go into the space stations, hunt for minerals, trade, do bounties, do escort missions, capture ships, the list is pretty comprehensive. The graphics are still pretty darn good other than the character models. I actually found this game far more immersive than the dead world of ED. Now I've only got 4.4 hours in so far, so if I find anything untoward I will update this, but so far runs well and plays awesome.

												I bought this game when it came out and immediately shelved it.  The game was broken and not ready for public release.  I didn't ask for a refund, I like all of Egosoft's X games and I knew they would support this or die trying.  I decided to wait a few years for patches and DLC releases for the game to get more "complete".  I am writing this review as the game stands now in April 2016, with Home of Light and Teladi DLC installed.I am still super angry that I cannot fly other ships.  X games always allowed you to pick your poison and fly whatever you wanted, or fly around in your space suit if you dared.  This game forces you to drive the Albion Skunk, an M3 with M4 weaponry and M7 missile compatibility.  I would prefer to drive a powerful M6 or hard hitting M3.  I believe the reason for not allowing you to change ships is because they added walk around mode while docked in large ships or stations.Walk around mode is stupid.  Even on release, the voices were repetative, and everything about walking around the station was like some stupid mini game that wasted my time.  The scenes become repetative as well.  To make matters worse, your ship, the Skunk, can still be blown up in space wherever you entered the station from while you are walking around and chit chatting.  You can get a game over if you are attacked while docked in a space station...  Egosoft changed the stations up.  Each station can be upgraded and extended with different components, nice.  However, every station has the same docking location types for your ship, IE bar, administration section, engineer wrench, and bullet thingy.  They all pretty much look the same on the inside, and specialists can be found in their corresponding section, or anywhere really.  It is random.  The sheer size of the stations makes it a huge problem if you want to talk to the station in general and get the low down on trade.  Trading is also handled by scripted AI and command execution.  No longer can you drive a freighter yourself and play the lowly merchant.  You have to rely completely on your AI pilots.  You are stuck with the Albion Skunk and that stupid co-pilot.AI is horrible.  Auto pilot is bad, so bad that they added the "Auto Pilot Epic Failure" voice error in the game.  Path finding is bad.  Ships get stuck on stations during combat.  You can actually fly into a station and clip inside and get stuck.  Combat is slow and pointless.  You might as well sit still and snipe.  UI is clunky and it takes forever to assign ships or give orders.  I found out how to group assign and broadcast orders to multiple ships, but it is still clunky and takes time to execute the proper orders.  Fighters are useless.  AI fighters will just die.  Your transport ships will also randomly break down and not repair themselves.The story is OK.  X games always had terrible voice acting and the story was long winded and boring.  I always just played sand box mode and eventually killed everything in my way.  The story in X Rebirth, however, isn't all that bad, but it is highly unbelievable at times.  I would have spaced my co-pilot the first chance I got.  Though, I like the story in general, even though I can't believe how the main character just stumbles in to being main hero all the time.  The writers portray human greed a lot, but seem to have a disconnect when it comes to Ren Otani's reactions to everything that Yisha gets him in to.  Hell, I don't know why Ren wants to keep the girl in his ship, she literally ruins his life.The story missions also take forever.  Trading isn't fast, it was slow in X3, and even slower now that the ships have to travel farther and line up on even larger stations.  It is a slow process building up your station to meet campaign objective goals.  The stations that make your components are usually sold out or in the hands of your enemy.  In fact, building the stations for campaign missions nearly ruined the game for me.  You have to raid PMC ships to get what you need, and that takes time.  The rest of the missions are simple, go here, escort this, kill that.  I lost my entire fleet on a PMC boss fight only to find out that the mission was supposed to lose...total burn.Level design is ♥♥♥♥, and story is meh.  The space highways are stupid, and the music that plays while you are in them is garbage loops.Fleet combat is also stupid.  It is nearly impossible to tell your ships how to target.  They also don't care about formations or tactics.  Though, X games always had this problem and were usually fixed with mods.  X Reunion, on the other hand, is so bad of a game, that nobody even cared to make the mods to fix this aspect of the game.  You essentially have to zerg your opponent with destroyers to win a major conflict.Pros: graphics are better than X3.  Sound is similar if not slightly better.Cons: Only flying the skunk is a low blow.  If I ever meet the Egosoft decision maker that decided this was a good idea, I have choice words for that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  That literally ruins replayability for me.  I hate the Albion Skunk, it is a terrible ship.  Just about everything else in this game is worse than X3.You cannot build station production loops anymore.  Other: If you are a diehard X fan, sandbox mode isn't too bad.  However, it will probably get boring quickly because all of the cool management features from mods in X3 are not available in Xrebirth.

ber 15, 2016
												TL;DR: Dis game is awsome!!1!!11 You shoot stuff and all!!1! Lol xoxoxoxo!!1And now for a more balanced approach. My review is based on version 4.0 with both Teladi Outpost and Home of Light expansions.X: Rebirth is of a space sim genre with strong elements of a strategy game and resource management as well as some elements of a cRPG. The player is responsible for direct control of a single spaceship with numerous sub-systems (ie. remotely controlled drones) and indirect management of a fleet of owned ships as well as stations. The player can also dock, disembark and walk around stations and in the docking bays of friendly or neutral ships.It is a projected 'step forward' from the previous, well known titles of the 'X' saga and was intended to be a fresh take on the aging idea. While comparison to previous X titles is inevitable this game should (IMHO) be played and assessed as a stand-alone.The Likes:- The trading system is diversified and hardly ever boring, there are dozens of wares and a complicated system of supply and demand to tackle.- The more work you put in, ie. exploring systems and stations, the more benefits you reap. Establishing trading agents on every station pays off handsomely in mid-to-late game.- All trade details in one screen, easy to execute, feels more 'hands on' and definitely makes the player feel as if they're sitting at the Wall Street Market waiting for this one golden opportunity. Ordering your ships around makes for more immersive experience than just setting everything up and leaving the fleet on auto.- Capital ship combat. In contrast to many similar titles, the capships are meticulously designed with many parts that can be targeted and destroyed without ripping the hull to pieces and the player can easily take advantage of blind spots.- Being confined to a small craft brings fun back to flying. Sure, all of us want to stand on the bridge of a mighty battlecruiser and feel invincible... but to be honest, in X3 I have always kept my M1's and M2's on escort duty due to their slow speeds and sluggish response, and used M6's to fly around. Rebirth does exactly that - gives you a perfectly balanced ship to do your day-to-day work whilst retaining the possibility to command a fleet of destroyers.- Boarding actions. The game expands on the idea first introduced in the previous titles and adds a certain depth to it. Capturing a capship now involves quite a lot of work but it pays off handomely and piracy is much more viable than in other, similar titles, even with the recruitment costs of your expendable meatshields marines.- Did I mention capital ship combat? Yes, I did. Lemme just add, that witnessing two destroyers slugging it out is a sight to behold.- The stations are highly detailed and actually 'feel alive'. While some may superficially resemble one another, the final result is actually rather customizable. They are vast installations, spanning several kilometers, with various, highly detailed and targettable components and interiors that may be visited (and looted).- The station building aspect is very well fleshed out and though out, with plenty of customization options available.- Missions. I find they are a good source of money throughout the game. They are varied enough not to feel bored after an hour and they are quite rewarding.The Dislikes:- Steep, unforgivable learning curve, with not many tutorials to learn from. The actions are also very badly explained and results can be heavy - click a wrong button and you're set to loose thousands of hundreds of credits.- Ant work. Grindfest. Repetitiveness. These are in-built in some parts of the game and are actually required to lift your new-game off the ground - exploration of the sectors in the beginning coupled with mindless scanning of the stations are a must if you want to earn any credits when trading.- The profits made are a drop in the ocean of your needs. You may hunt around for good deals and trade massive amounts of wares, but it takes dozens of those to earn enough to return the investments made when buying a new ship or building a station.- The flight model is simplified and resembles flying through thick pudding. Same with combat - dogfighting, which gets boring quick, against oponents that do the same maneuvers over and over again, is something you will get annoyed by quickly.- Selection of weapons is silly - only one of each is permitted even though the ship has five hardpoints and the guns themselves are rather generic, ie. a blaster, a shotgun, a machine gun, a laser and a plasma gun. Gone are the days of balanced loadout of exotic weapons.- Choice of interiors is limited. Sure, there are variations between stations, cultures and even between docking points of the same station, but it's just a 'procedural oatmeal' with rubbish bags generated in different parts of the same half a dozen layouts. You've seen everything after an hour.- Money! Everything is so horrendously expensive!- Horribly streamlined. Egosoft made an effort to bring the game to the consoles and in the process has made the UI clunky and hard to control.- Dumb AI. Duuuumb AI. Whilst better than most, forget any sophisitcated tactics and moves.To summarize - X: Rebirth is a good game that offers a lot of entertainment, but suffers from many bad development decisions. I know many players feel burned and this is reflected both here and on Metacritic, mainly because they perceive it as a step back. however, I have had plenty of fun playing this game and would recommend it to any spacefaring gamer out there. It is a relaxing experience that gives the player sense of accomplishment whenever a great trade deal is secured or a new transporter is released from the shipyard. There are hundreds of tiny things that make this game enjoyable... but I may well be the only gamer that enjoys 'parking' the Skunk right next to the brigde of my Heavy Sul, giving orders to the captain and listen to the whine of the engines as they hurtle the capship through the sector, dragging me alongside whilst I'm enjoying the view...

												I will not sugar-coat this, X: Rebirth was absolutely terrible at launch, but the reason why I still recommend it is because I think now with all the updates, it has become a decent game. If you don’t want to read the whole thing, then just go to the last paragraph on the bottom.First of all, let’s consider the price. I think the current price of whooping 50€ is unjustified; it wasn’t justified at launch and it still isn’t justified now. What I would recommend to people thinking about buying this game – wait for the CHRISTMAS SALE. I’m sure XR will be on sale this December, so even if you don’t like the game, you will have not spent too much money on it.Many people already familiar with previous X games will say XR should have been X4. What you have to consider is that the developers never intended to make X4, they wanted to create a whole different game with different mechanics. The biggest problem here is that they (over)simplified XR to appeal to wider audiences. This is the sole reason why XR does not feel like X4. They reduced the game complexities and I believe that cost them more than they thought it would. Many features were completely stripped from the game; the most debated being able to fly any ship reduced to only one ship in XR. Some features have been added now with patches though, which I find this ridiculous as they should have been in the game from the very start.As I mentioned before, at launch the game was riddled with bugs, crashes, and whatnot; it was completely game-breaking. But I believe they fixed quite a large amount of those and the game is slowly shaping up into a decent game. For players thinking about getting this game, you should be aware that XR is very sloooow. The developers wanted to make space exploration and economic empire building to be as realistic as possible, so even simple operations like ordering your ship to trade some wares, takes a while. They justify this by saying, “while you’re waiting for the trade to complete, go do / explore something else”. But after a while, this becomes terribly tedious and annoying, especially if you opt for building stations.Building stations for your trade empire used to be much simpler and faster in previous X games. Now it just takes forever, and to top it off, it takes a vast amount of money and resources. Again probably to make it more realistic. Fleet control is hardly on par with X3, there’s less races, less star systems, trading can be grating at times while you’re waiting for something to happen, travelling times are longer, the plot is not really that great, the interactive menus are badly designed (improved with v 2.50), and the NPCs just suck.BUT despite all this, I still invested 300+ hours into XR because I enjoy space simulators. The vast space cities they designed are stunning and gorgeous to explore, the universe really does feel alive, capital ships and freighters are also badass and I enjoy capturing and collecting them, watching your stations expand and earn you more money feels good, manoeuvring around stations at high speed looks awesome and your choices can really affect the universe.Hopefully with the release of XR 3.0, new features/improvements will make the game more enjoyable.In the end, it’s all a matter of taste. If you enjoy space simulations or you’re a hardcore space gamer, I think XR would be a good game to try. But if you are a casual player not looking for slow and complicated in-depth gaming, then you’re better off playing a space shooter or fast-paced strategy game.

												Edit: For the purpose of the one person complaining so much in my DLC review, because he is so butthurt over people hating his much loved game, I will add this prior to the below starting paragraph of the review.Either the 3.0 update, 2.50 update or the DLC may have been intented to have a "new menu system", therefore the DLC may or may not have been intended to bring in "a new menu system". Still there was intentions to bring in "a new menu system" because this is the wording in the "Update History" for X-Rebirth.The post stating "a new menu system" can be seen in the "Update History" in a post dated the 26 September 2014, first paragraph, second sentence. The same post is also on the Egosoft website http://www.egosoft.com/news/current_en.php same date, same position.Here is the quote "Together with the general availability of Update 2.50 for X Rebirth, which will be released soon, bringing a new menu system, ".Still a new menu system has not been added.________________________________________________________________When X-Rebirth came out now a year ago, I did not write a review although I definetly wanted to, there where however enough negative reviews already and that was all I was going to contribute, I wanted to back off from the whole debacle to allow for the devs to fix the bugs, make improvements and deliver new content. I was a big fan of this company and played all the previous X titles, spending thousands of hours in total across all the X series.My first experience with X-Rebirth the moment it became available to play just as so many others had experienced was terrible, below are some of the many problems at the time I found with the inital release.1) The first few times it crashed at menu.2) The next several times it crashed 10-30 minutes in the game and a few more crashes at menu in between. 3) The FPS was terrible getting 10-15 FPS when panning mostly.4) I could not proceed with missions after the first few.5) Once my freighter got stuck and would not collect the energy cells, causing me to have to restart.6) I found it absolutely ridicoulous that some way into the missions I was the enemy of most sectors.7) The menu system was cumbersome.8) I was stuck in one ship9) NPC's being terrible drawn and the annoying character Yisha, particularly saying shutup to the computer.10) I could go on with many more.So there have been quite a few updates and 2 expansions since then, I have kept the game updated and tried it out a few times to see its progress, If it becomes as good as the existing titles I will play it through. It has in my opinion not changed enough for me to want to play it through.A lot of the bugs have been fixed, It no longer crashes at the menu nor while playing, the NPCs are still terrible in rendering, animation and dialogue, Yisha no longer says shutup everytime to the computer, it has been greatly limited. It's still there and really needs to be removed all together. The biggest thing however is that the menu has not changed in the slightest, it is still needlessly cumbersome. Also you are still stuck in one ship, no matter what game option you want to play you are still in the Albion Pride and still with Yisha. In the other X titles, choosing a different game start ment you where in a different ship, this really needs to be introduced into the game.The new expansion The Teladi Outpost does not deliver on all the improvements it claims just as the inital release did not deliver on what it claimed, X Rebirth is still a failure and worthy of its low rating amongst critics and customers both new and old alike.

												In my short time with X Rebirth, I can say that I am, so far, 100% happy with this game. I know that the game had a rough (awful) launch and the following months weren't even remotely good either, but I believe update 2.0 fixed most of the problems players were having. The campaign is still a bit buggy with trade ships flying around for 40 minutes, only to leave the area without finishing the run, but restarting the game fixes that. If you're looking for a story, don't expect one. Play through the campaign to learn how to play the game, then jump into Free Mode, where the galaxy is yours to do as you wish. This is the space sim I've been wanting since childhood. This game is phenomonal in nearly every aspect. I say nearly only because of the facial models and some voice acting. Yes, some stations are copy/pasted, but I can look past that unlike most of you. To me, it feels nice to be able to freely exit my ship and talk to other people and aliens, and accept jobs or trade. This game is truely  what a space sim should be. Let's go a bit further though.You only get to fly one ship?Yes, but that ship is uprgradeable/customizable in nearly every aspect, including the cockpit/HUDI heard the FPS dips to sh**I've yet to have that happen, even during massive, 100 ship battles. Upgrade your POS computer.What can you do?Whatever you want, really. Go to bars, strip clubs, buy weapons, food, ammo, trade to ships/stations, bounty hunt, work for police, explore, pirate, anything!This review is not yet complete and I will be sure to update as I play the game more, but for now, yes I 100% recommend this game to anyone who loves space sims.

												This is a post 2.0 Review. A lot of the problems listed in the overwhelmingly negative reviews have been fixed. This far, I've found the game playable, and even interesting, though admittedly I waited to buy it on sale so I'm not expecting Mass Effect meets X3: Albion Prelude.The first thing I'd state is that this game is a simulation, not a traditional space sim. Thus far, the command ship I'm piloting flies like a drunken cow. Take a look at a contemporary aircraft carrier; that's what command ships do. But the world they've built here IS interesting, and at 10 hours into the game I'm starting to find ways to turn a profit and build myself into the trading system, as well as having a decent amount of fun exploring what the dev team built here.If you're expecting to jump straight into the cockpit of a maneuverable fighter, or fight large scale space-operatic battles right off the bat, this is not the game for you. There are still some bugs here (learn to love quicksave), but the game is good looking and a genuine, immersive experience.I'm going to say this one more time: THIS IS A SIMULATION. It's halfway between X2/X3 and Battlecruiser 3000AD. If you don't want or can't handle a steep learning curve and some of the frustration that comes with trading between genuinely different stations and not being the baddest ship in the galaxy (though you might just become the baddest fleet in the galaxy), pick up the old X3 games. Otherwise, you're in the right place, I hope they get the chance to finish polishing it.I'll update this review when I have a few more hours in.

r 18, 2015
												I managed to get this game for £6 from a Chinese website. I've read loads of the reviews warning me about this installment, but I absolutely adore Egosoft and I've been revelling in the glory of X since X2: The Threat. (I have over 400 hours in total clocked on all X games) £6 seemed like a fair price compared to the ridiculous price Steam is charging on here, so I thought I'd give it a go.I wish I hadn't. I feel like I've been robbed.Egosoft state they wanted to make the game accessabile to new players, but what they've done is remove everything that the X veterans loved about the game, but also made the game so poor that new players are not going to want to pic it up. They've failed both markets.The game was released completely unfinished, as we all know, but they've release 3 revisions and numerous 'patches' over two years and they still haven't addressed any of the underlying problems with the game. I have no idea why they re-wrote the engine, the original one was fine. They could have just expanded on the original one. The storyline is  basically the same, the lore and story follows on loosely from the previous games, but it feels completely disjointed, it doesn't make any sense. The graphics are terrible. The textures are terrible. The voice acting is terrible. Hell Roguey even 'quit' the X community because he was so mortified with what Egosoft had done to the game.Empire building is gone. Real trading is gone. Flying a million different types of ships has gone. There's no jumping in an M5 and racing around, bouncing off asteroids, then jumping in to an M2 and annihilating an entire system single handed.But my biggest problem with this game? The controls. In X3:TC they introduced the horrible control system for mice... the 'follow the cursor system'. It vaguely worked okay, but they gave you an option to use 'Classic flight mode' (shift + n) which was how X was meant to be played and works fine with a mouse. In Rebirth they have implemented another follow the mouse mode as the ONLY and compulsory method of flight, and it SUCKS. It's horrible and basically makes dogfighting impossible. I know many people like this kind of control and that's fine, but there's many of us who hate it. Egosoft has refused to implement this for the veterans. Egosoft spent so long trying to make this game feel like a console game with the controller inputs (the radial menus?) that they've forgotten that its a PC game. I wouldn't even mind that much if any of my PC controllers worked with the damn game?! All in all, don't make the same mistake I did. No matter how much you love space sims and/or the X universe, don't be tempted by this travesty. You'll regret it.If anyone wants me I'll be in the X3 series. :D

												Version: 3.0Is it 'playable'? Well in a purely technical sense, yes it is. It doesn't crash every five minutes and for the most part the most ridiculous and game breaking bugs appear to be fixed now that it's been out for more than a year.Is it actually enjoyable though? Definitely not, unless you have a strong sadistic urge, you most likely won't enjoy this AT ALL. Be prepared to wait hours upon hours for stuff to actually happen, cope with a ridiculously unintuitive user interface that requires you to click options for 5 minutes to do the most simplistic things imaginable and other highly annoying things to that nature.The previous games actually had sensibly structured menues and allowed you to configure hotkeys for every single important function you would ever need and then quite a few more. With this though? No Hotkeys whatsoever. Heck even within the dialogs it's ridiculously unintuitive. Press Enter to confirm stuff and/or make stuff actually happen? You'd better forget about that. Enter get's replaced by 4 in most of the dialogs, unless of course you hit one of the many exceptions to this rule when it's some random other number key or, in very rare circumstances, they actually stuck with the proven Enter key.Hit Escape to go back? Not so much in this game.The list actually goes on and on, but suffice to say that the UX is actually the worst one could possibly imagine for any game to have.Which leads to actually having to answer the question about whether or not it's playable with "no" since the UX is so freaking terrible, there are no words for it.Remote trading is pretty much gone, for like the first 10 hours or so there doesn't seem to be any way to remote trade or control anything. It continues to be this way until, by accident / pure luck, you spot the top part of the Trade dialog actually has an option to select one of several (not all) of your ships to do the trade.After you did that, you'll have to wait for endless hours for it to actually do it. Since there is no SETA anymore you're actually forced to sit there and wait, or do other stuff in the real world (as you can't use your PC since it has to run X).So yeah, I ended up going outside playing some Ingress sessions while the game was running waiting for your stupid ships to actually do something you are required to do and wait for.You can pretty much forget about fighting too, your ship is way to weak under any circumstances and pretty much uncontrolable in any fashion required to be able to dogfight, which unfortunately is being pretty heavily focused in the storyline so far. So be prepared to die A LOT, until you're so frustrated by even just flying around that you either say screw this piece of $60+ ♥♥♥♥ or go and make yourself invulnerable by means of cheating.Long story short: DO NOT BUY THIS! Go buy any of the previous titles really, they're fine and you will have lots of fun with the previous titles. They have a logical and sensible UI, and even though it might seem  a lot at first it actually provides a good UX.This one however has the most terrible UX & UI that has ever been created in the history of mankind and unfortunately that cannot ever be fixed.If you absolutely want this to complete your collection of X titles then maybe get it when it's on sale for less than like $5 or something. Anything more than that is simply not worth it.

												I pre-ordered this game. It wasn't playable when it came out.Eventually I was able to finish the campaign with a great deal of effort.Now that 4.0 came out I thought I'd see what playing this was like. I was looking forward to some "empire building".The native game requires too much micro management, and has completely idiotic design ideas.- Trade ships only remember stations for certain amount of time. It doesn't seem to matter if they just traded with it 5 minutes ago. All that seems to matter is whether the player ship has seen it recently. Present day is more advanced and efficient than this silly futuristic space game.- You have to fly near the stations and visually inspect them in order to get trade information. Sure, you can buy trade software to make it so you only have to fly near the station. However, are you kidding me? I can buy things I didn't know existed from towns I have never heard of using this magical thing called the internet. I can have people I've never met ship these wonderous things to me. The designers of this game have failed in so many ways.- Bugs are still present in this game, and they're silly similar to the bugs I encountered at launch. It is the same now as it was back then. The AI of certain ships die and they no longer do anything, ever. I bought a 10 million credit ship only to have it bug prior to making a single trade. Super cool. I've read online that I can edit the save game to fix it. Awesome. I remember doing that when I bought this game. I'm not doing it again. Not after all this time. Not after all the supposed bug fixes. It is clear that fundamentals in the design of many game systems are flawed and simply prone to error. Apparently if dust falls in the right place, a ship's soul will die. - Fighting is alright, though imbecilic. Super smart ships will jump to nav beacons in a hostile zones and get immeadiately pummelled. Meanwhile the player sees this and thinks there might be loot nearby. Yes, there is indeed loot nearby. From the half-dozen trade ships that oh so intelligently jumped into hell. Awesome. It's a shame they spent so much effort creating a visually immersive game only to have it be the most non-immersive game in a functional sense. You cannot have one without the other. It doesn't work like that. Ok, it works on the naive. Like, kids... I don't think many kids are buying a game like this...- Stations! You can go on them! You'll go on these stations a few times before realizing it is a terribly hollow experience. It tries hard visually, again, but fails hard in functionality. There is stuff for you to loot, but again... what? You can take stuff from peoples lockers and it is OK? Of course, because it's just a game... and we don't need immersion or logic here.Maybe some designer had grand ideas, and some silly person bought into them. Maybe then half way through their timeline they realized they were never going to complete their initial design specification. Maybe this could have been an amazing game if enough money and time was available. I don't know what happened. But, it just isn't good.Oh and see how many hours I've played? Yeah, that's me leaving the game on overnight hoping SOMETHING WILL HAPPEN.Awesome. 10/infinity

content:
ry 15
												This is a tough one to review. It's a good game. Don't let those ratings fool you. They are almost exclusively based around performance issues upon the game's release. Unfortunately yes it's taken this long to fix them all (that's how bad they were) and it does require a few easily added workshop mods to make it worth your time.The game is currently on version '4.0.' But, as such, 65 hours and I didn't experience a single c2d, minimal lag/screen tearing and all models and textures placed properly. Legit.Now, having said that, it ain't perfect. It does so, so many things right, even better than the other X games. However some bugs do still exist deep within, making the game playable but near impossible to finish; bugs like quests not triggering, wares not appearing, super strong enemies in low level areas...unfortunately what it does wrong it does so wrong it bottlenecks any greatness and instead of leaving you feeling like an epic veteran space captain, you feel like a helpless, injured lamb. Flying a spaceship.Fortunately this is worst at the beginning of the game, before you've upgraded your ship and have a clue how to play. Things slowly improve over time. There is a steep learning curve (not as steep as the previous X titles but still steep) with very, very little explaining of information. The first 10 hours at least were just me trying to figure out how to navigate through the menus. Eventually you do feel at least semi-empowered and it is fun to just fly around and blow up enemies and capture ships.Now, having said all THAT...the game 'can' be completed without any kind of mod...most likely, at least. But you will end up bald from stress and boredom about half way through. FORTUNATELY, and shockingly, this game has pretty active Workshop support...any game's saving grace. User made patches are godsends. There is also one called Simoom's cheat menu. Normally I would NEVER advocate cheating. I haven't actively cheated in a game since I was a little kid. I mean...what's the point? Well here the point is to be able to experience the game as it was 'meant' to be experienced, not as it currently is experienced. Making these ship modifications, making yourself not the ♥♥♥♥♥ of the universe...doing these things exponentially increases the games appeal and you get a feel for what the devs were trying to do all along.And it's when you're at this stage, the game is easily an 8, arguanbly even a 9/10. The trade system, though a bit overwhelming, is quite expansive (once you've upgraded your trade software) and you do truly feel like an epic space trader, brokering deals between corporations and governments, swindling pirates, stealing ships and trading their goods, dozens of wares to choose from...it's incredibly versatile, albeit tough to figure out without Youtube and Google.Combat, once your ship is upgraded, is also incredibly well done. Seriously, do not listen to these reviewers who likely didn't finish the game (or haven't updated the review in years. This is NOT the same X-Rebirth). The combat is some of the best space sim combat I've experienced. It's fast paced, intense, cool looking ships, multiple weapon and missile types...I mean it's awesome. The targeting system is easy to read and accurate. Dog fights are incredibly fun. The ship can be a little annoying since it doesn't always make it clear who's shooting at you from what direction, but once you get a feel for the game and learn the ropes this becomes a non-issue. Graphics are good, but just short of mind-blowing. From a distance the game is nothing short of a-mazing. You can just sit there and admire the universe for hours. As you move closer, I don't want to say it get's 'bad', it just gets...generic. From a distance you imagine these intricate space ships and stations, then when you get to them and they all look the same and not particularly unique...I mean they're still cool and fun to use, it is a TON of fun and super exciting to weave in and out of space stations...but it does feel like it's missing what the French call a certain, "I don't know what."Of course the worst part of the game would be the incessant need to land on stations. I say worst, but it's not like the 'worst' thing in the world, just get's repetitive after awhile. It would be the worst part of the game though. Fortunately your guy can run super fast and you can teleport back to your ship from anywhere...but you'll still wish you could just Comm in instead of having to dock and go walk around. It's fun for the first few hours, but it does get stale pretty quick. However compared to where it used to be, the stations are the most amazing thing ever and AAA status.In conclusion, the game is an excellent space-sim. Probably one of the worst launches in game history, infinitely worse than Rome 2 or Arkham Knight, while simultaneously being one of the worst game's ever. BUT it is also one of the most phenomenal combacks ever. It's a good game guys, I promise. It's not NEARLY as space simm-y as X3, but it is still a fairly intricate space sim that gives you lots of control and will appeal to the casual space-captain far more than X3 ever could. Elite Dangerous isn't even worth comparing because they are so different. Literally the only similarities are space ships in space. So if you're deciding between the two, do you want a space trading/combat sim, or a space explorer?I definitely recommend it on sale for $15-$20 or less, if not just to look at the graphics for awhile. If you like this sort of game, you will not be disappointed.8/10 Would eat chips as I float in space admiring my space station againEdit - Pro Tip: Early in the game you'll get a battle ship called a taranis. Repair this ship asap and use it to traverse the galaxy early on. Dock on it then give it orders where to go. It is incredibly useful having a battleship with you early on before you can upgrade your own ship. Expect to die and re-load a lot.

												This review will contain (in this order): 1. My personal opinion 2. A description of one minor bug and how to avoid it 3. some hints about harder plot missions and how to finish them (without spoilers or cheating), as well as one or two general tips.1. I first played this game in 2017 and completely missed any possible hype, or early problems, so my opinion is about the game as of 4.0. I actually had a lot of genuine fun and would place this game among the best games I played within the last year. This essentially plays like a better, faster, harder and a lot more beautiful Xbtf. However, some people complained about the inability to fly any ships other then the start ship. The ability to change ships will return in x4, but just like Xbtf, Xrebirth is the story of one man and his ship getting involved in big events (somewhat Han Solo and Millenium Falcon like, you even sort of have your own (human) female Chewbacca). You can however still own other ships and stations and order them around.Anyways. I enjoyed it a lot. The only thing that annoyed me, was that the NPCs were talking alot and I felt like they are generally unfriendly, but thats just me.2. The "death by collison" no longer exists in this game, which causes the problem that you can glitch into big ships, if you approach them at high speeds from behind, while they are boosting. In the past, you would have most likely just exploded. Now you end up inside the ships structure. You can now try to glitch out, it sometimes works. Other than that, just reload. This happened to me about once every 10 hours of gameplay. Just carefully approach, aiming for the side, rather than the behind. If it happens, it wont hurt you, because you can now save anywhere and any time (unless dialogue is running). Other than that, I noticed some three times that the bodies of NPCs on stations had not yet loaded in (which made for funny moments, watching floating heads), but they alwways did after a few seconds. Last but not least, three ctds in over 100 hours of playing, which i link to some specific program running in the background.3. The mission were you deliver some goods with your large tradeship. Trade now works a lot more realistic. Your trade ships now have to pull up next to the stations and then transports URVs will be send back and forth between the station and your ship. Just tell your ship to do the trade and wait. Like all thinks in all x games, it works somewhat faster and better of screen, so just leave the zone for a bit (dont need to leave the system), though you dont have to, because you can also watch the process if you want.The mission were you are supposed to build a station in a specific system. Construction ships now need actual wares and builder urvs to build and the process takes some time (again, more realism). You will need bio-optic fibres and fusion reactors. Both are rare and wont be produced in the system, so you have to organize it yourself (transports assigned to a construction ship will only trade in the system the ship is in). Fusionreactors are especially rare. You can capture Sanahar transports with those wares, from the bad gouys, if you are somewhat lucky. Other than that, you can closely watch a specific facility in one of the albion zones (look up which one). OR just go to the home of light system, if you have the DLC and buy that stuff, HOL produces the things in abundance :D. Dont forget to do the smalltalk minigame with traders on those stations and ask them for trade updates, the stations trade offers can then permanently be viewed (need opnly once per station).Last but not least,you can view your ships capture strength and enemy ships capture resistance in their respective general info parts. If yours is higher than the enemys, victory is almost assured.Thats it, have fun.

												As a space-sim enthusiast, I went into this thing open-minded, ready to disregard X Rebirth's abyssmal review scores and give the game a fair chance thanks to the free weekend promotion.Sadly, it only took about an hour to see that all the bad reviews were not only justified, but still relevant as well, despite all the claims that a myriad of patches have somehow "fixed" this train wreck into some sort of release-worthy state.You see, the problem isn't stability (although I have read several reviews that would suggest otherwise) - the problem is fundamentally flawed game design. This is immediately evident during the introductory mission, which ends with you destroying some hostile drone crafts and reclaiming your freighter, which the main character in his infinite wisdom seems to routinely leave floating around in empty space unguarded and unmonitored. And this empty space is swarming with armed rogues and thousands of hunks of floating debris, mind you. It's like leaving your space Ferrari on the side of the space road in the space ghetto. Who does that?Anyway, there's absolutely no way our hero could have seen this coming (>_>), so your only recourse is to set phasers to irritate and plink the drones to death. This is not nearly as straightforward as you'd think, thanks to this game's controls being the absolute worst I have ever experienced in any flight game in any genre, bar none (and no, Battlecruiser 3000AD doesn't count, because that thing does not qualify as a game). I don't care if this game is "meant" for a joystick - there is no reason that W, A, S, and D should not control pitch and yaw BY DEFAULT. Instead, the game pushes you to toggle flight controls - that's right, TOGGLE FLIGHT CONTROLS - with the Spacebar, which causes your ship to follow your mouse cursor. This needs no explanation to those who have experienced mouse-driven flight before. For those that haven't, all you need to know is that having to manually put the mouse cursor PERFECTLY back to the dead center of the screen to stop turning is absolutely terrible. I suppose you could disable the cursor by tapping Space to disable flight controls, which would stop turning as well, but COME ON.The obvious side effect of this is that hitting targets is ridiculously frustrating even when they're not moving. When both you and the target are moving - ha. It's nothing more than an exercise in frustration. How this passed focus testing is beyond me. I don't even know if the control scheme can be changed. The simple fact that this crap is the default is all I need to know.Your pitiful weapons can barely hit the drones at 300 m. However, the drones have no issue at all accelerating to 2km and beyond in seconds. Going back to Wing Commander 1 levels of AI complexity, the drones then proceed to stop, turn around, and rush you from 2km, firing all the while. They have no trouble at all hitting you non-stop, with laser precision from 2km away, even though you can't hit them. You can kill your thrust and sit there like a turret trying to do the same to them, but nope: eventually you'll lose your shields, individual components of your ship will start to break, and then you're dead.Why even include "combat," if this sorry mess is the state of it? You get spanked mercilessly by braindead AI at the very start of the game? You're trumped by what I assume are supposed to be throwaway DRONES?I've got plenty of other complaints. Don't even get me started on the "hyperspace lanes" nonsense, which is essentially a long-winded, boring, irritating teleportation mechanic. I'm just going to stick this game in the rear-view mirror and have done with it.Do not recommend.

												 As someone who played a lot of X3 years ago, which was my first and technically only X game i've ever played (also Terran Conflict), I cannot recommend X Rebirth, unless you can get it on sale. It feels clunky and unpolished in every way, compared to the previous game. There's some new features, and you can clearly see how ambitious Egosoft were. For example, you can walk around your ship, see the crew compartments and stuff. You can also walk around the stations when you dock, and talk to weird german aliens and loot crates like some kleptomaniac RPG hero, also you can hack things to make the station vulnerable to attacks or something. All this walking around stuff didn't look very functional, but it's kinda cool, i guess. Even if your ship and the stations look like crap on the inside. Also the denizens don't look too good. They look horrible, actually. It's like Egosoft pulled their models out of some weird european FPS from 2003.  Me myself, i was fine with being locked up on my ship all the time back in the X3 days of yore, staring out into space even as i docked into stations. Voice acting never was the strongest part of the X games, i suppose, but this game, which heavily depends on it, because it brings you closer to the actual people aboard the stations and your own ship, has some terrible, god awful english voice acting. Everything except for our smarmy space trucker hero talks like a robot, trying to communicate in what it thinks is English language. Oh, and there's supposedly only one ship you're piloting for the entire game, which you got from the beginning, which is some sort of an argon corvet (i guess?) called the "Albion Pride". It's not a big deal, having only one ship for the entire game, considering that corvets are probably the most flexible type of ships and most players stick to those. You can also upgrade it in some ways to suit your needs, from what i've seen. Even after two years, as of patch 3.50, it's horribly unoptimized. My rig is i5 3570, GTX 660 and 8 gigs of RAM, and since NVIDIA Expirience doesn't support X Rebirth, i thought i should keep the graphics somewhere in the middle. And it still lagged like hell, somewhere around 30 fps most of the time. Egosoft were very ambitious with this game, and i respect that. Unfortunately, X Rebirth doesn't feel good to play and i couldn't bring myself to play it for more than 0.8 hours. Some people say that the germans can only make crappy point-n-click adventures, and i strongly disagree. There's a company called Egosoft, which created some of the best games i've ever played. I'll be waiting for the next X. Good luck to you, guys.

content:
, 2015
												Notes: I am reviewing the vanilla X-Rebirth, without any modifications at all. I must do this in order to baseline the review, at the time of the writing the release is 3.5 - and rumors are another bugfix patch inbound soonish. Which the game frankly needs.After playing close to 22 hours in X-Rebirth, I can honestly say I do not recommend buying it if you are an adult, unless you have PLENTY of time to kill; This could be great for a younger teenager with plenty of time to spare, I'd have loved it back in the 90's.Like many other people who have played prior X games, I heard the negative comments. I ended up buying it anyway. I don't really regret the purchase, but I realize now one of the biggest obstacles for me is the feeling like I am going to get anywhere with this game.  Everything takes too long, and with no way to speed it up, I just don't see myself finishing anything in this game.90% of my 22 hours invested has been flying around, not really fighting, not trading, not even really having fun playing. You could I suppose call it "exploring", but that really isn't what it is. You have wormhole like paths you can take that do speed up your travel, but that is riding on rails like many racing games. It definately feels like artificially slow flying, and the empty space between objects makes this "exploring task" just boring, even using the highway system (wormhole like paths) barely improves upon this problem.You do have the option of using something called boost. With boost, it allows you to spend your shielding for a very short burst of speed. The trouble with that of course is that without shield, you take hull damage from enemies. So you can't always justify using the only real protection your bubble encased ship has, just to go faster, especially since enemies are almost always right around the corner, even if we forget the fact that the boost does not last very long at all.I can't fathom the design decisions behind the amount of time this takes, its almost like the developers didn't play the game at the speed we are.  I'm unhappy with my purchase, but enough positives exist that I will likely continue playing it. The gameplay at its core is not flawed beyond repair, for example, the combat missions can be pretty enjoyable, if you can find them. And that is really why I can't recommend this game. It requires SO much exploring that you don't get to really think, trade, build, or fight.

content:
er 3, 2013
												Maybe as with some of the other X-Universe titles, Rebirth will become a decent game in time, but for now I simply cannot recommend it -- and I do not like giving bad reviews because I know behind every product is a team that did try to make it work. Unfortunately, there is ample evidence that Rebirth was originally an attempted XBox 360 release, including XBox 360 controller support, but none for joysticks (unlike every other X-game since X2: The Threat). The code, the graphics, the general gameplay all say "console game" to me -- and my own theory is Rebirth was supposed to come out in 2007. Sure, the space backdrops are pretty -- but they were, in my opinion, just as pretty in X3: Reunion, a game released in 2005.There are more things wrong with Rebirth than right.- You have to scour station exteriors to find what's sold, then find a dock (which are no longer obvious), land, go inside, and locate the one NPC selling the item you want to buy. And the NPC graphics are laughably crude, with no more than a half dozen identical models. Station interiors feel like gulags. And the NPCs all talk like surly prisoners; heck, I'd be surly too if I had to spend my entire life on a space station that looks like a prison.- Speaking of identical models, well, that's the space stations, factories and whanot. Each one looks exactly like every other one. So yeah, if you go to all four sectors and all the systems and individual sites in the sectors, there are some 110 specific locales to visit. Seems like a lot. However, except for whatever planet or star or nebula is nearby and what specifically is being sold, they're all really the same.- Characters: They all hate you. Every single one. Try to have a polite conversation with an NPC to buy some ship parts and they respond like snotty teenagers. "A pleasure doing business... NOT!" The only person who has any affection at all for you is your co-pilot. Who mostly makes dumb remarks.- Apparently the X-Universe has suffered a devolution in technology overall. No more gates zapping you from point A to point B in an instant; now it takes minutes on these new 'space highways' (including a really stupid tailgating minigame). No more ship radar -- tech that was available in the very first X game, more than a decade ago. Dog-fighting has become an arcade game. Oh, and targeting is a total joke.- Egosoft -completely- forgot the lesson they learned as early as the first expansion, X:panded: That players want to fly more than one ship during the entire course of the game. That's right -- in Rebirth, you get only one ship to fly. And it's ugly. And there's no HUD, no way to fly your ship without static cockpit graphics chewing up 1/3 of your screen, with tiny, easy to miss indicators buried in the obscuring digital cruft.- User Interface: It remains terrible. The same key will do half a dozen different things depending on the context, and few of them are obvious. It is also impossible to remap many of the functions to other keys. Menus, if anything, are worse than they were in X3.- Other unbelievable design decisions: Looting boxes and air-vents for random junk and money, acts of outright theft completely ignored by station security standing right next to you. Having to land to buy -anything-, as with gates and radar, apparently the X-Universe denizens have forgotten how to use radios. Pointless transitions. Mind-numbing repetition in every detail of the game.- Bugs. Game breaking bugs. As is all too common nowadays, a pre-beta game was rushed out the door.Anyway, I could go on and on about my regrets in paying full retail for this game. I still have them. Want to have some fun playing a challenging space sim? Get a copy of one of the X3 games and deal with the steep initial learning curve. But all three of the X3 games are well-patched and have lots of player-generated add-ons to aid with gameplay.Or wait for Star Citizen. Like I'm doing.

literally dying in 3v1's and thought maybe my shields or guns suck until i found in the in-game encyclopedia that the skunk is classified as a "S" ship meaning small.  the only things under that are drones. so basically your trying to win the game with the smallest and weakest ship there is. all this nonsense about customizing your ship and what not. what good is that really? upgrading your small gun into a bigger small gun. regardless its still small and even if it did decent damage no matter what happens your gonna die in any fights where theres more of them because you simply cant "dodge" multiple enemies shooting at you. you cant boost aways because this drains your shields which is probably the dumbest thing ive ever heard of. another major thing to point out is most ships in the game have multiple guns which sounds fine because so do you but wait, the troll here is they get multiples of the same guns like 2x or 4x pulsed masers while you still only have one. i dont care if you upgraded it to mark 2 to get 30% more damage because they have 2 therefore 200% more damage. as far as missiles go im kinda glad to see they got it down to around 10 or so types. it took forever to learn all the missiles in x3. except... dun dun dun.... they (for one) dont even tell you how far the missiles goes so you dont have a freakin clue if you can even hit your target. on top of that anything less than a capital ship can simply out maneuver your missiles no matter which type you use unless the ai just happened to fly in a straight line which well, never happens when theyre running circles around your crappy ship.another obviously abused trick to get money is take on patrol missions as they pay pretty well most of the time, is to simply stay near a station and let the station guns shoot everything and chaching your magically making money for nothing. patrol missions in x3 were pretty scary at really high fight rank but now its like ok mission accepted afk ♥♥♥♥ break gg... sooo anyway even if somehow you managed to be an uber skunk pilot and 3 or even 5 enemies arent too tough to defeat and your well on your way to a fleet you think to yourself cool, i have (for example) 2 capital ships and 10 small fighters im ready for some action well, im sorry but, i cant remember ever seeing more than 10 enemy ships at a single time unless you plan to start a war with some faction in which case your probably going to be insanely outgunned because they have station guns on their side.the single best thing that happened in this game is how boarding works. its simply or 15 bucks then ya its probably worth that amount. but no more i assure you. game over x series, game over!

content:
14, 2015
												Upfront I have to say, I am a huge fan of the X³ series and X Rebirth is a different game, as was and is always claimed by Egosoft. So, I will try not to compare the two.TO UNDERSTAND WHY I RECOMMEND THIS GAME, YOU HAVE TO READ THE WHOLE REVIEW (or at least the last abstract :)Rebirth looks great! Stations and ships are detailled to a level that could be even considered not even necessary in a space game. Even the surrounding scenes in first person mode look great! The station layouts are a bit weird, though. All of them feel a bit crammed, even when they are huge on the outside. Textures and room are unbelievably repetitive. I don't get it why Egosoft did not simply include large windows in the station's interior sections to watch the beautiful scenery outside. They could use the same station layout over and over again, but you would still have a great sense of individualism. Add some simple ambient lighting effects depending on the outside scenery and you are there.Speaking of the interior: Here seems to be the biggest problem. The first person view is currently clearly a kind of elaborate placeholder. There is simply not much to do, but you could imagine it being used for close-quarter fire fights, boarding and similar missions. Why I say placeholder? The potential is there, but it is not being used at all. Other characters are boringly static, sitting around on their beds in their BORING 3rd class dormitories, for crying out loud. Whenever I have a bunk in a hostel, I will be sitting in a close bar, restaurant or even outside, or be somewhere either working or having fun. In Rebirth, the AIs sit, looking depressing as hell in their shiny helmets (helmets in bed??) and space suits. In the end, hiring one of them to drive your slow big freighter feels good. In the sense of freeing a pet from the animal shelter. I actually wondered if they would hug you!I don't even want to criticise the character models or animations. They are edgy and look clumsy, but that would not spoil the fun as much as the lifelessness of the stations. I want to buy a drink, change the music in a bar etc. Small, simple stuff. It's nearly all there anyway!Your ship looks so nice, you actually want to wander around in it and play with it. I am not a fan of the jerky cockpit entry animation, but my bigger issue is: Why make a ship you can walk around in, when you cannot walk around in it whenever you want? And why can I not enter the cockpit in first person view and look around and only have a pre-animated move to the seat itself. Also: I want to interact with the ship. Simple things: Have a music player somewhere. A TV set? An ingame browser, or SOMETHING! PLEASE! A coffee maker. A bed, or at least a light switch. Oh boy, you only have this one ship to play with, LET ME BOND WITH IT!There is so much springing to mind: Since I have a second character in my ship, why not allow her to "autopilot" the ship somewhere and go to sleep for the trip? Have her wake you up if anything happens? Nice and easy roleplay option. Thank you.Flying the ship feels a bit clumsy, especially when in close quarters around a space station. Forward and backwards should be as controllable as traversing left, right, up and down in that situation. Having forward and backwards only via throttle does not feel good. Also I want to be able to look around properly in my cockpit.AND NOT THE BIGGEST ISSUE: Let me walk around in my ships. And let me fly them. It is a space game, for gods sake! I can understand this might be an addon. I could live with it. I was feeling especially confined when I landed on my freighter (MY freighter!) in the beginner's missions and was not allowed to leave the landing pad. I want to go to the bridge and look out the huge windows. THAT woudl be awesome.The winding of the space highways is utter nonsense and feels idiotic. Why not make them straight energy beam kind of accelerated ways, from gate to gate? This winding nature seriously offends me. Sorry.I can see where Egosoft would like to go and, having lived through similar ups and lots of downs with the X, X² and X³ series, I actually think they will be able to pull it off, but the way there could be quite long and rough.Before I forget it: THANKS FOR THE LINUX CLIENT!To sum it up:I think this will be an awesome game if Egosoft has the stamina to improve it to meet their vision, they are known to work on their games for years to come! I guess I will buy the game, even if it is only to give them the financial means to do it. But so far I will gladly wait to actually play it until it is more complete and does not feel like an elaborate tech demo.

												In its current state X Rebirth is a buggy mess. Trading does not work as the trade ships get stuck 90% of the time. Combat is overly simplified and overpowered. Its too easy to gain advantage even with killing capital ships. The easiest way to make money is to find it floating in space. Due to trade not working it is impossible to build any stations and even this is limited to a few pre-determined positions. There is potential in this game but its way, way off at the moment.The best thing for this game is for it to be modded to hell with all the wanted functionality put back in.If you have an interest in buying this game I would definitely wait until there are some major changes or mods available.

content:
er 26, 2013
												I've played X Games since X2 the Threat.Firstly let me say this game does not function in almost all "features" described on this page. They simply either dont exist or just dont work. I would strongly suggest you think acrefully before considering to buy this game.The game randomly crashes, lags heavily in places and has display issues with key interactive elements like the terminal disappearing and being unable for use - the fix being save/reload visit the crew area bump into the door and go back to the cockpit. Then the terminal reappears.Edit Savefile Meta GameIn order to progress and ATTEMPT to fix your woeful ingame problems many advocate "editing the savefile". This takes the form of using a word processor to edit an XML file containing the save data of the game. The format would be confusing to most and is inherantly frustrating and prone to errors. In my personal attempts to get the game to work I edited this file hundreds of times. In my stats I reloded the game 216 times in less then 7 dyas.Combat.The only functionality in game that works is some combat - although some enemies do nothing, your other ships dont fight, your friendly fleet members dont fight etc.Further you can only put a few weapons on your ship and only one of each type. Some of the combat graphics for some weapons is nothing but silly and annoying with pulse masers having a ridiculous wavy line thing obscuring most of the left hand side of the screen.Boarding captial ships is initially some fun - however you can kill a capital ship very easily by just sitting behind the engines and shooting or flying in the dock area and shooting.MovementIn previous game you were able to pilot what ship you wanted, fit it out as you wanted, dock it where you wanted etc.However in X Rebirth you are only able to fly one ship. You are unable to get other craft to dock, fly where you want, autopilot anywhere, fight, patrol, trade - the only thing they currently do is follow you and mostly die. Even ships you build or own will die to a single random fighter of any kind because they dont fight back.TradeThe only ships which seemed to be able to trade were the Medium Class traders of which I had 1 given me via the campaign and 1 I managed to get through combat - that extra one took me two days. In order to get the ship back to my "safe area" I had to edit the save file and turn off enemy standings so it could actually fly to safety.I shot about 100+ ships in this process and got 1. So it's not a practical. For the 100s of combat ships I played against I got 2 free ships. You are unable to repair them nor fit them out nor will they fight/patrol/dock etc.The trading screen show wares you are "aware of" to be aware you need to fly around stations and look at icon points on the oustside. However over time these disappear and you have to go do the same thing again. To get better prices you have to examine ( i ) points around the station - the more you have examined the more discount are unlocked - but you have to get them by flying around the selling and docikning ponts again. If you leave the zone some of these points reset and you'll have to do it all again. Further after a few hours in game play all of the discounts and selling information disappears - even if you have a ship trading with the station - which I had 1.If you try and use freighters they dock but are unable to transfer goods - and so do nothing.Despite my best efforts trading doesnt work and is a complete joke compared to previous X games.I tried to tell you about the rest of the game but Steam limits the amount of text so I cant,,, bascially all functions are bugged or missing.

er 15, 2013
												AVOID this game. Its a BIG DISSAPOINTMENT.  It does not deliver to the expectations on so many levels. It feels like a dumbed down X series game for a console ported to the PCs.well, to be honest I have mixed feelings after playing a couple of hours. Yes is an X game, it feels nice the stations looks beautifull and the space is full of life, of ships, police, pirates, the atmosphere is just right I like it a lot.Now, the things that started to bother me. 1) Albiun Skunk, feels more like an albion Scam. We were all told that the ONLY SHIP that we were going to fly was going to be detailed and everything. It sad, so sad to say that its only 2 rooms, sort of. One is the cockpit, when you "stand up" its take an animation of going to the door and openning and the other one is the ramp / cargo hold. Thats it, nothing more well just like a table that you cannot even sit on it, you cant do anything else in the ship, yes this is NOT star citizcen. 2) Docking, well at the beginning is fun to get into a station try to fing a place to land ( if you remember previous x games you align to the station and approach for docking, well not anymore). After you request permission to dock, the SAME animation when you stand up and go to the door happens, you NEVER see you ship flying and landing, or approaching no nothing. Then you apear already in a lifeless plataform. The ship lacks character no vapor, no nothing, its just like a 1980 ship set there in the dull scenario. mhhh.3) Stations, yes, for the outside they look amazing so different to one another, you can see every small detail te machines working etc. BUT, inside, when looking for crew or trade (kinda) you have to get out of the ship, wonder in the station (which is exactly the same in every station). If you land in a bar, all bars are the same, if you land in another part looks exactly the same. The NPC are dull and the method of interation is slow and boring.4) Tunnels in the Stations, the tutorial tells you that yes you can investigate the tunnels to obtain some good left behind etc, and you know what? in every station, every tunnel has some goodies, sometimes good sometimes bad, but come on. I mean the tunnels are EXACTLY THE SAME EVERYWHERE. 5) Music in the bar. Oh yeah... you get to the bar probably to hire a pilot, buy stuff or something, and the music oh my god, its just a loop of 3 or 4 seconds again and again and again and its completly unintresting to visit. No new mechanics of interactions, no pirates or smugglers or something cool. NOTHING!I dont know kind of miss the "simplicity" of just docking to the statiion and doing everything in a console, now, we are stuck in one ship which is dull (yes, you can se a cockpit) but forget about freelooking around, you cant do it. I am a bit dissaponinted. If you are not a fan of the X SERIES, stay away DO NOT BUY. If you are fan, well, you probably share my dissapointment.

er 4, 2013
												I purchased this game without looking at any reviews. I loved the previous ones so much I didn't think to even look. Sadly the only good thing I can say about it, is that the graphics while you are in space are nice... I REALLY tried to like this game. Most of my play was in free play. So, to start, you only get to fly the one ship, and I thought "OK. The they want you to take more of an administrative role. I can do that." Off I go to get a trade ship. So, I look at the list of ships, and find that you need certain ships to trade certain goods. Again I think. "Ok. I can see that. Kinda makes sense." I figure I will start with bulk goods. Then I see how much it cost to build even the cheapest trading ship. "Ok. Guess I need to take a direct role with my one ship and quest for a while to earn the money to be able to be a merchant." So off I go, spending 2 days trying to earn the money to build a ship. I go back to the ship yard and order my ship. "Ok. It will take some time to build." I come back 2 hours later to the ship yard, and it is still a 0%. At this point I load up Chrome to see whats up. Turns out, that the ship yard didn't have the parts need to build the ship. The games "fully simulated economy" didn't replenish the goods in the shipyard... ever.... The usual answer to fix this problem is to bring goods to the station yourself. The one and only ship I you have in free-play can't move the goods you need... So, at this point I am 3 days of play in, and the ONLY thing I can do is play as a space shooter. If I wanted a space shooter, I would go play Miner Wars, because, despite it's bad reviews, at least it doesn't make much pretence of being more then a shooter, And, it only costs $20 instead of $50. If you are looking for what this game promised, go get it's parents, X3: Terran Conflict + the Albion Prelude add on.  If you get the "X3 Terran War Pack" the two of them together cost $20. A very complex game, but worth the time to figure out. Egosoft would have been much better off updating the engine they used for this one instead of making the new one. At least then the reviews would have ready. "Just another update to an old engine, but it's still a fun game and worth the buy." instead of "Don't wast your money on this game. It is badly broken, and even if they fix the bugs there is no real game here."

content:
er 13, 2013
												For now the game is too buggy to even properly find out how deep it really is. BUT, from what I've played, the game tries to add immersion to the, but end up making things more cumbersome and downright frustrating to do simple tasks (like trading and remotely controlling ships). From reading on forums at Egosoft and Reddit it appears this game was meant for consoles (even though they are anot admitting this) and this shows due to the stupid radial menus and lack of key customizations (improved now after 1.19). It's very clear they rand out of time and did not have enough resources to complete the station portion of the game, the characters look like they are from 2005. CPU optimization is pretty horrible, which funny enough cripples high end systems, I have a 2500K, 8 gigs of ram, 7970GHZ, and i get sub 15fps in some areas which is completely unacceptable for a modern $50 release of a game (again this is due to the console direction).Unfortunately Egosoft keeps saying that this is not X4, but that is what your customers wanted so I have no idea what they were thinking, they just had to take X3:AC and polish it up and simplify some of the systems, add a better tutorial and they would be all set. Right now, stay away from this game, and it hurts to say this as an X gamer.Visuals (outside) - 8/10Vishals (inside) - 2/10Gameplay - 3/10Sound - 5/10 (horrible voice overs, and police sirens in space??)Performance - 3/10 (as of 1.19)Overall - 4/10 (Angry Joe scale - 5 being average, not 8 like modern gaming sites seem to do...)Come back to it in about 6 months when the bugs are stomped and mods are out (if the x comunity is even willing to try and mod the stupid decisions out of the game), otherwise Egosoft may never get the chance to make a real X4.

Right now, stay away from this game, and it hurts to say this as an X gamer.Visuals (outside) - 8/10Vishals (inside) - 2/10Gameplay - 3/10Sound - 5/10 (horrible voice overs, and police sirens in space??)Performance - 3/10 (as of 1.19)Overall - 4/10 (Angry Joe scale - 5 being average, not 8 like modern gaming sites seem to do...)Come back to it in about 6 months when the bugs are stomped and mods are out (if the x comunity is even willing to try and mod the stupid decisions out of the game), otherwise Egosoft may never get the chance to make a real X4.

												So first off, let me say that I have not played any of the previous entries of this game. But at the same time I LOVE a good space sim. With that said, I went into this game with no preconceptions of what it should be overall. I think that is kind of a problem sometimes with people that go into a game that have a long standing series that they played most of and they feel like it should conform to what they have played before and thats ok too sometimes though and can be helpful to people also but, this review I think could be helpful from the point of view of a person coming in fresh to the series.I did watch some youtube videos of gameplay prior to buying this game. My intial thoughts, afterward, were that I MUST have it. Now, after getting into the game a little bit and playing through the story some, I think that I stand firm with my intial thoughts for the most part. I like X Rebirth a lot. Its a great game with a lot to do. I love that it breaks up flying around space with a little on foot things to do as well. I believe that lends to immersion and that it is an easy game to really project yourself into. Also, with workshop support there are many different things you can add and change about/to the game that can add enjoyment or tailor to the way you want to play which is a very big plus imo.As I have said, I played through the game a bit now and with that I have also seen some of the bad parts of it. There are missions that get bugged and prevent progression. It is nothing but a google search and some notepad++ action to remedy it usually but it still is unnecessary steps for a game that is supposed to be finished (out of beta). Optimization is not the best either. But, as for the above mentioned topics it really does seem like Egosoft is working hard to patch and update the game to fix these problems while adding more functionality and gameplay to the experience. On a more opinionated note, I found that except for story missions and the occasional 1 line there is no verbal interaction between the pilot (you) and the co-pilot that sits next to you. I would've liked to seen more dialog between them when just flying around for more immersion and to learn how those characters relationship evolve and more about their history.While I did and do recommend this game and feel that it is definately one worth playing if you like the genre, I dont feel like in its current state that it is worth the $50 price tag (as of 2.10). So if you're really wanting value from this I would suggest waiting on a sale or just waiting in general because I get the impression that they will continue to work hard to fix some of the issues with this game to make it an even better experience. If you're not that concerned about the price tag and want a good space sim and are willing to deal with some generally mild problems then my recommendation is to give this a shot.

They should be highly commended for what they have done here. The custom engine is doing things that I'm surprised I've not seen addressed in an industry paper about 3D engine technology. The graphic design and overall artistic direction is beyond outstanding. Egosoft have created a genuine hint of what it might be like to be thrown into a strange alien universe that can be compared to the SciFi series FarScape. My reaction to the game reminds me of John Criton's reaction to being thrown into a starship of strange aliens and having to quickly, and somewhat painfully, adapt. This is all communicated in game by the overall atmosphere that Egosoft create. Another game that is doing this kind of thing very well is Wolfenstein New Order. I think both these games show the maturing story telling and atmospheric immersion of these new "next gen" games. As I understand it Rebirth maybe missing some of the features that attracted fans to previous "X" games, but I still think Egosoft should be commended for not playing it safe. The world needs bold new creations such as Rebirth ! Some of the furore surrounding the initial release reminded me of the situation when Codemasters released a game under the Operation Flashpoint name. Where that game did ultimately flounder, here Egosoft seem to be doing a better job of fending off the detractors and sticking to their guns. If Rebirth somehow manages to "stick it to the man" probably depends on how much you think space exploration is an important part of our evolution. But at one point I was flying down a warp tunnel ("superhighway") and the radar had the words "Far Out" emboldened across the top. Just so. Rebirth can be like some kind of acid trip, something that does not go unnoticed by Egosoft with the ship called "Albion *Skunk*" and at one point in the campaign the pilot says (after a weapon installation) ... "The Skunk seems to be really working now". Need I say more ?
