THIS GAME SCORES [*0* | 1] = ~25% (0%-50%)(Might even only be 1of4, but I haven't seen enough of the game to judge.)I only looked at this game for about 20 minutes (free X weekend). Maybe (or maybe not) it has strong value in the simulation and other aspects, but I wouldn't play long enough to find out:The graphics engine seems to be from 2005: The default settings (which are medium) have very low FPS on my otherwise fluid-gaming-experience PC (It's hard to overburden this thing.), but this seems to even be the "engine programmer beginner mistake" that Deus Ex: Invisible War had before its first patch: Depending on how burdened the engine (e.g. depending on where you look), the motions will lag behind the mouse by 100 ms or something, where they would have been immediate in other games if I had cranked things up enough to cause low FPS. Even the graphics in space are not smooth with the default medium settings. Again, this machine is almost always completely smooth in the hundreds of games I played. The game's engine is the problem.The voice acting is very obviously amateur stuff. Which is a slight insult to amateurs nowadays, if the indie gaming scene is any indication.The field-of-view when walking around is much too narrow, and PCGW[pcgamingwiki.com] says that there's no way to fix this. Egosoft: FAIL.The videos and the game itself are much too bright on my machine. I know the look, I've seen it in "Witcher 2", too. What's going on here: The screen I played this with has linear gamma, which is a complete exception. All screens you buy in media stores (Where I got mine, too.) have a gamma of about 0.56 (1/1.8), meaning that the middle brightness (e.g. gray) is darker than intended, while white and black are exactly like they should be. The reason that most screens are like this is historic. E.g. all the WWW is designed too bright (in the middle brightness range) because all screens back then had this gamma.Now I happened to accidentally buy a screen with linear gamma [Not using it any more, have a big SmartTV right in front of me these days.] which shouldn't be sold in consumer stores, not without a warning. When I got home and discovered this, I stupidly used Windows calibration to bend everything back into shape, which worked well (partly because DTP is my job). But some very few games do not work with such extra color adjustments, and "X Rebirth" happens to be such a game. The result is not just something that's too bright, but the overall colors and brightness are just broken in half, glued back together, then verbally abused, abandoned on the roadside, soaked by rain, gone into hypothermic shock, returned home, recovered a bit, then beat up by a rabid dentist, then photographed. Anyway, this is clearly an engine problem since almost all games I have do not have this problem, and I do focus on 3D 1st person games which, as you know, have a bunch of rendering effects layered on top of each other. Again, the game could be good on some levels, but I am not willing to fight to get to those. The game is two years old and looks like it's ten years old.

												I've wanted to love this game since before it was released. Following the horrible reviews, I put it away and played other games. I knew Egosoft was going to get around to making it better and all I had to do was wait.  Well last month, I decided the wait was over. I loaded the game up, created a new campaign start and off I went.There are a couple of good things about the game. The ship, station and general space travel graphics are pretty nice. And that's about it.The Bad:Graphics for people are repetitive and worthy of something released circa 2005. Maybe earlier. The Skunk should have been more welcoming. As is, you have a cockpit that amounts to a cutscene to sit down, a ramp, and a crew quarters that really doesn't do any justice to the game.You can only really fly the Skunk. I know this was planned from the early days, but there are not enough modifications or modification types to keep the Skunk fresh. It gets really boring, really fast. Just a few small tweaks and that would've not been a problem.Trading is confusing. Only really big ships can trade but there is no real tutorial on how the whole system is supposed to work. Honestly, I have better things to do with my gaming time than doing extensive research on how to perform a basic task. A task that should be obvious.The dialog and story are pretty horrid. Some of the quests are still buggy as of the 4.0 release. I remember reading about the Energy Cell transfer being bugged in one of the missions. I ran across one where my carge ship would only sell a handful of Energy Cells at a time. It took me about two hours for the ship to dock, sell 6-10 energy cells, undock, fly around the sector, dock, sell 6-10 energy cells...Combat is boring. I've come across enemy ships that just sit there while I pound on them and still others that die quickly while reciting the same old threats. When the enemy ships do present a challenge, it is usually because you have so many of them pounding on you that your shields get depleted fast. Conclusion:This could have been a great game. This SHOULD have been a great game. As is, the earlier X3 games run circles around this one. I hate to be that guy that looks backwards, but I just cannot look past all of the shortcomings that X: Rebirth has. Stick with X3: Terran Conflict or Albion Prelude. That or wait to see if Star Citizen lives up to all of its hype.

												First off, I have a lot more hours than steam shows into this game. I play offline at work with no internet. I probably have closer to 100 hrs or more into this game.Short version: The game is great. It's a lot of fun. You can easily and happily sink many hours into it and still have not experienced half of what this massive game has to offer. The possibilities are seemingly endless. With that said, this game does have its down falls(mentioned below), some pretty annoying. But nothing bad enough to earn this game the rating it currently has. It is well worth the base price. If it's on sale, you should jump on it.Long Version:As it has been stated this game had a very rough start. That is long over with. The game isn't broke. Its much much better now.I'll start with the good...To start, I own all of the X games, as I got them all in a bundle. I have not played any of the previous titles. I tried X3 but I found it to be incredibly incredibly frustrating to learn and a little ugly/dissappointing in graphics next to this one. So I put it down and came straight to X: Rebirth. With that said, I can't accurately compare it to any of the previous X titles. However I can say, the X games have a nasty reputation for being super hard to learn and not holding your hand along the way. X: Rebirth is a deep game, it is harder than the average game to learn to play. You will need to do your fair share of tutorial vids and googling along the way. But it is SO MUCH better than X3. I picked it up fairly quickly. It is not nearly as frustrating to learn as X3. That for me is a major plus. What I really love about this game are the possibilities, depth, and the sandbox like atmosphere. You can follow the main story, you can turn it off and do a great many of things, from different odd jobs, you can specialize in things like transporting/trading a huge number of different goods, bounty hunting, smuggling, passenger transport, policing/patrolling, be an evil space pirate(scan, hijack, loot, hack, pillage, sabotage, and destroy every thing you come across), Build massive space stations and create a HUGE and extremely profitable empire, engage in gigantic space battles worthy of a Star Wars movie, grow a fleet of ships or have multiple fleets, upgrade and mod your ship and ships in your fleet, etc.. the list goes on. That is what makes this game such a great experience for me. Now the game as great as it is, has some pretty major downfalls that are pretty ill recieved. First off, and possibly worst.. (You probably already know) You only get the one ship. That's a bummer. I had hopes of being able to buy and garage a huge inventory of different ships. Upgrade them, customize them, mod them, etc.. This game doesn't have that. You can buy a ton of ships.. but you will not be piloting them. You will be hiring captains and pilots to do that for you and then you will order them to do your bidding. It would have been so much cooler to be able to personally pilot a huge freighter and transport/smuggle goods all by yourself. Or deck out a wicked fast/agile little fighter ship to wreak havoc in battle. Or captain a huge battleship and command a fleet of fighters in battle. Maybe go on the hunt for special/legendary ships... But no you just get the one ship. Now you can customize the ship by changing the cockpit configuration. You can buy new weapons, upgrade them, upgrade the engines, shields, software, scanner, etc. And then you can find and buy mods to use on your weapons to improve and/or alter their performance. This is probably the biggest downfall of this game for me. The next biggest thing is, stations.. They are EXTREMELY bland and feel very unfinished to me. Every station you step onto is identicle to the last one. There are a couple of different variations that very mildly change them up.. but for the most part they are pretty much identical. They also feel incredibly lifeless. There are few NPC's on most of them (anywhere between 4 to 15(maybe)). Those NPC's stand or sit in one place, they do not walk or move. They don't work on anything or operate anything. If you go into a bunk room, they will all just be sitting on their beds or leaning against a wall not talking.. or doing any moving aside from blinking and maybe looking around. As often as you have to go onto stations the devs should have put more care into them and done something to make the process a lot more interesting.The next thing, the NPC's and the whole smalltalk thing.. This is annoying and kind of dumb in my opinion. You can engage in smalltalk with the NPC's and if you perform well you can get special little benefits from them like a personal or station discount, told where to find a good job applicant, etc. However the only way to engage in this smalltalk is to wait around in a populated area like a bunk room and wait for one of them to talk. Sometimes it happens quick.. Sometimes you'll wait 10 - 15 minutes and not hear a peep. The things they talk about are annoying as well.. as you have about 3 -4 (maybe more or less) different conversation topics. When responding to them you have to stop a little sliding bar at the right time to "peform" in the conversation well, their responses to you have nothing to do with the conversation, instead they compliment or insult you based on how good of a talker you are lol. If you do this a couple times good enough then you can get access to the discounts or you can continue if you give them a gift. Also this improves or hurts your reputation with whatever faction the NPC belongs to. You will find yourself doing this a lot trying to get station discounts,  trade offer updates, better vendor prices, or whatever else. There are mods that help with this like Trade Agents Forever.. but there is still no way to completely avoid or get around it. This whole little mechanic is something that should have been completely scrapped, replaced, or whatever. It gets super old, super repetitive, and just annoying.This is almost a non issue now due to the mod Capital Ship Bridges... But when you dock on capital ships, they have no bridge. They are all identical for the most part and just have the docking area. The mod makes it to where they have a bridge and a couple other small areas you can check out. The only reason I mention this is because the devs should have at least done what the mod does. Not only that, they should have made a somewhat unique bridge to each type of capital ship. Not a huge deal.. but just something that would have have helped with immersion.The last thing that somewhat bothers me.. Sometimes when in a battle with small ships the AI seems a little wonky when watching the other ships. This is not a big deal, doesn't affect game play, doesn't break the game, just something a little silly looking. But every once in a while its like a ship will just stop midspace and rotate itself around a different direction and continue on. Instead of more realistically keeping the ship in motion heading forward and either looping back or banking around. I know space flight is probably nothing like flight on earth.. but we probably all imagine the flight mechanics to look similar to(or more intense/agile than) flying a jet, banking around, loops, cork screws, etc.. Not just coming to stop, slowly turning a different direction, then going on lol. Again its not a big deal, its just kind of a mood killer sometimes.. you'll be feeling like Luke Skywalker zooming around in an X-Wing after a baddie in a Tie Fighter.. then that baddie.. just stops midspace for something that looks as awkward and slow as a 3 point turn for.There are some other things I could probably mention that would make the game better. But these things are the biggest and would make what is now a great experience into an outstanding and amazing experience. Obviously(saying that), I still think highly of the game and do not feel these issues ruin the game or make it not worth the price.

ber 5, 2016
												In every way possible this game screams terrible.The interface is terrible, the voice acting is terrible, the combat is terrible, the trading is terrible.The interface and combat relies heavily on drone useage and assistance. But can you launch them all with one push of a button and have them attack your target? NO! you have to launch them all 1 by one going through the main menu by hitting enter and going through a set of menus while you are under fire and a sitting duck.The voice acting: So many times I have heard the mis-prouncieacion of simple words that end up in a sentance that makes no sense what so ever. For example; When I finished an escort mission the pilot of the other ship said "You came though" instead of "You came threw". Then there is the total butchery of the word "Quadrent" it is pronounced "Quandrent", umm what? Trading (or empting your cargo bay if you are full, which it dont even let you know about) you must find every single docking hub on a station that has a merchent that buys that perticular item. There is also a limmit to how many missles you can cary which it also does not let you know if you are full up on.Afterburners require a shield drain, there are missions that send you into combat in hasardus arieas (I wouldn't complain about that if not for the shield drain ABs and the crappy HUD that shows only things that are very close to you). When you die in combat (no matter how good you are it WILL happen) you are forced to go through 2, yes TWO load screens just to re-load from the latest save. The autosave is 100% ♥♥♥♥ as it only saves when you undock from a station, and it requires a full pause of the game. Not like other newer games of this age that do it in the backround and can be ignored. It's the same with any manual save.Three years after release and it still is lacking in any from of being 'user friendly'. If you like a nonstop punishing amount of frustration, then you might like this 'game'. Otherwise buy anything else, just not this.

content:
15
Positives:Galaxy that feels alive. Yep, you can easily see that most of the ships are there just to create an illusion. Still, it's the first game since Freelancer that creates this impression;Gorgeous visuals;Exploring the galaxy, at least for the first time, is really enjoyable expirience. Lots of things to see. Lots of effort was put into creating beatiful enviroment and enormous space stations, that are full of small details, animated pieces, traffic around them etc;Highways are a great idea and fun to use;Lots of stuff to do: mining, trading, completing random missions, salvaging stuff, station building, trying to squeeze into existing production lines at NPC conttolled systems etc;Some neat options to approach these tasks. I like the idea of drones, where some are controlled by the player, some are controlled by AI. I like weapons as well, they are fun to use and easy to understand. Long range scanner is fun to use;You can explore interiors of space stations, though, to be honest, the feature could've been implemented much better;Your fleet is controlled by employed stuff, which feels much better than it used to be in older games, where it was controlled by faceless and voiceless AI;I kinda like the idea of having one unique main upgradeable ship and your second pilot in it throughout the most of the game;Some great mods available here at steam workshop. Some make the game a bit more approachable, some make it more immersive;Basic controls and main part of the interface are easy to learn and pretty well refined.Negatives:There's only one ship you can pilot. On top of that, though you can get up from pilot's seat and look around, its interior design is subpar at best. Same goes to capital ships if you happen to land on them;Some horrible NPC design, subpar voice acting and scriptwriting that is downright laughable at times;Campaign itself feels extremly cheap, characters barely interact with each other and overall it feels like those full-fledged but amature expansion mods from something like Skyrim, that are done with limited budget and assets available;Trading and station building interface is awkward to understand and operate, at least for a newcomer;Limited control over your fleet. It's not hard to control your fleet and issue commands, but the feature could've been implemented way better;AI often don't react well to what's going on, ships get stuck in stuff, which is unfortunate, but not unexpected from a game of this scope;Some things about mission design, rewards etc feel loose. Overall, lack of polish is evident in those aspects of the game.Overall, I think the game deserves at least giving it a shot and you can get it pretty cheap at steam sales. I've enjoyed playing it, even though it's not really my thing, genre-wise. There's nothing criminally wrong with Rebirth for it to recieve such a low rating. Though the game is not even remotely perfect, its shorcomings could be looked over since the stuff in which it succeeds is really good and unique.

y 8, 2014
												I'm hammer326, and I'm here to clear the air about this game in a lot of ways.First and foremost, note that EVERY LAST ONE of the highest rated reviews bashing this game, even armed with a few good points, have not clocked more than 13 hours in a game that's supposed to take you well over 100 to see even a fraction of it. Let that mean what it will to you.That said, I actually agree with a lot of criticisms. This game's NPCs are horrendously aged to the point where it looks like they're suffering from too long a day at H.R. Giger's house. Walking in Stations is as barely there as EVE, but at least here we have modders and devs sincerely interested in developing that further. If that is a deal breaker for you, so be it, but a lot of the other big issues with the game have actually been fixed, and well.  This thesis is bolstered by two outside sources: 1: My dear friend Waddy with his wonderfully realist perspective on the game, which I encourage you all to take 10 minutes and watch: 


YouTube™ Video: X Rebirth - My Thoughts After 120hrs 

			Views: 72,815		

			X Rebirth - While we wait for a few fixes I wanted to give my impressions and thoughts about the game after playing 120hrs. I try to be as honest as I can about my experience with the game.		

2: An anonymous associate here on steam who helped shed a lot of light on all things X:rebirth. He put the state of affairs quite well in a recent conversation- "You have 2 overall options in XR, trade and fight. fight, in one way or another, is functioning. Your ships can now fire back, finally. Trade is working again. You can order ships to refuel their fuel cargo. I hope they will extend the commands, it's a necessity. Stations are working, but they are still bugged alot. So this part of the game needs to be fixed ASAP. Ofc, the graphics are quite nice. I loved the atmosphere since I started. The main story isn't finished yet, it was just a "pilot episode" so we will see more of that too."With all analyses put forth and a fair amount of hours clocked between the three of us, we unanimously agree that X:Rebirth, as Waddy said oh so well, "is good if you're okay with bugs." Some people don't mind spending $50 and watching a game progressively get better and better, which Egosoft have done consistently, for those who don't know. If I had to find a gaming company less likely to ♥♥♥♥ you as a customer, it'd be a very hard decision to make.  If you aren't into paying that much, that's your right, and I would wait on it to get cheaper which won't be long. No, not because it's bad and broken and horrible, but that's just how game prices work.Overall this is not remotely near the 32/100 it is stained with on Metacritic, and its butthurt fanbase have desperately tried and even succeeded at convincing a LOT of people otherwise. I hope you take this review into consideration when deciding whether to buy the game, I encourage discussion in the comments below. Until then, fly safe.

content:
er 2, 2013
												X Rebirth is both a step forward and a step backward for the X Series.  An all-new game engine provides for gorgeous vistas and a truely open world, where you can, with enough patience, fly from one place to almost any other place you can see (and some which you can't).  The underlying simulation promises the same degree of complexity seen in previous games, while the simplified user interface makes the most basic aspect of the game, flight and space dogfighting, easier and more accessible.  However, that same new interface lacks the fine grained control over player owned ships and stations that X players have come to expect.  Add to that a very rocky launch, with arguably every aspect of the game being broken in some way, and it's clear that X Rebirth is not quite ready for mass consumption.  Fortunately, the dev team is working tirelessly on bringing the game up to speed, and the modding community is plugging away intently adding features that are either broken or perceived as missing.  Overall, X Rebirth is a flawed gem, not yet ready for the average gamer, but stands as an excellent platform for the next generation of X games, and, with the dedicated developers whom Egosoft has proven themselves to be, will hopefully soon be the X game we've always wanted, and worthy of a spot in every spaceie's Steam Library.

18, 2016
												I played X, X2, X3 and I really wanted to like this game.What I get from the forums and good reviews is: it is a X-Game in a smaller universe with good remote control of your ships/stations. You are more an operator of a fleet of drones than a pilot.But the first time when I got the game and now the 2nd time when I really tried to get into is: graphics are way worse then X3-Terran Conflict (taste) sounds feel cheap compared to X3 (could be they are even the same, don't know, it is just a feeling of "cheap") I hate the highways. Instead of navigating through sectors you just find a highway entry and let go. Fun... not. I just don't understand the logic behind the interface, in X3 it was - after some time - very clear and intuitive. You just knew where you had to look for certain commands. I don't like the fights. They feel cheap and I don't see for example my laser connect with the target. I don't like that I have to search each station I dock with for chests or I will lose a lot of money (at least for the first hours it is a lot of money. I don't like the look of the characters. Is that game really 10 years old? Oh, no, it is not. So why? I found no bugs, but bad mission descriptions: it seemed the mission was fullfilled but the game did not recognize it, in reality, the mission was a complete other one than I thought. I was not the only one with that problem, I found other guys in the forum with the same problem in these missions.I could go on but you will already have understood, that game is not what I like.I am sure this is not a bad game. I am sure for some guys it is a very good game.But it is not a good game for me and so I can not recommend it. (And I am really sorry about it)

content:
, 2014
												First I have to say that this is the only game in the "X"Series that I have not tested, and this was by choice for lack of time to truly give full attention to the game.After reading most of the comments about the game, I saw that 90% of the comments were negative...it wasn't really encouraging, but since I have faith in Egosoft, I bought it anyway. For the life of me, I can't really find anything truly wrong with the game.I haven't experienced the game crashes that others were complaining about, and I didn't get the impression that the game was unfinished in any way nor that it was still in beta form.So for those people that were stating that the game was in Beta form or should have been an early access game, you obviously don't know the game your dealing with. The game is finished and complete. So either the people making those types of comments don't really know what their doing when it comes to testing or they really don't know the game and the history of the "X" series games.Most of the complaints that I read were from the very first weeks of the game being released. Egosoft always has patches out for their games within 6 to 12 hours of release if there were final tweeks needed or even fixes to correct game breaking bugs, and all it takes is going to the website and downloading the patches.On the other hand, Steam might not have the updates uploaded nearly as quickly, but thats a steam thing and not Egosofts fault.I have to admit that after being an "X" series veteran since X-beyond the frontier and having been a member of the Dev Team from or since 1999, this game is a beast all its own. And seeing as I got it from Steam, I don't really have a ready manual right in my hands to help me along with some of the commands and some of the other facets of the game.Piloting the ship is interesting, and I like the return of the cockpits, I was one of the mates that missed them when they were left out...so KUDOS!! for the return of the cockpits.On the other hand, I really don't care for the way that the character walks through the station. I'd personally like a 2nd or 3rd person view of the character, on the other hand...I really might have gone a different way with the modeling of the NPC's on the station. I'd be willing to go as far as saying that if something was rushed in the game, it was the characters...I do however miss the POV look around. It was helpful but not a hands down needed feature.There are a lot of things that are different in the game. Some of them facinating and other that could be infuriating...like trying to track down a specific person in the campain...but after I completely understood the nature of the game, it wasn't all that hard to find the others and it started to become fun.So reading all of the negative reviews...I took a look back at them...intersting that their near or on the same day...and probably about the same time...but thats another subject for a different type of forum. I also noted that the same people that were complaining that the game was unfinished and crashed a lot had as many hours as 600+ logged playing the game...thats not a number that denotes there are "...lots of bugs and crashes"...and..."the game is a lost cause..."Since I've only played the game for a cursory period of 3 hours or so, I don't really know much about the game play. I do know that I haven't encountered any of the bugs and or glitches that people say they have encountered...then again...I've only read where one or two people recently had trouble running the game recently as of the latest patch on 05/20/2014 and the bulk were more than a year old...so I'm guessing that many of the game breaking bugs have been fixed and dealt with harshly.I do have to say, with any game, if your PC doesn't have the "kung fu" to handle the game, its not going to play or it won't play right if at all. So perhaps the people that are complaining about the game are running them on machines that truly can't handle the program...I'm not there...so I really don't know.I myself am running a 3rd Gen Phenom 6 core...I run 2 and sometimes 3 3D modeling programs at the same time like 3DS Max and Maya while using photoshop and fireworks in tandem with adobe premier Pro, and I have no slowdown in performance...so my machine can handle the game and then-some...but someone else might not have a PC that can handle the game like mine can or anyone else that plays the game without problems.My advise to people that want to buy this game...1).  Make sure your PC can handle the game...graphically and processor wise as well memory wise.  Take the time to look at your machines specs and figure out if your PC can actually handle the game...as a tester (alpha and beta...and not just for Egosoft)  you should always make sure your PC can handle the programs you are running. Sometimes a system that can not handle the game will act funny while running it...that is IF it runs the game at all.2).  If you've played the previous games and are expecting the same type of game...Don't...its not the same game...as I said before...its a beast all its own.3).  Take the time to get used to the way the game plays. If you have a joystick, take the time to adjust it to the game...all buttons and movements etc. If you play using mouse and keyboard, get used to the way everything responds...learn the controls.Perhaps I got really lucky and I can run the game because it likes my machine, but I really haven't found the glitches and bugs that everyone else is/was complaining about. My one and only complaint is that I can not find a physical copy of the game and had to get this through Steam. Its a preference to be honest, and I like having the physical copy on hand to make multiple instances of the game on my PC...its a tester thing.All in all...I like the game. Its an interesting viewpoint for the game and an interesting switch up in the game world.I will not however recommend this game to someone that does not have the time to invest in the game play. Its not a casual instant gratification game and never will be. So if you're looking for instant gratification, look for another game. Re-Birth takes time to play and it needs a good deal of time invested to truly get anywhere in the game...thats the way the game is designed.Think - Trade - Fight - Build...and one more...re-learn what you have learned about the "X" series of games...You're not flying with the gate system anymore.Warchild - aka - (/\)archild

er 25, 2013
												With the new advent of the series in X:rebirth, the game takes an interesting twist on the micromanage extravaganza that was X2, X3 and its subsiquent expansions, with having AI take control of much of the detail work.  That said, the idea is sound but the implementation is (so far anyway) leaving much to be desired in terms of game crippling bugs, updates the wipe the stations clean of units or resources needed to keep the fluid economy functioning, ship AI flat out refusing to function as its supposed to, and faulty quest progression linkages.  However even with these annoying bugs (that to thier credit have been squashing with acceptable haste, maybe not for some unfortunately), the game handles very smoothly, the environments are INCREDIBLY detailed and 'alive', what may seem like a simple station, when you get into the nuts and bolts of the woodwork of the world, there is a level of detail on such a huge scale, its simply incredible.egosoft did a great job on the design aspect of the worlds structure, with a somewhat lackluster series of testing the AI scripting before release, which honestly is the only serious drawback (for now anyway like i said, its being worked on).

content:
ber 9, 2014
												I am a huge fan of the X series, having played hundreds of hours in both X3:TC and X3:AP, however I was very dissapointed with Rebirth on releaes.Game had an absolutely terrible launch, completely broken and buggy, but coming from a small studio I suppose its to be expected. However its been almost a year since the game has launched and Egosoft has been steadily updating the game and improving upon it. With the 2.50 patch which is currently in open beta, I feel the game is finally reached a point where it is of a an acceptable release quality. The game runs very smooth now, and the AI is much better than launch. Bug fixes and many new features have been added, such as small / medium shipyards, adding shields to all capital ships, new squad management hierarchy for commanding your fleets, ect ect. One of my biggest gripes about the game, was how easy it was. With the addition of difficulty levels and a complete combat rebalance in patch 2.0, you can no longer solo capital ships with the base ship. Even a small swarm of fighters can overwhelm you if your not careful. The game is steadily moving in the right direction, although I still feel the universe and number of sectors is too small compared to previous X games. Also the skunk still is not as customizable as it should be , considering its the only ship you can fly.Overall, I like what egosoft has done with the game, and am excited to see what kind of future paid expansions or DLC content may bring to the table, its just a shame it took them so long to make the game fun and playable.

												I wish there was a "Maybe" button for the recommendation.- Visually - Appealing.- Control - Lacking, but slowly getting there.- Trade/Build - Difficult with current control scheme, and still ocasionally buggy.- Fight - Playership is still a bit overpowered, and "dogfighting" is still a bit of a "meh" But I do have moments of just pure  enjoyment destroying a squadron of fighters. (Something that has gotten easier with the ability to switch targets)- Fight - Player Owned ships are still a bit buggy but if you can get them to work theyre useful.- Storyline - Just...broken. I like where they are coming from, but it seems like the game assumes you know whats going on and who is doing what and what has happened in the intervening years between the Terran Conflict and the shut down of the gate network.I am a longtime egosoft fan starting with X: BTF, and I was among the masses more than looking forward to this game and claiming I would be disappearing from the world at launch. Sadly, this didnt happen. Launch was a disaster, crashing and save game edit requirements being among the forefront of the issues. That being said however, Egosoft seems to be working hard to bring the game in line with a true "Release" quality build and, as always, the community is hard at work to mod whatever they want into the game as well as changing what they view as needing change.Hopefully with further support this game can come to be something closer to the anticipated game.To elaborate on my beginning notes - what I thought while playing it:(Just to get this out of the way) The single ship thing does bother me as I have gotten used to the previous titles ability to pilot whatever is available. However, I do like the attempt to make that single ship something worth upgrading - they just need to broaden the options beyond their simple Mk1 Mk2 Mk3 Mk4 setup."Player owned Ships" and their crew - Fortunately the ships are starting to respond properly (Especially with the mods available) and I do like the idea of hiring the "command" crew of the ship (I say that because i like to think the ship has more than 3 people on it, especially the bigger container ships and cruisers) and, while it does get tedious, it does play to the micromanager in me.- Trading is a bit of a pain, and while updates have been making it easier, I have been forced to turn to the community to make this something worth doing.-I have to say that despite any issues with control over the ships, once you get your warships into a fight its quite a sight (Given they attack what you want them to - i believe a recent update allowed for this) with the heavy beams against larger craft and chain guns against fighters.-Building stations can be a pain, while the idea of the construction ship being able to buy from merchants to get what it needs is nice, it never seems to work - especially in Devrise. Keep in mind that I do not believe you should be able to autopilot and have a station magically appear, I do like that there are so many materials needed and you have to work for your station. I just have an issue with the apparent "WE ARE BUYING THIS AND THIS AND THIS!!" not seeming to work with the NPCs.Now the storyline: You start off well enough. Random event leading to you getting embroiled in x and y story. However, as it progresses there are so many fragments and seeming skips in what you can tell Should be there and isnt that you get lost trying to figure out how you went from problem A to problem B and both being fixed with Solution C...yet not really. While i understand there is supposed to be an episodic nature to the game...where is the rest of the first episode? Again i still wish there was a Maybe button. I'm recommending this title with the note that it is still a work in progress and has a lot of potential, but if you do pick this up head straight for the modding forums as there are plenty of options to make this game more appealing.

												I cannot stand this game. I was a big fan of X3, and I'll admit that might have shaped my expectations. But I bought this thing when it was released fullying knowing it was going to be a different experience. I was fine with that.But here, in 2016, version 4.0, this game still sucks. It's not fun. In X3, people talk about a learning curve. When you first enter the game, it's pretty daunting and you really don't know what you're supposed to do. But the pieces are there for you to figure out. I see a station in the distance. I fly over. It has some stuff for sale. They seem to be producing it here (I can tell because of function of the station is in the name), so it's probably cheap. I buy some and continue on my way. I see another station. I fly over. They are buying this good for more than I paid for it! Profit! Other times, a station will have a red cross next to it. That means they will pay me to kill something. The game doesn't specifically tell you what to do, but the world is simple, and you can gradually start piling on the complexity by your own design,X:Rebirth is a convoluted mess. Stations are no longer stations, but big sprawling space cities with 20 different contact points you have to nose around to see if they offer any function whatsover. Chances are, there may be nothing worthwile to do in the entire city, so you have to move on somewhere else. Travel takes forever. Apparently SETA is back in the game, but its some mission reward (god knows what mission or where to start it), so you are forced to sit through a couple of hours of complete boredom before you can start to shape how your time is spent in this game. Instead of simplicity in design and presentation, X:Rebirth has caked on layer after layer of obstacles between me and what I'm trying to do. That means having to walk on stations and talk to ♥♥♥-ugly NPCs just to do basic interactions. That means having to fly around and scan things just to know if there is something being sold. That means having to look at a big, bulky 3D model of a cockpit just to have some basic HUD elements. I'm aware that mods can fix a lot of these complains. I'm aware that the game will probably seem less grating the more time I spend with it (though I don't think Yisha is going to get any more pleasant). But this is a $40 game and I have a life. I know I spent hundreds of hours in X3, but I could see where it was going pretty early on, even if I still had learning to do. I can't take it on faith that anything interesting is going to happen in X:Rebirth and I don't have to time or energy to find out.You have taken the Ubuntu of space sims and turned it into Microsoft Bob.

content:
er 24, 2013
												I picked up X: Rebirth on Steam based on the reputation of the earlier games. I like it, but it's rough. Like "released too soon" kind of rough. The graphics were done in DirectX 9.0c which have seemed dated for years now. With Windows XP losing support less than six months after it releases, coupled with their years-long release cycle why they chose to use it is baffling. (The answer is likely that the game was stuck in development hell for years and when the decision was made to use DIrectX 9.0c Windows XP had a few years to go. The upside is this is one of the few game developers known for major version updates on their games so a DirectX 11 isn't infeasible in a few years.The graphics themselves look decent in space scenes, and the cockpit is nice, but anything that involves people looks terrible. Human textures are stretched and blurry and quite simply poorly done. Movement of human characters looks rigid and with the poor textures it looks more like a game from the early 2000s if not late 1990s. Honestly those sections add so little to the gameplay itself why they decided to include a half-♥♥♥♥♥ station-side game is beyond me.The gameplay itself is enjoyable but in order to understand the free-fly mode one needs to have played the campaign as a tutorial and the campaign is buggy and does a poor job explaining what's going on. I spent an hour flying my ship looking for a place to dock with a station only to remember a passing remark about buying a hacking drone, which wasn't available for sale anywhere near me. Another 45 minutes later I'm finally able to perform the mission.A major annoyance is that X3: Reunion and its umpteen expansions made good use of my Saitek X52 HOTAS joystick. X: Rebirth, on the other hand, absolutely requires an XBox 360 controller (or maybe a DualShock clone). The game is hard-coded to assume there are two sticks and uses both of them extensively in gameplay. They've also coded XBox 360 symbols into the menus and dialogs that appear even if you don't use the controller. This would be understandable if it were intended to be cross-platform but Egosoft has announced they have no plans to release a console version. So, in short, the game plays like a crappy console port... but will never have a console release. (And also came at the tail end of a console generation if it were.) A good comparison is X3: Reunion is Wing Commander: Privateer to this game's Freelancer. They took a complex game with lots of controls and simplified it to a handful of buttons. Bear in mind I don't begrudge it entirely, I always found X3: Reunion too complex to get into for more than a few hours at a time.The voice acting is bad, plain and simple. The reasons are simple, too. The company is German and obviously didn't hire a native English speaker for voice acting and while they're faking an American accent their native accent slips through from time to time. (I'd dare say the voice actor for the co-pilot has a Slavic accent of some sort.) I know enough people who don't speak English natively but who have a better command of the language than many Americans (not difficult, honestly) but the decision not to hire even British voice actors for a game that has English as one of its primary audio languages is puzzling.Assuming Egosoft continues development despite poor reviews (not every game company is willing to do that) this would definitely be one of those games to be re-reviewed in, say, a year. I waited just over a month and many of the game-breaking bugs early reviewers had seen weren't there (so far). I could see this becoming a great game in a few years but without a major re-thinking of the controls to be more joystick friendly (for those who enjoy that) and a graphical overhaul - especially to the station side of the game - it could be a major flop on the order of the 2013 SimCity.﻿

												Okay, so I've put some pretty good time in to the game. First, don't buy this game if you get frustrated by frequent crashes and bugs. However, if you're willing to try out the different systems and explore a beautiful space universe, this game really is quite fun and addictive. Thus far, I started off by using the Long Range Scanner to pick up random items out in space in Freeplay mode. Apparently Campaign mode is horribly broken (it crashes constantly for me), so I've been learning the systems by trying them out and researching the forums and live streams. After collecting and selling junk, I upgraded my ship to where I felt comfortable attacking a Capital freighter. After many failures, I learned that having a TON of marines help. I began capturing and selling freighters for cash, and attempted to send one out to trade. It was very time consuming and unpleasurable to search for "trade deals". It was, however, fun to ride on the deck of the freighter, standing outside of my ship, while it tore off through space to destinations I commanded it to go. Eventually I decided to try for an Arawn, the biggest baddest Carrier in the game. Somehow after 10-15 tense minutes later, I captured one. I then tested out refueling theh ship for instant Jumps. It took the Arawn almost 2 hours to line up to the fuel dock, and then failed to load anything. At this point, none of my Capitals are able to load Jump fuel. Before I went back to the Dockyard, I saw another Arawn and decided to pounce on it. Three reloads later (due to my ship flying into the structure of it, among other bugs), I was able to capture another one! These sell for 50 mil apiece! My next endeavour is to learn to build my own stations, and continue raids into the Albion system to pilage and plunder freighters and super carriers. Amassing my wealth and building my blood Empire for the day that the game is fixed, playable without near paranoid saves, and as fun as I know it can be. Give it a few months if you're not THAT in to this genre. But if you're starved for the mere experience of exploring in your own ship, and testing some fun systems in the mean time, then I'd recommend picking it up. Hope this helps someone!

Well, you can play allready but its like stuffing red-hot nail into your ♥♥♥♥. V1.18 / 1.19Beta. Expect a "tech demo" of visuals at best with current version/vanilla.X-games have a HUGE community and mod-base, Rebirth is no different and theres even a public-beta to take part in and give the devs some feedback that they actually take. Theres also some of the most talented modders out there involved and the game is very mod-friendly in every way, even more with the new engine.X-games were the closest thing to a "single-player EVE-online" there was. Previous title: X3AP after its brutal learning-curve is stupidly awasome, twice with mods. X:rebirth is far from its predesessor but i have no doubts it will be even better then the previous titles were, however right now the ONLY reason to buy it is to believe in the devs and give them support. I believe in them and i bought the game, if you like space sims, Freelancer, Free Space, I-war 1 & 2, etc you will like this.Giving a "full review" at this point is meaningless, there are so many changes been made and so many more to be made that i'd need to update the review weekly. Egosoft has promised a lot and by the looks of it those will be fullfilled too. Dont expect to get the best of it yet, give it time and let it become the best there is, cause us space-sim fans dont have many to choose from.

content:
ry 7, 2016
												I wanted so bad to like this game.I also wanted to give a brief synopsis as to why this game didn't do it for me but that didn't work out, so there's a TL;DR at the end.I've been a huge fan of everything that Egosoft has done for the last decade, the amount of hours I put into the X series since X2 has probably been the reason my plots for world domination haven't come into affect yet (at least that's my excuse), so when I saw all the concept art and everything promised by egosoft, I was real excited. I tried this game on release and it WAS as bad as everybody said it was. It was terrible, it crashed non-stop, the AI was painful, but those are the only two things Egosoft have seemed to improve on since release. Against my better judgement, I read the steam reviews and saw everyone saying to "give it another chance. You love egosoft. They love you." And I did. And I regret it. Here's why:- This whole game is the embodiment of "half-♥♥♥♥♥." I will reference the human models and movement, the dialogue, the transience of the dialogue, the plot, the textures, the trading. It was like they took an idea, threw some things together and said to each other "This kind of looks like that! Let's use it!"- The ship (singular. That's right, you get one ship that has been described from the get go as a "piece of junk" and they're not lying) doesn't feel nice to fly. It's responsive, sure, but it's just not "immersive", a concept that the creators obviously tried very hard with in regards to everything else.... *elbow nudges* - The menus never stop being confusing. the maps aren't insightful, maybe this one part is immersive in the fact that it looks like somebody designed it and never decided to change it. It's horrible. - The AI is still mostly terrible, but it's just not terrible enough that when you're not looking, it can do what you asked it to do. When it comes to your ship though, it's not even worth using the autopilot command, because it was obviously designed by Japanese Engineers during World War 2, you're going head-first into whatever it is you'd like to go to.- Design-wise, the ships look great. This is something I always appreciated about the X-series. They had a wide range of ships, from god awful (Xenon - Teladi) to sleek and sexy (Terran - Terran. (Maybe also the paranid.)) However the textures and aliasing issues let them down if you ever want to admire them. My system is more than capable, so don't let there be confusion there. I have a team of several hamsters working around the clock to make sure I can boost my graphics as much as I want, but the game was having too many issues with this. Your co-pilot's (Who is so unlikable I literally forgot her name on purpose) hair was either having some graphical issues, or it was super cool and futuristic and could change between red highlights to jet-jet-black to white, all in the space of several miliseconds. - The sound design is awful. Awful. This was something Egosoft didn't pay too much attention to previously, as many of the looped sounds were 2-3 seconds long and it was obvious they were just looped samples, but it wasn't obvious enough to bug me. Now in stations, there are many more of them, and you hear them all the time, and the transition is so obvious Steve Reich would be disgusted. The music in the highways bugs me the most, and oh boy, let's talk about the highways.- One of the things I liked about the X games was that they were at your own pace. If you wanted fast paced, you could have that (kind of), if you wanted to slow it down and be a trader, you could do that as well. But with the removal of the time accelerator, this absolutely awful "Boost-in-exchange-for-shields" addition and the highways, it was like they were trying to make the game more interesting all the time, but again, it was done in a severely half-♥♥♥♥♥ fashion, so none of it is fun, none of it is immersive and it makes you feel like an idiot when you drop out of the highway because your mouse was a centimeter from the center of your HUD. It's a bad minigame, with no obvious parameters for collisions with other ships, the lighting from the systems your travelling through often obscuring whatever it is that is in front of you. Of all the things I didn't like in this game, I didn't like these the most. My best example of this would be audiosurf, except the music you're listening to is start menu music from a low-budget game from 1998 that lasts 3 seconds, looping over and over but not even perfectly, so the tempo is off, and you can't really see the bricks you're meant to hit and not meant to hit, and your rent is late again and your parents really want you to visit for the weekend. - The human models haven't been upgraded since X2. Remember, when you first meet Saya Kho onboard the Express and you were like "WOAH, what the F**K is that thing!", well that's what they're still like now. The textures have barely even been upgraded, the movement is so non-human it's actually unnerving, the "guards" that you see inside stations have weapons that look like they cost 1.49 in your nearest pound shop. The dialogue is abysmal, everyone is talking like they are trying to record an automated message for EA customer support, a lot of it makes no sense in regards to where it came from and why they said it, much like EA customer support. Maybe this is art, and Egosoft are trying to describe a future far from now, in which the masses have been silenced and free will has been an illusion for so long, humans aren't even good at feigning it anymore... Probably not though.And that's as brief as I could make this rant. Wow. Look... Don't buy this game. I believe as a community that still cares about good space Sims, if we all collectively believe that this never existed, there's still hope. Egosoft, if you ever get around to reading this, please just let us go back to the way things were. I miss you. TL;DR: Not bad. 7/10

												I bought this game a while ago so I could rate it negatively for featuring only one ship you can fly, but ended up playing a bit.The greatest flaw with this game, as of the time I've been playing, are the limitations in content. There are never enough options in regards to everything you can imagine, except maybe station variety. On the other hand, much of the game's main features are now easier to handle, without losing much complexity, which is quite a feat in the gaming industry.Cons- Very few weapon and equipment options. 3 types of shield, 4 types of engines, 10 different missile models, about 6-7 different weapons, 3 scan upgrades, a few licenses, 3 or 4 different software, some cockpit configurations, and thats all you can buy to upgrade THE ONLY SHIP YOU GET TO FLY THE ENTIRE GAME. - You can get money quickly by farming lockboxes in Nirins treaty. There are plenty of other opportunities to break the game by farming resources real quickly.- Little ship variety. At the capital shipyard in Home of Light there are only 4 XL models available to buy LOLOLOLOLOLOLOLOLLLLLLLLLL- YOU CAN ONLY FLY ONE SHIP- Combat is less fun and rewarding than in previous games- Pointless and repetitive station interiors. Has first person exploration but no combat. - Long loading times (although no loading time between sectors)- Crafting is limited. Got little use for most items. - Trading ships have a deplorable small cargo capacity- No SETA, but as you upgrade your shields, your turbo capacity will increase, making traveling over long distances faster.- Your co-pilot is there, but useless- Cannot fly in a fleet, no SETA means you have to keep the pace of your slowest ship, which makes traveling in a group *VERY* tedious- Number of sectors is very small- No stock market- Bad voice acting, as always- Missions are still very repetitive and do not feel like they are part of the rest of the game, and are there just because of the player, which breaks immersion. They do not feel like contracts or mercenary work. The "bandit leaders" and "raiders" only exist within the context of a mission, they are never really there, harassing traders and stuff. It also has the mission variety one would expect from a sandbox game: very poor.- Aim assist won't work against some ships. I dont know whether this is a bug or intended behavior.- An MK4 shield costs almost 4kk on your ship, but a capital ship shield is only 300k. This is clearly an example of how certain parts of the market were not integrated to the economy at all.- You cannot combine weapons anymore. You can only use them one at a time. - You cannot build stations wherever you want anymore. There are predetermined places to build them now.- Soundtrack is nice but repetitive- You can hire engineers, but they won't repair your ships. They do nothing at all. You have to keep sending your ships back to the shipyard to be repaired. You dont even have the repair laser anymore.- Exploration consists of finding lockboxes. The thrill of finding hidden stations and rare ships has diminished.Pros- Graphics are reasonable- The cockpit view adds to immersion- Trade is said to be oversimplified, but I dont think so. Some parts of it are actually better than in previous games. Less micromanagement without eliminating a lot of the complexity. Trade menu also helps a lot.- Ships are dedicated to carrying certain types of goods, adding to complexity.- Mining is more complex, interesting, and can be fully automated.- Supply chains are bigger, more logical, and more complex- Interface is ridiculously better than the ones from previous titles- Drones are a good addition- Commanding other ships and fleets is easier now- Bulletin board gathers information on all missions available in a region.- It is much easier to grab floating cargo- Mission rewards are more balanced than in X3, but, as I've mentioned before, there are other ways of farming money.- Hull damage no longer directly affects ship speed.- Boarding is easier, more functional- Docking in a station or capital ship is easier - Station composition is improved by modularization. No more complex hubs!- There are now weapon mods, a minor feature that lets you customize what little number of different models are available to you.4/10 as of Home of Light DLC and 4.0 update, would buy it again just to give it a thumbs down.

y 24, 2016
												 X Rebirth. Lets get something clear, this is a vastly different direction from X3:TC/AP. Only three systems that you can visit, but this game does several things that the previous games do not.1: Space is big.With the previous games, each system could easily be crossed in a minute or two before reaching jumpgates. In this particular game, each region is massive. The stations are huge and modular, can fight back, and can be precision disabled instead of outright destroyed easily. You can find ships by the hundreds, making space feel less empty. Speaking of stations...2: Improving infrastructure is no small deal.In the last game, all you needed to do to build a station is buy a prefab set, hire or buy a ship large enough to carry the parts, and just plop it down anywhere you like. Here, you can't just build anywhere you like, which is more realistic. Plus, once you plce down a blueprint, you have to obtain all the materials needed to build the structure. In addition, after you build the station, you can expand on it further using the same methods. Every station is going to be dependant on others for one thing or another, you can't just build a megaplex that takes care of itself. Unfortunately, this leads to some problems in the storyline.3: You can't do everything yourself.You only have one ship, and its more a fighter then a cargo ship. Granted, this is a bit of a downer as being able to fly any ship you like was one of the more enjoyable parts of prior games. Fleets are also fairly small and mostly freighters instead of fleets of destroyers. Managing your fleets isn't simple, and too clunky for my tastes.4: The economy...Is a joke. Trading isn't easy and can't be automated, and isn't profitible in the end. Your best bet is to turn to piracy/bounty hunting and jack freighters. There hasn't been any other decent source of money.In the end, you can't build up to be a force that matches the major governments. If you dive into the lore, the limited number of systems makes sense, and is a bit worrying if you really think about this. This is mostly a very clunky game that has been too long in development and doesn't nearly match the standards of todays games. Maybe if it was released back in 2007...

content:
er 1, 2013
												WARNING: This game feels like a beta at time of writing (01-Dec-2013) thus my review is based on this premise.NOTE: Do not buy this game if you are expecting a perfect/completed game but do buy it if you want to participate in it's evolution. The initial release is a starting point and may feel unplayable by some but Egosoft are now formally adopting a public Beta update strategy.There is no neutral recommendation status so this will have to stand as a recommendation, this game is not perfect by any stretch of the imagination but it does show promise which is why I will let my recommendation stand as a yes rather than a no.First off, I know there are a large number of long-time fans of the X Series of games from Egosoft that consider this game a failure and alot of new comers who also feel the same. Some feel like Egosoft have perhaps been not as open about the nature of the game pre-release as perhaps they should have and others complain about the price of the game but putting things simply IMO the game is not too far off what Egosoft were pitching it as and it "will be" worth the asking price in the long run.If you are expecting a perfect game from X-Rebirth then you are going to be sorely disappointed, there are plenty of flaws with the quality of the software even a fortnight after release but Egosoft are working hard to make things better so lets not dwell on what it is not and more on what it is...X-Rebirth is an attempt by Egosoft to relaunch their X game series with an engine that is more upto date and an interface that is easier for new comers. The latter part is one which many people will dispute it has failed at with the user interface simplified too far and I do agree with this assessment to a large degree but I do believe there is hope of it improving sufficiently based on the current efforts of the X-Rebirth modding community.One of the primary things that is new to the X-series in X-Rebirth is better native support for modding, more specifically the ability to have more than one mod loaded at once. Older versions of the engine did include native modding support but in general it barely got used since most people would want to use more than a single mod package. This change is a welcomed improvement and long overdue. Especially since several mods may currently be necessary to help the game meet the expectations of some long term fans. X-games in general have typically had a strong modding community and this would appear to be continuing with X-Rebirth.Unfortunately at this time, there is not much positive that I can actually write details about but this game does feel to me like it has promise and from my experience with past X games written by Egosoft they tend to improve after release both with the efforts of the modding community and the on-going development by Egosoft themselves.Update: 31-Aug-2013The game is currently at v2.20 and there is a pretty significant patch due in the near future and when this is released I will probably rewrite this review from scratch. In the mean time I felt a small update to this review was required.If you are considering the X games as one series of games then I would stop there. From X-BTF to X3:AP the X-games are considered the X-Trilogy which is based on iterative revisions to the original X-BTF game. As of X-Rebirth, pretty much everything is new (except for lore and perhaps a few ship models). X-Rebirth also brings the game engine design pretty much up to date in technical terms and still requires work in many areas but IMO is still worth getting and playing. No doubt if/when you start playing it you will find it lacking in some areas but Egosoft have been listening to and responding to community observations (mostly in terms of results - patch changes - as they are not really big on getting embroiled in the discussions) but they do have some changes that they appear to consider red lines (possibly due to the Level of Effort required to implement them). We do know they plan to release another X-Game in the future (believed to be a follow on from X-Rebirth) thus the best hope for the red-line changes being addressed is probably in that future title.

												I will start this by saying this game is flawed. Given that I would still recommend this game. For those of you who don't have the patience I would say wait till Christmas or so to buy it at the earliest. It's as though this thing was released in a beta stage while being full price and not being advertised as early access. I am not sure if that is the developers or the publishers fault.The good things about this game is that there is a highly active community of modders and yes fans should not be responsible for fixing or adding features into a game necessarily, it is something that makes the x series in general stand out since it is so easy to mod. In addition Egosoft while having a record of releasing buggy ♥♥♥ near unplayable games also has a record of supporting that game and actually sticking with it and fixing it. So between the highly active community and the devs who actually support their games far after release dates there is always someone working to make the game better or more tailored to how you want to play.This game despite the bugs and issues actually still can be fun. I personally have managed to sink about 50 or so hours into this game and plan to sink many more this coming weekend. It's a game that is definitely enjoyable and becomes much more with a couple of simple mods, the most useful mod currently being the one that crops your cockpit so you can actually see more than the small horizontal slice you currently get. Seriously just that changes the game completely.The bad things are that there are definitely currently some features that are broken or just left out that should be there (does seem like they are meant to be added just not currently there)NPCs don't travel out of their system so there is no trade between jumpgates, there is no way to change which faction controls a zone of space, you could have all friendly stations there and the police force will still be of a faction you are at war with possibly, medium trade and fighters exist along with the shipyards for them but there is no way to buy sell or repair them (there is a way to get them but only through getting the pilot to bail in an existing one and claiming it by having a pilot in your crew), hiring a crew is annoying as hell since the only way to see their stats is to hire and assign them or play a stupid smalltalk minigame that isnt even useful (Tracking down the crew in the first place should count as the minigame and their stats should just be visible if you are allied with their faction), Boarding capitals is broken...unless you try to board a capital ship that already has constructor drones. Otherwise what happens is this: You must destroy engines to board the ship, ship will need contructor drones and an engineer to repair itself (no issue righ?), no way to transfer constructor drones to that ship unless it can move and no way to get it to move without contructor drone...you see the loop here, cap ship dead in water. Bright side not completely useless you can still sell a ship to a capital shipyard dealer no matter where it is. So capping still brings decent monetary reward.Overall this is a game that has a lot of potential, should it have been released in the state it is and been marketed as a completed game at full price? No. However this game will evolve quickly with the mod and dev support it has and I do not regret spending my money on this game.

er 30, 2013
												Once again the X universe has made its way to my PC and once again I find myself using all kinds of mods to make the game play as I want it to. This isn't necessarily a bad thing as I am a firm believer in the ability to mod a good, or even great, game and mold it into the experience you are wanting. The caveat with rebirth is that in its current form modding is almost required to fix certain aspects of the game that were "missed" in the testing stage of the game.  I could list all the little things that have been broken with the game but it's easier to read the patch notes, currently 21 micro-patches to fix bugs,  then it would be for me to list everything that was wrong and has or has not been fixed. It is worth noting that the overwhelming majority of bugs that are currently plaguing the game are in the campaign mode, free play has been by and large a much better experience.  All that being said I am enjoying the game and have yet to come across a bug or error that I haven't been able to bypass in one way or another.  I would recommend this game to fans of the series and to those that are not afraid of modding because there is a good amount of fun to be had here. I would recommend nexus as the best place to get mods, link is below. http://www.nexusmods.com/xrebirth/

												It is sad, but true, that evidence indicates that Egosoft does not seriously beta test their games before release. It is now the first of December and there are, other than technical issues, still problems with the campaign mode, which should have been picked up by beta testers. It is a very pretty game though I suspect that modders will make it far prettier. What has frustrated many old supporters is the lack of all the old functions which made the previous X games complex but also relatively automated. The drones for instance are limited to Launch and Smart Defense. The ships captains don't appear have the functionality to trade independently. You are limited to flying one ship which you don't get to choose, though it's equivalent to an armed yacht. The AI is more prone to "breakage" where they stop functioning because there's no "Failure" Loop. Wait to buy until the second quarter of 2014, when Egosoft may have fixed some of these issues - or the modders have.

												Updated Impressions:After the release of Rebirth 2.0 and later, this game has become much more enjoyable. There was something there to like, when it was first released, but there were too many bugs and glitches in the way of liking it.Now, they have fixed every aspect in the game that I have experienced so far. I am running a few items from the workshop, which refine it a bit more, but the core of the game is now believable.I have played a lot of space games, and I'm not sure what it is that I'm looking for when I play them, but I often find myself playing this game for hours longer than I intended to, and during the whole time I can feel the attention to detail that went into making it an immersive universe.Most of the characters in the stations still look like scary dolls, unfortunately, but they actually look a lot more like the pasty spacefaring folk from previous X titles, and less like unfinished character models.Voice acting has been vastly cleaned up, but there are still some instances of line delivery where the voice actor obviously didn't have any sense of context when they delivered the (sometimes terribly written) lines.The key aspect for me, though, is immersion. In that sense, X-Rebirth is really becoming something special.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This is a game of much potential, but like all Egosoft games before it, it's not quite ready out of the gate. While there are some who believe Egosoft has finally lost their edge (and all of their fanbase), the fact is, most of their true fans know to expect great aftersales support for a product that almost innevitably releases with bugs gallore. Whether you should buy it now or wait relies mainly on your ability to be patient, and the level of love you have for space sims.

												Yes, with a caveat.As with every other X game in the series, Rebirth's Launch has been buggy and somewhat feature starved.  When compared with the depth of the previous x offerings, Rebirth comes away as somewhat shallow.  However, due to the efforts of a dedicated and highly active modding community, I give Rebirth a thumbs up.  Many of the design decisions referenced in other reviews have already been addressed by the community or are well under way to being so.I recommend this game if you like the sound of a highly flexible space sim where the community can have direct influence on the in-game behaviour through modding and AI scripting.  Egosoft has specifically left their software easily moddable to encourage this behaviour, as they have in previous x-games.Should it have been released in this state? No. Will the community make it as flexible and deep a space sim as previous x-games? I do not doubt it.

												My no vote is potentially temporary. It's to be considered a No for right now. Absolutely do not buy this game right now. Just like the history of Egosoft games, it's been released riddled with bugs. Game killing bugs. Bugs that destroy the games ability to do the very things that this game needs to do in order to be a game.But there have been seven patches so far. The lot of them together have fixed quite a bit, but not enough. I'm using patch 8 (beta) and the game is almost entirely playable at this point. It's sort of nice. But it's still not quite there yet. If you jump in, jump in after version 2.0 maybe. I've played this game for over 20 hours. Am I a massochist? Yes. Wait.. no. I just really, really want a great modern space combat/trade/exploration sim. This isn't it... but it has the potential to be. That potential and seeing what I can do next... the empire that I will eventually be able to build is what has kept me going. That and the patches. By version 1.8, players should be able to trade mostly. It is nice.If you are an old X player, this game doesn't work like the last three. You do build up an empire, but you do it from a single ship. You can't take command of cap ships or freighters. Is this a game breaker? For some people, yes. For me? Well, I don't prefer it this way, but the skunk is a capable and fun ship to fly, and I still can have a bunch of other ships at my disposal (and I can ride around in them outside my ship, so that's cool.)The acting is terrible. TERRIBLE. But... it's an Egosoft game. Expecting good acting out of an Egosoft game is like expecting an EA game to not have microtransactions.I give this game a tentative thumbs up for a first or second quarter 2014 purchase. Unfortunately by then, we may have Star Citizen or the new Elite. Or maybe another unexpected title? It remains to be seen.Maybe try it on a steam sale. Heck, there's at least one poor schlub out there enjoying it despite its flaws. (that would be me.)

content:
er 26, 2013
												First off, my ideal space game would be the flight and combat mechanics of Evochron Mercenary coupled with the depth and complexity offered in the free form sandbox of the X series. I believe this is the closest thing I've found to date and though it has it's issues and may put people off for now it's certainly one to keep an eye on. Despite the drawbacks which I explain further below I am still happy to have made the purchase and I plan to play often, it's still fun but mostly I want to keep tabs on the fixes and updates before I make serious run at the campaign and building my empire. More conservative space fans might want to wait it out. The game has a lot of the old systems of the X games but right now they're mostly inaccessible due to bugs and design flaws but they are there and I have no doubt this will become one of my favorite games. It has that much potential but keep in mind that it's potential. I actually appreciate the new direction of the series and think that once the bugs are handled and some optimization is done more and more people will forget about the launch troubles and begin enjoying it themselves. My favorite comment on the design and a great description of what I love about the change was that they wanted to make traveling more fun, much like the GTA series where traveling is an extremely action oriented element of gameplay. I believe they have done that and I love the new travel system with highways and drafting, it's really cool and far more fun to use than gates at NSWE. The controller use in space is great and makes all spaced based elements look and feel more like a sim than a RTS as in previous X games where all the flying was mostly done on drop down menu's except when in a fight for brief periods. Traveling was never fun and took way too long. Make no mistake, X could never get by without menus and they're still around, using the controller is the downfall here as with limited options you have select categories and follow the branches although the menus seem to make things easier to manage and operate like property, market and crew functions even if their navigation is less than perfect. All in all it's a huge change that incorporates a lot of the depth of the X series although not as micro manageable as some seem to prefer it but it's packaged in an action sim which is my dream come true. One of the newest features is the ability to visit and walk in stations which I believe is a great idea and it looks good. It's not amazing by any means but for a feel of actually visiting places by leaving and boarding your ship I like it. There are lockers and chests to raid for loot via Borderlands but mostly it's to make contacts with people to hire on as crew or to peruse their wares as merchants. I haven't found it something that you have to do often if you'd like to avoid it I imagine it would be possible to minimize station visits enough to not be bothered. My problem so far has been the optimization as space looks great stations barely chug along which is disorienting but otherwise acceptable, but only for now. I expect all this to improve. Another feature and what some would consider a drawback is your limitation to only fly one ship from the cockpit. It's a cool ship though which you can walk around, it's small but the views are amazing and I love the HUD. You can upgrade your ship plenty to keep you feeling more powerful and you can still own and remotely fly and manage your fleets, stations and vessels and I feel it was a good tradeoff. I don't want to say the game is not worth the $50 tag because it is although it is NOT worth that much as it stands right now. Pick it up if you are a diehard fan but prepared for frustration. I would recommend everyone keep a sharp eye on the updates which have already been streaming out regularly. This certainly was a rough launch but anyone who writes off a game for a bad launch isn't much of a fan as this is certainly nothing new and it will continue as games become more complex and demanding and users machine become more diverse. I'm not defending anyone except my passion for great experiences through games and as a disabled combat Veteran I am more grateful for the developers efforts in bringing this amazing world to life than I am upset with them for a substandard release. Everyone benefits if it gets fixed so let's just hope for that. Egosoft didn't launch and run and that tells me these guys like what they do and are as embarassed about the issues as some people are upset by them.
